[[2020 United States Senate election in Nebraska]]

CATEGORIES: 2020 United States Senate elections, Nebraska

An election happened on November 3, 2020 to elect a Senator from the U.S. state of Nebraska. The main two people in the election were Ben Sasse (Republican Party), Chris Janicek (Democratic Party). Sasse won the election and went back to the Senate for a second term.

This election was strange because Democratic nominee Chris Janicek, lost the support of his party after a number of scandals, write-in candidate Preston Love Jr., got the support of the state Democratic Party instead but Janicek was still on the ballot. Primary elections happened on March 12, 2020. There were two people in the Republican Party primary election. Ben Sasse won the primary election against Matt Innis. There was seven people in the Democratic Party primary election. Chris Janicek won the primary election. Gene Siadek was the only person in the Libertarian Party primary election. They won the Libertarian Party primary election. 

[[Chord chart]]

CATEGORIES: Musical notation

A chord chart (or chart) is a form of musical notation that describes the basic harmonic and rhythmic information for a song or tune.

[[Virtue signalling]]

CATEGORIES: Human behavior

Virtue signalling is when a person shows anger to make themselves look good to others.  Usually, this means the person says that they don't like or don't approve of something.  For example, a person might talk about political ideas that they know the other people around them agree with.

Psychologists Jillian Jordan and David Rand say that even when people feel true anger, they still show it in ways that they think will make them look good to other people.  They even do this when they are alone.

According to the Boston Globe, the word "virtue signalling" was used as early as 2004 and became popular in 2015.

[[Juan Carlos Copes]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2021 deaths, People from Buenos Aires, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Argentina, Dancers, Choreographers

Juan Carlos Copes (31 May 1931 – 16 January 2021) was an Argentine tango dancer, choreographer, and performer. He started dancing with Maria Nieves when he was 17 and she 14. Copes and Nieves were well known for their Tango dancing from the 1970s and, particularly, in Argentine Tango. He was born in Buenos Aires.

Copes died from COVID-19 on 16 January 2021 at a Buenos Aeries hospital during the COVID-19 pandemic in Argentina, aged 89.  

[[María Nieves]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, Living people, Dancers, Choreographers, People from Buenos Aires

María Nieves Rego (born September 6, 1934) is an Argentine tango dancer and choreographer. She worked with her long time dance partner Juan Carlos Copes in the 1983 musical Tango Argentino. She was born in Buenos Aires.

[[Chris Cramer]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2021 deaths, BBC people, CNN people, British journalists, People from Portsmouth, Cancer deaths in England

Christopher Ranville Cramer (3 January 1948 – 16 January 2021) was a British news journalist and executive. During his career, he was worked for the BBC and was an executive at CNN International. He worked as a consultant for The Wall Street Journal. He was born in Portsmouth, England.

Cramer died of cancer on 16 January 2021 at age 73.

[[György Handel]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, 2021 deaths, Hungarian footballers, Sportspeople from Budapest, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Hungary

György Handel (20 March 1959 – 16 January 2021) was a Hungarian footballer. He played once for the Hungary national football team in 1987. His playing career lasted from 1973 to 1997. He played for Győri ETO and MTK Budapest.

Handel died on 16 January 2021 from COVID-19 during the COVID-19 pandemic in Hungary, aged 61.

[[Pave Maijanen]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from motor neurone disease, Finnish musicians, Finnish singers, Finnish writers, Songwriters, Keyboardists, Drummers, Guitarists, Record producers, Eurovision Song Contest entrants

Pekka Juhani "Pave" Maijanen (3 September 1950 – 16 January 2021) was a Finnish musician and singer-songwriter. He was a bass player, keyboard player, drummer, guitarist and producer. Maijanen was a member of The Royals, Rock'n'Roll Band, Pepe & Paradise. He was the keyboard player and producer of Dingo and the Hurriganes. Maijanen was born in Lappeenranta, Finland.

Maijanen participated in the 1992 Eurovision Song Contest with his song "Yamma, yamma".

In 2018, Maijanen was diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS). He died from the illness on 16 January 2021, aged 70.

[[Schroders]]

CATEGORIES: 1800s establishments in the United Kingdom, 1804 establishments in Europe, Companies of the United Kingdom

Schroders plc is a British multinational asset management company. It was founded in 1804. The company has over 5,000 people worldwide in 32 locations. Its headquarters is in the City of London.

[[Sergi Mingote]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 births, 2021 deaths, Politicians from Barcelona, Mountain climbers, Accidental deaths from falls

Sergi Mingote Moreno (1971 – January 16, 2021) was a Spanish mountaineer and politician. He was also a lecturer at the ESADE. Mingote was born in Parets del Vallès, Spain. He was mayor of Parets del Vallès for the Socialists' Party of Catalonia between 2011 and 2018.

Mingote fell to his death while attempting to climb K2 in Pakistan on January 16, 2021. He was 50.

[[Parets del Vallès]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Catalonia, Municipalities in Catalonia

Parets del Vallès is a city about 23 km north of Barcelona, in Catalonia, Spain, in the south-west of the comarca of Vallès Oriental, and 7 km from its capital Granollers.

[[Bheki Ntuli]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in South Africa, South African politicians

[[Sayidiman Suryohadiprojo]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2021 deaths, Military people, Indonesian politicians, Ambassadors of Indonesia

Sayidiman Suryohadiprojo (21 September 1927 — 16 January 2021) was an Indonesian Javanese Army lieutenant general and politician. He was an Ambassador to Japan from 1979 until 1983 and Ambassador-at-large to Africa from 1992 until 1995. Suryohadiprojo was born in Bojonegoro Regency, East Java. 

Suryohadiprojo died on 16 January 2021 at a Jakarta hospital, aged 93.

[[Ibaté]]

CATEGORIES: Municipalities in São Paulo (state)

Ibaté is a municipality in the state of São Paulo, Brazil. 30,734 people lived here in 2010. 

[[Arturo Tizón]]

CATEGORIES: 1984 births, 2021 deaths, Spanish sportspeople, Deaths in sport

Arturo Tizón Ibáñez (25 May 1984 – 16 January 2021) was a Spanish motorcycle racer. He was born in La Vall d'Uixó, Spain. From 2005 to 2007, he competed in the 250cc Motorcycle World championship. He was the CEV Supersport champion in 2005.

Tizón was killed on 16 January 2021 in a biking accident in Alcudia de Veo, Spain at the age of 36.

[[Pedro Trebbau]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2021 deaths, German scientists, Venezuelan people, Zoologists

Pedro Trebbau (born Karl Peter Trebbau Millowitsch; 20 May 1929 – 16 January 2021) was a German-born Venezuelan zoologist. He was known for his reference book The Turtles of Venezuela. Trebbau was born in Cologne, Germany. Trebbau worked at the El Pinar Zoo and at Caricuao Zoo. 

Trebbau died on 16 January 2021 in Caracas, Venezuela at the age of 91.

[[Paul Varelans]]

CATEGORIES: 1969 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American mixed martial artists, Sportspeople from California

Paul Varelans (September 17, 1969 – January 16, 2021) was an American professional mixed martial artist. He competed in Ultimate Fighting Championship from 1995 to 1996. He had a fixed match in Extreme Championship Wrestling in 1996. He was born in Sunnyvale, California. 

In December 2020, Varelans was hospitalized with COVID-19 in Atlanta, Georgia and was put into an induced coma. He died on January 16, 2021 from the infection at the age of 51.

[[Nikolay Antoshkin]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2021 deaths, Russian military people, Russian politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Russia

Nikolay Timofeyevich Antoshkin (Николай Тимофеевич Антошкин; December 19, 1942 – January 17, 2021) was a Russian Air Force colonel general and politician. He was born in Kuzminovka, Soviet Union. He was known for being in charge over the Chernobyl disaster response. He was a member of the State Duma from 2014 until his death. He was a member of the United Russia. Antoshkin was a Hero of the Soviet Union.

Antoshkin died of COVID-19 in Moscow on January 17, 2021 at the age of 78.

[[Dave Arnold (politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from brain cancer, State legislators of the United States, American lawyers, Politicians from Pennsylvania, US Republican Party politicians

David J. Arnold Jr. (December 7, 1971 – January 17, 2021) was an American politician and lawyer. He was born in Lebanon County, Pennsylvania. Arnold was a member of the Pennsylvania State Senate from 2020 until his death. He was a member of the Republican Party.

Arnold was diagnosed with brain cancer in October 2019. He died on January 17, 2021 in Lebanon County from the disease at the age of 49.

[[Jacques Bral]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, 2021 deaths, French movie directors, French movie producers, French screenwriters, French painters, People from Tehran

Jacques Bral (21 September 1948 – 17 January 2021) was a French movie director, screenwriter, and producer. He was also a painter. He was born in Tehran, Iran. Bral directed and wrote the 2012 movie Black Really Suits You. He wrote the 1989 crime movie Street of No Return.

Bral died in Paris on 17 January 2021 at the age of 72.

[[Harry T. Edwards]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, Living people, American judges, American lawyers, Politicians from New York City, Politicians from Washington, D.C., US Democratic Party politicians

Harry Thomas Edwards (born November 3, 1940), an American politician, lawyer and legal scholar. He is a Senior United States Circuit Judge and chief judge emeritus of the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit in Washington, D.C.. In 1980, he was nominated to the court by President Jimmy Carter.

He is a professor of law at the New York University School of Law.

[[Abel Gabuza]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2021 deaths, Roman Catholic bishops, South African people, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in South Africa

Abel Gabuza (23 March 1955 – 17 January 2021) was a South African prelate of the Catholic Church. He was the Archbishop Coadjutor of the Archdiocese of Durban from 9 December 2018 and until his death in 2021. He was Bishop of Kimberley from 2010 to 2018. He was born in Alexandra, South Africa.

Gabuza died from COVID-19 on 17 January 2021 at the age of 65 in Durban's Hillcrest Hospital.

[[Ghulam Mustafa Khan (singer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2021 deaths, Indian musicians

Ghulam Mustafa Khan (3 March 1931 – 17 January 2021) was an Indian classical musician. His works were in the Hindustani classical music tradition. He was awarded the Padma Shri in 1991, the Padma Bhushan in 2006 and Padma Vibhushan in 2018. Khan was born in present-day Uttar Pradesh, India.

Khan died at his Mumbai home on 17 January 2021, aged 89.

[[.org]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 establishments, Non-profit organizations, Top-level domains

The domain name org is a generic top-level domain (gTLD) of the Domain Name System (DNS) used in the Internet. The name is truncated from organization. It was one of the original domains established in 1985, and has been operated by the Public Interest Registry since 2003. The domain was originally intended for non-profit entities, but this restriction was removed in August 2019. 

In November 2019, the Public Interest Registry (PIR) was to be sold by the Internet Society to shell company Ethos Capital for US$1.135 billion.  However, this move was criticized by non-profits and various digital rights groups on concerns that Ethos Capital, a private equity firm, would raise fees or censor the domain. The sale was blocked by Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN) in April 2020 on the basis that transfer of control of the domain to the private equity firm would create "unacceptable uncertainty" for non-profits that relied on the org domain.

[[First Rutte cabinet]]

CATEGORIES: Cabinets of the Netherlands, 2010 establishments in the Netherlands

The First Rutte cabinet, also called Rutte I cabinet or Rutte I, was a Dutch cabinet, which governed the Netherlands from October 14, 2010 until November 5, 2012 (outgoing from April 23, 2012).

It consisted of the People's Party for Freedom and Democracy (VVD) and the Christian Democratic Appeal (CDA). It was supported by the Party for Freedom (PVV).

The Prime Minister was Mark Rutte (VVD), the Deputy Prime Minister Maxime Verhagen.

It was succeeded by the Second Rutte cabinet.

[[Jubril Martins-Kuye]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2021 deaths, Nigerian politicians

Jubril Martins-Kuye (16 August 1942 – 17 January 2021) was a Nigerian politician. He was a member of the People's Democratic Party. He unsuccessfully ran for Governor of the Ogun State in 1999. From 2010 to 2011, he was  Minister of Commerce and Industry during the Goodluck Jonathan administration.

Martins-Kuye died on 17 January 2021 in Ago Iwoye, Ogun State at the age of 78.

[[Sammy Nestico]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2021 deaths, American composers, Musicians from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, American jazz musicians

Samuel Louis Nistico (February 6, 1924 – January 17, 2021), better known as Sammy Nestico, was an American composer and arranger. Nestico was best known for his arrangements for the Count Basie orchestra.

Nestico died on January 17, 2021 at the age of 96.

[[Vincent M. Rizzotto]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2021 deaths, Roman Catholic bishops, People from Houston, Texas

Vincent Michael Rizzotto (September 9, 1931 – January 17, 2021) was an American prelate of the Roman Catholic Church. Rizzotto was an auxiliary bishop of the Archdiocese of Galveston-Houston from 2001 to 2006. He was born in Houston, Texas. 

Rizzotto died on January 17, 2021 at the age of 89 in Houston.

[[József Sas]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Hungary, Hungarian stage actors, Comedians, Theatre directors

József Sas (born József Polacsek; 3 January 1939 – 17 January 2021) was a Hungarian actor, comedian and theatre manager. He was director of the Mikroszkóp Theatre from 1985 to 2009. He was born in Békéscsaba, Hungary. His career lasted from 1957 to 2018. 

Sas was hospitalized with COVID-19 during the COVID-19 pandemic in Hungary. He died on 17 January 2021 from the infection in Budpaest, aged 82.

[[Philip Wilson (bishop)]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2021 deaths, Australian Roman Catholics, Roman Catholic archbishops, People from Adelaide

Philip Edward Wilson (2 October 1950 – 17 January 2021) was an Australian Roman Catholic prelate. He was the eighth Archbishop of Adelaide from 2001 to 2018. He was President of the Australian Catholic Bishops' Conference from 2006 to 2010. 

From 1996 to 2001 Wilson was bishop of the Diocese of Wollongong. He was born in Cessnock, New South Wales.

Wilson died in Adelaide, South Australia on 17 January 2021, aged 70.

[[La Beaume]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Hautes-Alpes

La Beaume is a commune in the Hautes-Alpes department.

[[Jean-Pierre Bacri]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2021 deaths, French screenwriters, French movie actors, French television actors, Algerian people, Cancer deaths in France

Jean-Pierre Bacri (24 May 1951 – 18 January 2021) was an Algerian-born French actor and screenwriter. He was born in Bou Ismaïl, Algeria. Bacri was known for his movie roles in Same Old Song and Place Vendôme. He was also known for writing the screenplay for The Taste of Others.

Bacri died of cancer in Paris on 18 January 2021, aged 69.

[[Ceillac]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Hautes-Alpes

Ceillac is a commune in the Hautes-Alpes department.

[[Carlos Burga]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2021 deaths, Peruvian people, Boxers, Olympians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Peru

Carlos Burga (12 May 1952 – 18 January 2021) was a Peruvian boxer. He competed in the men's welterweight event at the 1972 Summer Olympics. Burga also competed in the welterweight class at the 1975 Pan American Games.

Burga died on 18 January 2021 from COVID-19 in Lima, Peru at the age of 68.

[[Joshua Kyeremeh]]

CATEGORIES: 2021 deaths, Year of birth missing, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Ghana, Ghanaian politicians

Joshua Kyeremeh (died 18 January 2021) was a Ghanaian politician and administrator. He was a member of the New Patriotic Party. He was a National security coordinator for the President of Ghana. Kyeremeh was Director of the Bureau of National Investigations from 2005 to 2009.

Kyeremeh died on 18 January 2021 at an Accra hospital from COVID-19.

[[Josep Mestres Quadreny]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2021 deaths, Spanish composers

Josep Maria Mestres Quadreny (4 March 1929 – 18 January 2021) was a Catalan composer. He taught at the Darmstadt New Music Courses and the Latin American Course of Contemporary Music in Brazil. 

He was chairman of the Joan Brossa Foundation and an emeritus member of the board of trustees of the Joan Miró Foundation. He composed the music for Nocturne 29.

Mestres Quadreny died on 18 January 2021 in Manresa, Spain at the age of 91.

[[Francisco Daniel Rivera Sánchez]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Mexico, Roman Catholic bishops, Mexican people

Francisco Daniel Rivera Sánchez (15 October 1955 – 18 January 2021) was a Mexican Roman Catholic auxiliary bishop. Rivera Sánchez was born in Guadalajara, Jalisco. He became a priest in 1988. He was titular bishop of Aradi and auxiliary bishop of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Mexico City from 2020 until his death in 2021.

Rivera Sánchez died on 18 January 2021 from COVID-19 during the COVID-19 pandemic in Mexico, aged 65.

[[Pro-Life Action League]]

CATEGORIES: 1980s establishments in Illinois, 1980 establishments in the United States, Abortion, Political organizations based in the United States, Chicago, Illinois

The Pro-Life Action League is an American anti-abortion organization. It was founded by Joseph M. Scheidler in Chicago in 1980. The organization's mission is to end abortion.

It was involved in the Scheidler v. NOW 2006 decision by the United States Supreme Court.

[[Juan Carlos Tabío]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2021 deaths, Cuban screenwriters, Movie directors

Juan Carlos Tabío (1943 – 18 January 2021) was a Cuban movie director and screenwriter. He was best known for his 1994 movie  Strawberry and Chocolate which won awards at the 44th Berlin International Film Festival, and was also nominated for the Academy Award for Best Foreign Language Film. He also directed the 2000 movie Lista de Espera.

Tabío died on 18 January 2021 at the age of 77.

[[William Vickrey]]

CATEGORIES: 1914 births, 1996 deaths, American Protestants, Columbia University faculty, Columbia University alumni, People from Victoria, British Columbia

William Spencer Vickrey (21 June 1914 – 11 October 1996) was a Canadian-American professor of economics. He is a Nobel Laureate. He was awarded the 1996 Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Sciences with James Mirrlees for their research into the economic theory of incentives under asymmetric information, becoming the only Nobel laureate born in British Columbia.

The announcement of his Nobel Prize was made just three days prior to his death. Vickrey died during his journey to a conference of Georgist academics that he helped found. He was never missed once in 20 years. His Columbia University economics department colleague C. Lowell Harriss accepted the posthumous prize on his behalf. There are only three other cases where a Nobel Prize has been presented posthumously.

[[Chris Bauer]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Actors from Los Angeles, California

Mark Christopher Bauer (born October 28, 1966) is an American actor. He was best known for his television work in The Wire, Third Watch, True Blood, Survivor's Remorse and The Deuce.

[[K. V. Vijayadas]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, 2021 deaths, Indian politicians, Deaths from cerebral hemorrhage

K. V. Vijayadas (25 May 1959 – 18 January 2021) was an Indian politician. He was a Member of the Kerala Legislative Assembly from the Kongad (State Assembly constituency) from 2011 until his death. He was a member of the Marxist Communist Party. 

Vijayadas died of a cerebral haemorrhage on 18 January 2021 in Palakkad, India at the age of 61.

[[Fernanda Urrejola]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 births, Living people, People from Santiago, Chilean movie actors, Chilean television actors

Fernanda Loreto Urrejola Arroyo (born September 24, 1981) is a Chilean actress. She was born in Santiago de Chile. Her best known movie roles were in My Best Enemy (2005), Drama (2010) and Bring Me the Head of the Machine Gun Woman (2012). She will star in the 2021 Clint Eastwood movie Cry Macho.

[[Molly Bernard]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, LGBT actors, Lesbians, Actors from New York City

Molly Kate Bernard (born April 10, 1988) is an American actress. She is best known for her role as Lauren Heller on the television series Younger. Bernard was born in New York City.

Bernard is openly lesbian.

[[Jerry Ferrara]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Actors from New York City

Jerry Charles Ferrara (born November 25, 1979) is an American actor. He is known for his role as Turtle on the HBO comedy series Entourage. He starred on the Starz drama series Power as Joe Proctor. Ferrara was born in New York City.

[[Ramji Lal]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2021 deaths, Indian politicians

Ramji Lal (25 March 1930 – 15 January 2021) was an Indian politician. He was in the Rajya Sabha as a member of the  Indian National Congress from 1992 to 1993 and 1994 to 2000.

Lal died on 15 January 2021 at the age of 90.

[[Anatoliy Vishnevskiy]]

CATEGORIES: Russian academics, Economists, 1935 births, 2021 deaths

Anatoliy Vishnevskiy (1 April 1935 – 15 January 2021) was a Russian demographer and economist. He was born in Kharkiv, Kharkiv Oblast. He was a visiting professor at Lumière University Lyon 2, the University of Paris 8 Vincennes-Saint-Denis, and Sciences Po.

Vishnevskiy was editor-in-chief of the information bulletin "Population and Society" and of the online journal "Demoscope Weekly". He was also a writer and historian of the White émigré. 

Vishnevskiy died in Moscow on 15 January 2021 at the age of 85.

[[Jon Arnett]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, Los Angeles Rams players, Chicago Bears players, Sportspeople from Los Angeles, California

Jon Dwane "Jaguar Jon" Arnett (April 20, 1935 – January 16, 2021) was an American professional football player.  He was a first-team All-American. He was born in Los Angeles, California. He played for the Los Angeles Rams from 1957 to 1963 and for the Chicago Bears from 1964 to 1966.

Arnett died on January 16, 2021 from heart failure in Lake Oswego, Oregon at the age of 85.

[[Svavar Gestsson]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2021 deaths, Icelandic politicians, Ambassadors

Svavar Gestsson (26 June 1944 – 18 January 2021) was an Icelandic politician. He was a Minister of Social Affairs from 1980 to 1983. He was an Ambassador to Sweden from 2001 to 2005 and Ambassador to Denmark from 2005 to 2012.

Gestsson died on 18 January 2021 in Reykjavík, Iceland at the age of 76.

[[Maria Koterbska]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2021 deaths, Polish singers

Maria Koterbska (13 July 1924 – 18 January 2021) was a Polish singer. She was popular in the 1950s and 1960s. She was born in Bielsko, Poland. 

In 1999, Koterbska was awarded the Officer's Cross of the Order of Polonia Restituta.

Koterbska was known for her singles were "Augustowskie noce", "Brzydula i rudzielec", "Karuzela", "Parasolki", "Serduszko puka w rytmie cza cza", "Wrocławska piosenka" and "Do grającej szafy grosik wrzuć".

Koterbska died in Bielsko-Biała, Poland on 18 January 2021 at the age of 96.

[[Dündar Ali Osman]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2021 deaths, Turkish people

Dündar Ali Osman (dynˈdaɾ ˈali ˈosman, Dundār ʿEly ʿOsmān; 30 December 1930 – 18 January 2021), also known as Dündar Ali Osman Osmanoğlu was the 45th Head of the House of Osman from 2017 until his death. He was born in Damascus, Syria. 

Osman died on 18 January 2021 in Istanbul, Turkey at the age of 90.

[[David Richardson (writer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from heart failure, American television producers, American television writers, Cancer survivors

David Richardson (December 24, 1955 – January 18, 2021) was an American television writer and producer. He wrote for The Simpsons, Malcolm in the Middle, Two and a Half Men, and F Is for Family. 

Richardson died of heart failure on January 18, 2021 at the age of 65.

[[V. Shanta]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Indian scientists

Viswanathan Shanta (11 March 1927 – 19 January 2021) was an Indian oncologist. She was born in Chennai, India. Shanta was Director of the Adyar Cancer Institute from 1980 to 1997. Shanta was awarded the Padma Shri, Padma Bhushan, and Padma Vibhushan.

Shanta died on 19 January 2021 in Chennai from a heart attack, aged 93.

[[Dani Shmulevich-Rom]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from cancer, Israeli footballers

Daniel "Dani" Shmulevich-Rom (דני (רום) שמולביץ; 29 November 1940 – 18 January 2021) was an Israeli footballer. He played for the Maccabi Haifa F.C. from 1957 to 1973. He also played for the national team.

Shmulevich-Rom died on 18 January 2021 from cancer at the age of 80.

[[Sinclair Hood]]

CATEGORIES: 1917 births, 2021 deaths, British archaeologists, British academics, British centenarians

Martin Sinclair Frankland Hood (31 January 1917 – 18 January 2021), generally known as Sinclair Hood, was a British archaeologist and academic. He was Director of the British School of Archaeology at Athens from 1954 to 1962. He led the excavations at Knossos from 1957 to 1961. 

Hood turned 100 in January 2017. He died on 18 January 2021, two weeks before his 104th birthday.

[[Emanuele Macaluso]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2021 deaths, Italian journalists, Italian politicians, Italian activists, Trade unionists, Accidental deaths from falls

Emanuele Macaluso (21 March 1924 – 19 January 2021) was an Italian trade unionist, journalist and politician. He was born in Caltanissetta, Italy. He was an editor of L'Unità. 

Macaluso was a member of the Italian Communist Party. From 1963 to 1976, he was a member of the Chamber of Deputies. From 1976 to 1992, Macaluso was a member of the Senate.

Macaluso died on 19 January 2021 in Rome from problems caused by a fall, aged 96.

[[University of San Diego]]

CATEGORIES: 1940s establishments in California, 1949 establishments in the United States, Colleges and universities in California, Buildings and structures in San Diego, California

The University of San Diego (USD) is a private Roman Catholic research university in San Diego, California. It was founded in July 1949.

It should not be confused with the University of California, San Diego, nor with the San Diego State University.

[[Süleyman I of Rüm]]

CATEGORIES: 11th century births, 11th century deaths, Turkish people

Süleyman I was born in 1041. and died in 1086. He founded an independent Seljuk Turkish state in Anatolia and ruled as Seljuk Sultan of Rûm from 1077 until his death in 1086.

[[Papurana papua]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

The Papua frog (Papurana papua) is a frog from New Guinea.  It lives in both Indonesia and Papua New Guinea.  It also lives on Manus Island and Waigeo Island.  Scientists have seen it as high as 1200 meters above sea level.

[[Zakraoui]]

CATEGORIES: Names

Zakraoui or Zakaraoui is a name that can refer to : 

[[Nataliya Pipa]]

Nataliya Pipa (born October 12, 1983; Lviv) is a Ukrainian public and political figure, activist, platoon member, former member of AIESEC, former member of the Ukrainian Galician Party, co-founder of the Best Sykhiv NGO. She is the People's Deputy of Ukraine of the IX convocation from the party Holos (ukr. Voice).

[[Ihor Pohodin]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, Living people

Ihor Pohodin or Igor Pogodin (ukr. Ігор Погодін; born February 4, 1974, in Vitebsk, Belarus) is a Belarusian and Ukrainian psychologist, psychotherapist, candidate of psychological sciences, associate professor, director of the Gestalt Institute, leading coach and founder of Pogodin Academy, the Academy of Practical Psychology.

[[Kyiv School of Economics]]

CATEGORIES: 20th century establishments in Ukraine, 1996 establishments in Europe, Colleges and universities in Ukraine, Schools, Kiev

The Kyiv School of Economics (KSE) is a higher education institution founded in 1996 by the Consortium for Economic Research and Education (EERC). In 2017, four master's programs of the Kyiv School of Economics (economic analysis, business and finance economics, KSE business education and public policy and governance) were licensed by the Ministry of Education and Science of Ukraine. From 2021, the Kyiv School of Economics launches two new bachelor's degree programs: Economics and Big Data and IT and Business Analysis. The School does not have a single owner, it is governed by an independent board of directors who do not receive compensation for their work, and an international academic board (which includes, in particular, Nobel Laureate Roger Myerson). The president of KSE is Tymofiy Milovanov, a former Ukrainian mister of economics.

[[Ring girl]]

CATEGORIES: Occupations, Boxing, Martial arts, Professional wrestling

Combat sports such as boxing are done in rounds. Since about 1965, there are usually young women, who hold up the number of the the next round, after one round finished. These women are called ring girls. Very often, ring girls wear a bathing suit or a bikini. They are also meant to entertain the spectators in the pause when there is no combat. They are similar to pit babes, which take this function in motor racing.

[[ChuckleVision]]

CATEGORIES: 1980s British television series, 1990s British television series, 2000s British television series, 1980s children's television series, 1990s children's television series, 2000s children's television series, 1987 television series debuts, 2009 British television series endings, BBC Television programmes, Television series about brothers

ChuckleVision is a British television series created by Martin Hughes and the Chuckle Brothers for the BBC. 

[[American Name Society]]

CATEGORIES: Linguistics, 1952 establishments in the United States, Non-profit organizations of the United States

The American Name Society (ANS) is a non-profit organization started in 1951 to promote onomastics, the study of names and naming practices, both in the United States and around the world. 

[[Japanese battleship Musashi]]

CATEGORIES: Warships

Musashi, named after the former Japanese province, was one of three Yamato. Four ships were begun, but only two were completed as battleships. The third, Japanese aircraft carrier, was completed as an aircraft carrier and the fourth was scrapped before completion.built for the Imperial Japanese Navy (IJN), beginning in the late 1930s. The Yamato-class ships were the heaviest and most powerfully armed battleships ever constructed, displacing almost 72000 fully loaded and armed with nine 46 main guns.

[[Kilmainham Gaol]]

CATEGORIES: Buildings and structures in Ireland, Prisons

The Kilmainham Gaol was a prison in Ireland.

The Kilmainham Gaol opened in 1796.  It was a county jail for the city of Dublin.  It stopped being a jail in 1924.

Today, Irish people think of Kilmainham Gaol as related to nationalism because many rebels and nationalists were prisoners in that jail.  Ordinary criminals were also prisoners in the jail.  Some of the people held in Kilmainham Gaol were later transported to Australia, meaning they were forced to move to Australia.

[[Gallagher]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, Living people, American comedians, People from Tampa, Florida

Leo Anthony Gallagher, Jr. (born July 24, 1946), known mononymously as Gallagher, is an American comedian, best known for smashing watermelons as part of his prop comedy act.

[[Katy Carmichael]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, Living people, English television actors, English movie actors, English comedians, Actors from Liverpool

Katy Jane Carmichael (born 5 March 1970) is an English actress, director, and producer. She is most known for her roles as DC Jo McMullen in the ITV crime drama series Liverpool 1 (1998–1999), Twist Morgan in the Channel 4 sitcom Spaced (1999–2001), Lucy Barlow in the long-running ITV soap opera Coronation Street (2002–2003), and Melissa Ryan in the hit BBC One school-based drama series Waterloo Road (2009).

[[Sarah-Jane Potts]]

CATEGORIES: 1976 births, Living people, English child actors, English television actors, English movie actors, Actors from Bradford, People from Yorkshire

Sarah-Jane Potts (born 30 August 1976) is an English actress. She is best known for her roles as Molly in the American college-based drama series Felicity (2000–2001), 'Saint' Sarah in the Channel 4 comedy-drama series Sugar Rush (2006), Ellie in the BBC One medical drama series Casualty (2008), Jo Lipsett in the hit BBC One school-based drama series Waterloo Road (2009–2010), and Eddi McKee in the BBC One medical drama series Holby City (2011–2012). She has also acted in other British television series such as Children's Ward, The Bill, Peak Practice, Emmerdale and Doctors.

[[Dead Reckoning (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 movies, 1940s mystery movies, American mystery movies, Movies directed by John Cromwell

Dead Reckoning is a 1947 American mystery movie directed by John Cromwell and starring Humphrey Bogart, Lizabeth Scott, Wallace Ford, George Chandler, Morris Carnovsky. It was distributed by Columbia Pictures.

[[New York's 4th congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Congressional districts of New York (state)

New York's 4th congressional district is a congressional district for the United States House of Representatives located on Long Island. The district is currently represented by Kathleen Rice. 

The district includes the communities of Baldwin, Bellmore, East Rockaway, East Meadow, the Five Towns, Lynbrook,  Floral Park, Franklin Square, Garden City, Hempstead, Atlantic Beach, Long Beach, Malverne, Freeport, Merrick,  Mineola, Carle Place, New Hyde Park, Oceanside, Rockville Centre, Roosevelt, Uniondale, Wantagh, West Hempstead, Westbury and parts of Valley Stream.

[[Caste (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 movies, 1930s drama movies, British drama movies, Movies based on plays

Caste is a 1930 British drama movie directed by Campbell Gullan and was based on the play of the same name by T.W. Robertson. It stars Hermione Baddeley, Nora Swinburne, Alan Napier, Ben Field, Sebastian Shaw, Mabel Terry-Lewis and was distributed by United Artists.

[[The Petrified Forest]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 movies, 1930s crime movies, 1930s drama movies, American crime drama movies, Movies based on plays, Warner Bros. movies, Movies directed by Archie Mayo

The Petrified Forest is a 1936 American crime drama movie directed by Archie Mayo and was based on the play of the same name by Robert E. Sherwood. It stars Leslie Howard, Humphrey Bogart, Bette Davis, Joseph Sawyer, Genevieve Tobin, Porter Hall, Dick Foran, Eddie Acuff and was distributed by Warner Bros..

[[New York's 24th congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Congressional districts of New York (state)

New York's 24th congressional district is a congressional district for the United States House of Representatives in western New York. Republican John Katko became the representative in the 2014 election.

The district includes all of Cayuga, Onondaga, and Wayne counties, and the western part of Oswego County. Its largest city is Syracuse.

[[Second inauguration of Barack Obama]]

CATEGORIES: Barack Obama, United States presidential inaugurations, 2013 in the United States, January 2013 events

The second inauguration of Barack Obama as President of the United States was the 57th inauguration and marked the commencement of the second and final term of Barack Obama as President and Joe Biden as Vice President. A private swearing-in ceremony took place on Sunday, January 20, 2013, in the Blue Room of the White House. A public inauguration ceremony took place on Monday, January 21, 2013, at the West Front of the United States Capitol in Washington, D.C.

[[The Ellen DeGeneres Show]]

CATEGORIES: 2000s American television series, 2003 American television series debuts, 2003 in television, 2010s American television series, American LGBT television programs, American television talk shows, Comedy television series, Emmy Award winning programs, English-language television programs

The Ellen DeGeneres Show (often shortened to Ellen and stylized as ellen) is an American daytime television variety comedy talk show that is hosted by Ellen DeGeneres. Debuting on September 8, 2003, it is produced by Telepictures and airs in syndication. The majority of stations owned by NBC Owned Television Stations, along with Hearst Television, serve as the program's largest affiliate base. For its first five seasons, the show was taped in Studio 11 at NBC Studios in Burbank, California. From season 6 onwards, the show moved to being taped at Stage 1 on the nearby Warner Bros. lot. Since the beginning of the sixth season, Ellen has been broadcast in high definition in Season 6, from 2008-present.

The show has received 171 Daytime Emmy Award nominations and has won 61 Daytime Emmy Awards as of 2020, including four for Outstanding Talk Show and seven for Outstanding Talk Show Entertainment, surpassing the record held by The Oprah Winfrey Show, which won nine. The show also won 17 People's Choice Awards. On May 21, 2019, DeGeneres announced she had signed for three more years, renewing the show through 2022. On March 11, 2020, DeGeneres announced over Twitter that for now she would be shooting her show without a studio audience to protect the health and safety of the fans, staff, and crew. In a tweet dated March 13, 2020, DeGeneres announced that production of the show had been suspended until March 30, 2020 to protect the health of her audience and staff during the COVID-19 pandemic.

The eighteenth season premiered on September 21, 2020.

[[Laura Aikman]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 births, Living people, English child actors, English television actors, English movie actors, English stage actors, Actors from London

Laura Holly Aikman (born 24 December 1985) is an English actress. Her most notable roles include Mysti in the CBBC-BBC Two children's fantasy series The Mysti Show (2004–2005), May Phelps in the BBC One medical drama series Casualty (2009–2010), Rosie in the ITV2 mock reality show Lemon La Vida Loca (2012–2013), Melanie Poppy in the CBBC comedy drama and musical children's series 4 O'Clock Club (2012–2014), Natalie Mason in the ITV2 sitcom The Job Lot (2014–2015), Lorna Hutchinson in the BBC One school-based drama series Waterloo Road (2015), and Sonia in the hugely popular BBC One sitcom Gavin & Stacey (2019).

==Other websites==  

[[General Secretary of the Workers' Party of Korea]]

CATEGORIES: North Korea

The General Secretary of the Workers’ Party of Korea (Korean: 조선로동당 총비서) is the leader of the Workers' Party of Korea (WPK), the ruling party in North Korea and typically the supreme leader of North Korea.

The office of WPK Chairman was abolished on 12 October 1966 and replaced with the office of General Secretary by a decision of the 14th Plenary Session of the 4th Central Committee. At the 8th WPK Congress in 2021, where the WPK Chairman was abolished and replaced by the General Secretary of the Workers' Party of Korea.

The current General Secretary of the Workers' Party of Korea is Kim Jong-un, who took office on 10 January 2021.

[[Chairman of the Workers' Party of Korea]]

CATEGORIES: North Korea

The Chairman of the Workers’ Party of Korea (Korean: 조선로동당 위원장) was office that existed within the Workers' Party of Korea (WPK) between 1949–66 and 2016–21. The office of "Chairman of the Central Committee" existed between 1949–66 and the office of "Chairman of the Workers' Party of Korea" existed in 2016–21.

The deputy to the Chairman, the officeholder of Vice Chairman of the Central Committee existed in 1949–66 and 2016–21. This list also includes the chairmen and vice chairmen of the direct predecessors of the WPK.

[[Manpur]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Pakistan

Manpur Cheema is a village in Sialkot,Pakistan. A stream flows along the village which originiates from Himalayas. During the time of partition, Sikh Cheema families migrated to Indian Punjab.

Manpur Cheema is surrounded by other historic villages of Cheema Jatts including Sahowala Cheema, Kamalpur Cheema, Jamke Cheema, Baddoke Cheema, Saabke Cheema, Sahjoke Cheema, Adamke Cheema and Bhopalwala Cheema.

[[Rendezvous with Annie]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 movies, 1940s comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movies directed by Allan Dwan

Rendezvous with Annie is a 1946 American comedy movie directed by Allan Dwan and starring Eddie Albert, Faye Marlowe, Gail Patrick, C. Aubrey Smith, Raymond Walburn, George Chandler, William Frawley, Joyce Compton. It was distributed by Republic Pictures.

[[Up in Central Park]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 movies, 1940s musical movies, 1940s comedy movies, American musical movies, American comedy movies, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by William A. Seiter

Up in Central Park is a 1948 American musical comedy movie directed by William A. Seiter and was based on the play of the same name by Herbert Fields. It stars Deanna Durbin, Dick Haymes, Vincent Price, Albert Sharpe, Tom Powers, Hobart Cavanaugh, Howard Freeman and was distributed by Universal Pictures.

[[Moss Rose (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 movies, 1940s mystery movies, 1940s thriller movies, American mystery movies, American thriller movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Gregory Ratoff

Moss Rose is a 1947 American mystery thriller movie. It was directed by Gregory Ratoff. It was based on the novel of the same name by Marjorie Bowen. It stars Vincent Price, Peggy Cummins, Ethel Barrymore, Victor Mature, Margo Woode, George Zucco. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox and was a box office disappointment.

[[Rush Hour 2]]

CATEGORIES: 2000s action comedy movies, 2001 comedy movies, American action comedy movies, Movies directed by Brett Ratner, Multilingual movies

Rush Hour 2 is a 2001 American action comedy movie directed by Brett Ratner. It was written by Jeff Nathanson, based on the characters created by Ross LaManna. The cast were Jackie Chan, Chris Tucker, Roselyn Sánchez, John Lone, Alan King, Harris Yulin, and Zhang Ziyi. The story follows Chief Inspector Lee (Chan) and Detective James Carter (Tucker), who go to Hong Kong on vacation only to be thwarted by a murder case involving two U.S. customs agents after a bombing at the American embassy. Lee suspects that the crime is linked to the Triad crime lord Ricky Tan (Lone).

Rush Hour 2 opened on August 3, 2001, to generally mixed reviews. The movie was a commercial success. It grosses $347.3 million worldwide. It made the highest-grossing film in the franchise. A sequel, Rush Hour 3, was released on August 10, 2007.

[[RDS Group]]

CATEGORIES: Companies, Ukraine, Transport

RDS is a group of road construction companies founded in 2005 as the “Rost” investment group for housing and commercial real estate construction.

It is included in the TOP-3 road companies of Ukraine in terms of volume (mileage) of roads built. The main office is in Odessa.

[[JSTOR]]

CATEGORIES: 1995 establishments in the United States, American websites, Libraries in the United States

JSTOR (';https://support.jstor.org/hc/en-us/articles/115007466248-JSTOR-Title-Lists short for Journal Storage) is a digital library. It was founded in 1995 in New York City, United States. It was originally containing digitized back issues of academic journals.  It is now encompasses books and other primary sources as well as current issues of journals. It provides full-text searches of almost 2,000 journals.

2013, more than 8,000 institutions in more than 160 countries had access to JSTOR. Most access is by subscription but some of the site is public domain, and open access content is available free of charge.

JSTOR's revenue was $86 million in 2015.

[[Brian Trueman]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, Living people, People from Manchester, English television presenters, English children's writers, English voice actors, English television writers, English screenwriters

Brian Trueman (born 16 May 1932) is an English writer, broadcaster and voice actor. He is known mainly for his work with the animation studio Cosgrove Hall. He wrote and/or narrated children's cartoon series, mostly during the 1970s and 1980s.

[[Víctor Crisólogo]]

CATEGORIES: 1952 births, 2021 deaths, Peruvian politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Peru

Víctor Crisólogo (1952 – 17 January 2021) was a Peruvian politician. He was a member of the Congress of the Republic of Peru from 2011 to 2016. He was a member of the Possible Peru. He was born in Virú, Peru.

Crisólogo died on 17 January 2021 in the Nuevo Chimbote District, Peru from COVID-19, aged 68.

[[Sutton Foster]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 births, Living people, Drama Desk Award winners, Tony Award winning actors, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, American dancers, Actors from Georgia (U.S. state), Singers from Georgia (U.S. state)

Sutton Lenore Foster (born March 18, 1975) is an American actress, singer and dancer. She is known for her work on the Broadway stage. She won two Tony Awards for Best Performance by a Leading Actress in a Musical. She is known for her role as Millie Dillmount in Thoroughly Modern Millie and Reno Sweeney in Anything Goes.

[[Muriel Grossfeld]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2021 deaths, American gymnasts, American Olympians, Sportspeople from New York City

Muriel Evelyn Grossfeld (née Davis October 7, 1940 – January 17, 2021) was an American gymnast. She won a team gold medal at the 1963 Pan American Games. She competed in all artistic gymnastics events at the 1956, 1960 and 1964 Olympics. Grossfeld was born in New York City.

Grossfeld died on January 17, 2021 at the age of 80.

[[Roger Machin]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2021 deaths, Referees, People from Toulon

Roger Machin (26 April 1926 – 17 January 2021) was a French international football referee. Machin was born in Toulon, France. He was member of FIFA in 1964–73 and refereed six international matches. 

Machin died on 17 January 2021 at the age of 94.

[[Sokil Kyiv]]

Hockey Club Sokil Kyiv (Ukrainian: ХК Сокіл Київ; English: Falcon Hockey Club), commonly known as Sokil Kyiv or HC Sokil, is a Ukrainian Professional Hockey League team in Kyiv, the capital of Ukraine. Their home arena is  in the city, but the team also plays out of Brovary, still within the Kyiv region.

Sokil is developed many of the country's top young hockey players, producing NHL All Stars such as Dmitri Khristich and Alexei Zhitnik, and Stanley Cup Champions Ruslan Fedotenko and Anton Babchuk.

[[Junior Mance]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2021 deaths, American composers, American jazz musicians, American pianists, Musicians from Illinois, People from Evanston, Illinois

Julian Clifford Mance, Jr.  (October 10, 1928 – January 17, 2021), known as Junior Mance, was an American jazz pianist and composer. Mance recorded for major labels Capitol (1964–1965) and Atlantic (1966–1970).

He also taught at The New School for Jazz and Contemporary Music for 23 years, retiring in 2011.

From 1990 to 2009 Mance was part of a group called "100 Gold Fingers" which toured Japan every other year.

[[José Alves]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2021 deaths, Brazilian footballers

José Alves, nicknamed Zague (August 10, 1934 – January 19, 2021) was a Brazilian footballer. He played for Corinthians in his home country, and Club América in Mexico.

Alves died on January 19, 2021 at the age of 86.

[[Cesare Maestri]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2021 deaths, Italian writers, Mountain climbers

Cesare Maestri (2 October 1929 – 19 January 2021) was an Italian mountaineer and writer. He was born in Trento, Italy. 

Maestri began climbing in the Dolomites. He was known as the "Spider of the Dolomites". He became an alpine guide in 1952. 

He also climbed the Civetta, the Solda-Conforto Route on the Marmolada, and the southwest ridge of the Matterhorn in winter.

Maestri died on 19 January 2021, aged 91.

[[Gustavo Peña]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2021 deaths, Mexican footballers, Mexican football managers

Gustavo Peña Velasco (22 November 1942 – 19 January 2021) was a Mexican football defender and manager. He was born in Talpa de Allende, Mexico. He made 82 appearances for the national football team between 1961 to 1974. 

Peña died on 19 January 2021, aged 78.

[[Stephanie Seymour]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, Actors from San Diego, California, Models from San Diego, California

Stephanie Michelle Seymour (born July 23, 1968) is an American model and actress. During the 1980s and 1990s, she was one of the most popular supermodels.

In 2000, Seymour played Helen Frankenthaler in the movie Pollock. In 2002, she played Sara Lindstrom in an episode of Law & Order: Criminal Intent.

[[Windows Phone 8]]

CATEGORIES: Microsoft operating systems

Windows Phone 8 is the second release of Windows Phone. It was publicly released on October 29, 2012. It is similar to Windows 8. It is unsupported as of January 12, 2016. It can be upgraded to Windows Phone 8.1 to help updates security for unsupported Windows Phone 8, the first update was leaked on April 8, 2014. Microsoft released the final version, Update 3, on April 14, 2014, just six days after the Windows XP's end of support.

[[Lubomir Kavalek]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2021 deaths, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Czech people, American chess players

Lubomir (Lubosh) Kavalek (Lubomír Kaválek, August 9, 1943 – January 18, 2021) was a Czech-American chess player. 

He was awarded both the International Master and International Grandmaster titles by FIDE in 1965. He won two Czechoslovak and three U.S. championships, and was ranked as the world's #10 player in 1974.

Kavalek was also a chess coach, organizer, teacher, commentator, author and award-winning columnist. He was born in Prague, Czechoslovakia.

Kavalek died on January 18, 2021 in Renton, Washington at the age of 77.

[[Ákos Kriza]]

CATEGORIES: 1965 births, 2021 deaths, Romanian politicians, Hungarian politicians, Economists, Mayors

Ákos Kriza (10 February 1965 − 18 January 2021) was a Romanian-born Hungarian politician and health economist. Kriza was a member of the Fidesz Party. He was Mayor of Miskolc from October 3, 2010 to October 13, 2019. He was born in Oradea, Romania.

Kriza died on 18 January 2021 in Miskolc at the age of 55.

[[Chuck Mills]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, Deaths from multiple organ failure, American football coaches, Sportspeople from Chicago

Morton J. "Chuck" Mills (December 1, 1928 – January 18, 2021) was an American college football coach. Mills was born in Chicago, Illinois.

His career lasted from 1957 to 1997. He was the head coach at Pomona College, Indiana University of Pennsylvania, the United States Merchant Marine Academy, Utah State University, Wake Forest University, Southern Oregon University, and the United States Coast Guard Academy.

Mills died on January 18, 2021 in Honolulu, Hawaii from pneumonia caused by multiple organ failure, aged 92.

[[Henryk Ostrowski]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2021 deaths, Polish politicians

Henryk Ostrowski (1960 – 18 January 2021) was a Polish politician and farmer. He was a member of the Sejm from 2001 to 2005. He was a member of the Self-Defence of the Republic. Ostrowski was born in Szprotawa, Poland.

Ostrowski died on 18 January 2021 in Szprotawa, aged 60.

[[Jimmie Rodgers (pop singer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2021 deaths, American rock guitarists, American country guitarists, American folk musicians, American folk singers, American rock singers, American country singers, American pianists, Musicians from Washington, Singers from Washington

James Frederick Rodgers (September 18, 1933 – January 18, 2021) was an American folk pop singer. He was popular in the 1950s and 1960s. He was known for his singles "Honeycomb", "Kisses Sweeter than Wine" and "Secretly".

Rodgers died on January 18, 2021 at the age of 87.

[[Camas, Washington]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Washington (U.S. state)

Camas ˈ is a city in Clark County, Washington. About 19,355 lived here at the 2010 census.

[[Gatot Sudjito]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2021 deaths, Indonesian politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Indonesia

Gatot Sudjito (28 October 1960 – 18 January 2021) was an Indonesian politician. He was a member of the Golkar party. Sudjito was born in Sidoarjo Regency, Indonesia. From 2014 until his death, he was a member of the People's Representative Council. 

Sudjito died on 18 January 2021 in Malang, Indonesia from COVID-19, aged 60.

[[Don Sutton]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2021 deaths, Cancer deaths in California, Los Angeles Dodgers players, Houston Astros players, Milwaukee Brewers players, Oakland Athletics players, California Angels players, Sportspeople from Alabama

Donald Howard Sutton (April 2, 1945 – January 18, 2021) was an American professional baseball pitcher and broadcaster. He played in Major League Baseball (MLB) from 1966 to 1988. He played for the Los Angeles Dodgers, Houston Astros, Milwaukee Brewers, Oakland Athletics, and California Angels. He was born in Clio, Alabama.

In 1998, Sutton was honored in the National Baseball Hall of Fame and Museum.

Sutton died on January 18, 2021 in Rancho Mirage, California from cancer, aged 75.

[[Giovanni Zucchi]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2021 deaths, Italian Olympians, Olympic bronze medalists, Rowers

Giovanni Zucchi (14 August 1931 – 19 January 2021) was an Italian rower. He competed in the 1956, 1960, and the 1964 Summer Olympics, winning bronze in 1960. He won five gold medals at European Rowing Championships. Zucchi was born in Mandello del Lario, Italy.

Zucchi died on 19 January 2021, aged 89.

[[Sibusiso Moyo]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, 2021 deaths, Zimbabwe politicians, Generals, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Zimbabwe

Sibusiso Busi Moyo (1961 – 20 January 2021) was a Zimbabwean politician and Army major general. He was Minister of Foreign Affairs and International Trade from 2017 until his death. Moyo was born in Mberengwa, Zimbabwe.

Moyo died on 20 January 2021 from COVID-19 in Harare, Zimbabwe.

[[Lâm Quang Thi]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2021 deaths, Vietnamese people, Generals, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States

Lieutenant General Lâm Quang Thi (7 May 1932 – 19 January 2021) was a Vietnamese senior military officer in the Army of the Republic of Vietnam. He was active from 1950 to 1975 including the Vietnam War. Thi was born in Bạc Liêu, French Indochina.

Thi died on 19 January 2021 in Fremont, California at the age of 88 from COVID-19.

[[Danial Jahić]]

CATEGORIES: 1979 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Serbia, Long jumpers, Serbian sportspeople, Olympians

Danial Jahić (1 July 1979 – 19 January 2021) was a Serbian athlete. He competed in the men's long jump at the 2000 Summer Olympics.

On 19 January 2021, Jahić died at the age of 41 from COVID-19.

[[Nombulelo Hermans]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in South Africa, South African politicians, Women politicians

Nombulelo Lilian Hermans (1 January 1970 - 18 January 2021) was a South African politician. She was a member of the African National Congress. She was in a Member of the National Assembly of South Africa from 2019 until her death in 2021.

Hermans died from COVID-19 on 18 January 2021.

[[Xavier Hunault]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2021 deaths, French mayors

Xavier Hunault (29 January 1923 – 16 January 2021) was a French politician. From 1959 to 1989, he was Mayor of Châteaubriant. From 1962 to 1993, Hunault was a member of the National Assembly. He was born in Châteaubriant.

Hunault died on 16 January 2021, aged 97.

[[John Joseph Ryba]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2021 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Chicago, Politicians from Wisconsin, US Democratic Party politicians

John Joseph Ryba Jr. (August 10, 1929spaced ndashJanuary 9, 2021) was an American politician and public administrator. Ryba was a member of the Democratic Party. He was a member of the Wisconsin State Assembly from 1993 to 2003, representing Green Bay. Ryba was born in Chicago, Illinois.

Ryba died on January 9, 2021 in De Pere, Wisconsin at the age of 91.

Robinson Township is a township in Allegheny County, Pennsylvania, United States. It is about 12 west of Pittsburgh. 13,354 people lived here at the 2010 census.

[[Robinson Township, Washington County, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: Townships in Pennsylvania

Robinson Township is a township in Washington County, Pennsylvania, United States. The population was 1,931 at the 2010 census.

[[Cry Macho (movie)]]

Cry Macho is an upcoming American neo-Western drama movie directed and produced by Clint Eastwood. He also stars in the movie. It is based on the 1975 novel of the same name by N. Richard Nash. The movie was produced by Eastwood's Malpaso Productions. It will be theatrically released by Warner Bros. Pictures, and digitally on HBO Max on the same day, sometime in 2021.

Nathan Richard Nusbaum (June 8, 1913 – December 11, 2000), known as N. Richard Nash, was an American writer and dramatist. He was best known for writing Broadway shows, including The Rainmaker.

[[Decatur, Tennessee]]

Decatur (d dih) is a town in Meigs County, Tennessee, United States. 1,598 people lived here at the 2010 census. It is the county seat of Meigs County.

[[Decaturville, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Tennessee, County seats in Tennessee

Decaturville is a town in and the county seat of Decatur County, Tennessee, United States. 867 people lived here at the 2010 census.

[[Parsons, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Tennessee

Parsons is a city in Decatur County, Tennessee, United States. 2,373 people lived here at the 2010 census. Parsons is the largest city by population in Decatur County.

[[Shabestar]]

Shabestar (شبستر; also known as Chabiastar, Shabiastar, and Shabistar) is a city and is the capital of Shabestar County, East Azerbaijan Province, Iran.  As of the 2011 census, its population was 25,663.

[[Moluccas frog]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Asia, Frogs

The Moluccas frog (Papurana moluccana) is a frog from the Moluccas in Indonesia.

[[Cap]]

CATEGORIES: Headgear

A cap is a form of headgear or headware. Caps have crowns that fit very close to the head. They have been used in almost every society, especially those societies which have colder weather.

They made their first appearance as early as 3,200BC. Caps typically have a visor, but sometimes have no brim at all. They are popular in casual and informal settings, and are seen in sports and fashion.  They are designed for warmth, and often have a visor to block sunlight from the eyes. They come in many shapes, sizes, and are of different brands. Baseball caps are one of the most common types of cap.

[[Maxime Verhagen]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, Living people, Christian Democratic Appeal politicians, Deputy Prime Ministers of the Netherlands, Dutch businesspeople, Dutch councillors, Dutch historians, Dutch Roman Catholics, Former leaders of political parties in the Netherlands, Former members of the House of Representatives of the Netherlands, Former MEPs, Government ministers of the Netherlands, MEPs for the Netherlands, People from Maastricht, Politicians from Limburg (Netherlands), Writers from Limburg (Netherlands)

Maxime Jacques Marcel Verhagen (born 14 September 1956, Maastricht) is a former Dutch politician of the Christian Democratic Appeal (CDA).

Verhagen studied history at Leiden University.

He was a member of the municipal council of Oegstgeest from 1989 to 1990, a member of the European Parliament from 1989 to 1994, a member of the House of Representatives from 1994 to 2007 and in 2010, and also parliamentary leader from 2002 to 2006 and in 2010.

From 2007 to 2010, he was foreign minister, in the Fourth Balkenende cabinet. He also was development cooperation minister in the same cabinet in 2010. From 2010 to 2012, he was both economics and agriculture minister, and deputy prime minister in the First Rutte cabinet.

Verhagen was leading the CDA from 2010 to 2012.

Since July 2013 he has been chairing Bouwend Nederland.

Maxime Verhagen is married with three children, and a member of the Catholic Church. He lives in Voorburg (province of South Holland).

[[Poop deck]]

CATEGORIES: Ship building

A poop deck is part of a ship. It is the deck that is the roof of a cabin. It is at the back of a ship. Usually, it is the highest deck. Note that poop comes from French poupe, Latin puppis, which is the name of the stern of a ship.  

[[1991 Georgian independence referendum]]

CATEGORIES: 1991 in Asia, 1991 in Europe, History of Georgia (country)

A referendum was held  on 31 March, 1991 in the Republic of Georgia. The question was: "Do you support the restoration of the independence of Georgia in accordance with the Act of Declaration of Independence of Georgia of May 26, 1918?"

[[New York's 9th congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Congressional districts of New York (state)

New York's 9th congressional district is a congressional district for the United States House of Representatives in New York. The district is in New York City. The representative is Yvette Clarke.

The district is located entirely within Brooklyn. It includes the neighborhoods of Brownsville, Crown Heights, East Flatbush, Flatbush, Kensington, Park Slope, Prospect Heights, Midwood, Sheepshead Bay, Marine Park, Gerritsen Beach, and Prospect Lefferts Gardens.

[[He Loves to Fly and He D'ohs]]

CATEGORIES: The Simpsons episodes, 2007 television episodes

"He Loves to Fly and He D'ohs" is the first episode of the 19th season of The Simpsons. It was first shown on the Fox network on September 23, 2007. It is the first episode to be shown after The Simpsons Movie was first shown in movie theaters. The episode is about Homer Simpson trying to get a job that will let him fly an airplane. The episode was written by Joel H. Cohen. Mark Kirkland is the director of the episode. Lionel Richie and Stephen Colbert are guest stars in the episode.

[[New York's 1st congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Congressional districts of New York (state)

New York's 1st congressional district is a congressional district for the United States House of Representatives located on Long Island. The district had voted for a Democrat but in 2014, Republican Lee Zeldin.

The district has the counties of Suffolk County, Smithtown, Brookhaven, Riverhead, Southold, Southampton, East Hampton, and Shelter Island. The very wealthy neighborhoods of the Hamptons are also in the district. 

[[New York's 20th congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Congressional districts of New York (state)

New York's 20th congressional district is a congressional district for the United States House of Representatives located in the middle of New York. It includes all of Albany and Schenectady counties, and parts of Montgomery, Rensselaer, and Saratoga counties. Democrat Paul Tonko represents the district since 2013.

[[New York's 6th congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Congressional districts of New York (state)

New York's 6th congressional district is a congressional district for the United States House of Representatives in New York City. The district is part of Queens. It is represented by Democrat Grace Meng. The district has voted for a Democrat every election since 1983. Over 714,000 people live in the district.

[[New York's 19th congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Congressional districts of New York (state)

New York's 19th congressional district is a congressional district in New York. It is in the middle of the state and north of New York City. The counties of Columbia, Delaware, Greene, Otsego, Schoharie, Sullivan, and Ulster are all in the district, and parts of Broome, Dutchess, Montgomery, and Rensselaer counties are also in the district. The 19th district borders Vermont, Massachusetts, and Connecticut to the east, and Pennsylvania to the southwest. The district is represented by Democrat Antonio Delgado since 2018.

[[New York's 27th congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Congressional districts of New York (state)

The 27th congressional district of New York is a congressional district for the United States House of Representatives in western New York.  It includes all of Orleans, Genesee, Wyoming, and Livingston counties and parts of Erie, Monroe, Niagara, and Ontario counties. The district is represented by Republican Chris Jacobs since 2020. The district used to be represented by Republican Chris Collins but he left his job after he was found guilty of insider trading a special election was held to take Chris Collin's job. Chris Jacobs won the election.

[[New York's 13th congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Congressional districts of New York (state)

New York's 13th congressional district is a congressional district for the United States House of Representatives located in New York City. The representative is Democratic congressman Adriano Espaillat. The district is the smallest congressional district in the U.S. Upper Manhattan and parts of the West Bronx are the places the district is in.

[[Dharmaśāstra]]

CATEGORIES: Hindu texts, Religious behavior and experience, Law

Dharmaśāstra (धर्मशास्त्र) is a genre of Sanskrit theological texts, and refers to the treatises (śāstras) of Hinduism on dharma.

[[Thermopause]]

CATEGORIES: Atmosphere, Earth sciences

The thermopause is part of the planet Earth's atmosphere.  It is the top of the thermosphere.

[[Fear Strikes Out]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 drama movies, American drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Robert Mulligan

Fear Strikes Out is a 1957 American biographical drama movie directed by first time director Robert Mulligan and was based on the 1955 memoir of the same name by Jimmy Piersall. It stars Anthony Perkins, Karl Malden, Adam Williams, Perry Wilson and was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[Australian plate]]

CATEGORIES: Tectonic plates, Indian Ocean, Australia

Australian plate is a major plate tectonic that is a section of Indo-Australian plate. Australia is located centrally on the Australian plate and is remarkably stable tectonically. Australian plate and Indian plate is two separates plate, in the most recent issue of Earth and Planetary Science Letter (vol. 133).

[[Casanova's Big Night]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 comedy movies, American comedy movies, Movies directed by Norman Z. McLeod

Casanova's Big Night is a 1954 American comedy movie directed by Norman Z. McLeod and starring Bob Hope, Joan Fontaine, Audrey Dalton, Basil Rathborne, Hugh Marlowe, Arnold Moss, John Carradine, John Hoyt, Hope Emerson, Lon Chaney Jr., Raymond Burr, Vincent Price. It was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[The Kid from Brooklyn]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 movies, 1940s musical movies, 1940s comedy movies, American musical movies, American comedy movies, Movies directed by Norman Z. McLeod

The Kid from Brooklyn is a 1946 American musical comedy movie directed by Norman Z. McLeod and was a remake of the 1936 movie The Milky Way. It stars Danny Kaye, Virginia Mayo, Vera-Ellen, Steve Cochran, Eve Arden, Walter Abel and was distributed by RKO Radio Pictures.

[[The Razor's Edge]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 movies, 1940s drama movies, 1940s romance movies, American romantic drama movies, Movies based on books, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Edmund Goulding

The Razor's Edge is a 1946 American romantic drama movie directed by Edmund Goulding and was based on the 1944 novel of the same name by W. Somerset Maugham. It stars Tyrone Power, Gene Tierney, John Payne, Anne Baxter, Clifton Webb, Herbert Marshall, Lucile Watson, Frank Latimore, Elsa Lanchester and was distributed by 20th Century Fox. It was nominated for 4 Oscars and won an Academy Award in 1947.

Firmin Ngrébada (born 1968) is the current prime minister of the Central African Republic since February 25, 2019.

[[Zoë Bell]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, Living people, Stuntmen, New Zealand movie actors

Zoë E. Bell (born 17 November 1978) is a New Zealand stuntwoman and actress. Some of her best known stunt work was doubling for Lucy Lawless in Xena: Warrior Princess and for Uma Thurman in Kill Bill.

[[Don Stroud]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, Living people, Surfers, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, American stage actors, Actors from Honolulu, Musicians from Hawaii

Donald Lee Stroud (born September 1, 1943) is an American actor, musician, and surfer.

Stroud appeared with Clint Eastwood in two movies, Coogan's Bluff (1968) and Joe Kidd (1972).

He played Sheriff Bob Sharp in the 2012 movie Django Unchained.

[[Lindsay Hartley]]

CATEGORIES: 1978 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, Actors from California, People from Palm Springs, California

Lindsay Nicole Korman (born April 17, 1978) is an American actress. She played Theresa Lopez-Fitzgerald Crane Winthrop on Passions, Cara Castillo on All My Children and Arianna Hernandez on Days of Our Lives. She was born in Palm Springs, California.

[[Carmen Carrera]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, LGBT models, LGBT actors, American LGBT rights activists, LGBT people from New Jersey, Models from New Jersey, Actors from New Jersey

Carmen Carrera (born April 13, 1985) is an American reality television personality, model, burlesque performer, and actress. She is known for appearing on the third season of the Logo reality television series RuPaul's Drag Race.

Carrera is a transgender woman and a transgender rights activist.

[[Elmwood Park, New Jersey]]

CATEGORIES: Boroughs in New Jersey

Elmwood Park is a borough in Bergen County, New Jersey, United States. In the 2010 United States Census, 19,403 people lived here.

[[Fantastic Mr. Fox (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2009 comedy movies, 2009 animated movies, American comedy movies, American animated movies, Movies directed by Wes Anderson, Movies based on books

Fantastic Mr. Fox is a 2009 American stop motion animated comedy movie directed by Wes Anderson. It is based on Roald Dahl's 1970 children's novel of the same name.

The movie stars the voices of George Clooney, Meryl Streep, Jason Schwartzman, Bill Murray, Willem Dafoe, Michael Gambon, and Owen Wilson. 

It was released on November 13, 2009. The movie also received nominations for the Academy Award for Best Animated Feature and Best Original Score, but lost  both to Up.

[[Isle of Dogs (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2018 science fiction movies, 2018 comedy movies, 2018 animated movies, 2018 drama movies, American science fiction movies, American comedy movies, American animated movies, American drama movies, Movies directed by Wes Anderson

Isle of Dogs is a 2018 stop-motion science-fiction comedy-drama adult animated movie written, produced, and directed by Wes Anderson. It stars Bryan Cranston  as the dog Chief and Koyu Rankin as a young human called Atari. 

The movie also stars Edward Norton, Liev Schreiber, Bill Murray, Bob Balaban, Jeff Goldblum, Scarlett Johansson, Kunichi Nomura, Tilda Swinton, Ken Watanabe, Akira Ito, Greta Gerwig, Akira Takayama, Frances McDormand, F. Murray Abraham, Courtney B. Vance, Yojiro Noda, Fisher Stevens, Mari Natsuki, Nijiro Murakami, Yoko Ono, Harvey Keitel, and Frank Wood.

It had a limited release in the United States on March 23, 2018, by Fox Searchlight Pictures, and went on wide release on April 13. It was nominated for two Academy Awards, for Best Animated Feature Film and Best Original Score.

[[Boris Zaborov]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2021 deaths, Belarusian people, Painters

Boris Zaborov (Барыс Абрамавіч Забораў; 16 October 1935 – 20 January 2021) was a Soviet Belarusian artist. He moved to Paris, France in 1980 to begin a career in painting. He was born in Minsk.

Zaborov died on 20 January 2021 in Paris at the age of 85.

[[Mike Sadek]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2021 deaths, San Francisco Giants players, Sportspeople from Minneapolis, Minnesota, Cardiovascular disease deaths in California, Deaths from lung disease

Michael George Sadek (May 30, 1946 – January 20, 2021) was a Major League Baseball catcher. He spent his entire major league career with the San Francisco Giants. His career lasted from 1975 to 1981.

Sadek died on January 20, 2021 in San Andreas, California from heart and lung disease, aged 74.

[[John Baptist Kaggwa]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Uganda, Roman Catholic bishops, Ugandan people

John Baptist Kaggwa (23 March 1943 – 20 January 2021) was a Ugandan Roman Catholic prelate. He was Bishop Emeritus of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Masaka from 10 January 1998 until his retirement on 16 April 2019. From 19 December 1994 until 10 January 1998, Bishop Kaggwa was Coadjutor Bishop of Masaka, Uganda. Kaggwa was born in Bulenga, Wakiso District, Uganda.

Kaggwa died on 20 January 2021 at a hospital in Kampala, Uganda from COVID-19 at the age of 77.

[[Lars Westman (writer)]]

CATEGORIES: Swedish journalists, 1934 births, 2021 deaths, Swedish novelists

Lars Gustaf Westman (16 April 1934 – 16 January 2021) was a Swedish writer and journalist. Westman was the grandson of architect Carl Westman and the artist Elin Westman. He was a journalist at Stockholms-Tidningen and the magazine We. In 2012, he published the book Till Saltsjöbaden.

Westman died on 16 January 2021, aged 86.

[[James D. Heiple]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2021 deaths, American lawyers, American judges, Politicians from Illinois, People from Peoria, Illinois, US Republican Party politicians, Deaths from cerebral hemorrhage

James D. Heiple (September 13, 1933 – January 18, 2021) was an American lawyer and Republican politician. He was elected as a Justice of the Illinois Supreme Court in 1990. He was its chief justice from 1997 until his retirement 2000. Heiple was born in Peoria, Illinois.

Heiple died on January 18, 2021 at a hospital in Peoria from a cerebral hemorrhage, aged 87.

[[Tom Prebble]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2021 deaths, Educators, People from Wellington

Thomas Kenneth Prebble NZL (November 1945 – 17 January 2021) was a New Zealand educationalist and university administrator. He was born in Wellington, New Zealand.

In the 2019 New Zealand Honours, Prebble was appointed a Member of the New Zealand Order of Merit.

Prebble died on 17 January 2021 in Palmerston North, New Zealand aged 75.

[[Barbara Gronemus]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2021 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Wisconsin, US Democratic Party politicians

Barbara (née Barry) Gronemus (November 21, 1931 – January 17, 2021) was an American politician and farmer. Gronemus was born in Norwalk, Wisconsin. She was a Democratic Party member of the Wisconsin State Assembly from 1982 through 2008. 

Gronemus died in Blair, Wisconsin on January 17, 2021 at the age of 89.
