[[Gerald Wiegert]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, 2021 deaths, Engineers from Michigan, Businesspeople from Michigan, People from Dearborn, Michigan

Gerald Alden "Jerry" Wiegert (July 12, 1944 – January 15, 2021) was an American automotive engineer and businessman. He was the founder of two companies, Vector Motors and Aquajet. Wiegert was born in Dearborn, Michigan.

Wiegert died on January 15, 2021 at the age of 76.

[[Benjamin de Rothschild]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Bankers, French businesspeople

Benjamin de Rothschild (30 July 1963 – 15 January 2021) was a French banker. He is the owner of the Edmond de Rothschild Group from 1997 until his death. He was the son of Edmond Adolphe (1926–1997) and Nadine (born 1932). In 1972, he created the professional offshore sailing racing team Gitana Team.

On 15 January 2021 De Rothschild  suffered a heart attack and died, at his home in Pregny-Chambésy, Switzerland. He was 57.

[[Nadine de Rothschild]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, Living people, French writers, French movie actors, French stage actors

Nadine de Rothschild (née Nadine Nelly Jeannette Lhopitalier; born 18 April 1932) is a French author and former actress.

She appeared in The Sleepwalker, Women of Paris, Children of Love, Madame du Barry, Girls at Sea.

[[Socialist Republic of Romania]]

CATEGORIES: 1940s establishments in Romania, 1947 establishments in Europe, 1989 disestablishments in Europe, Former countries in Europe, Former countries in the Balkans, Former socialist republics, States and territories established in the 1940s, States and territories disestablished in the 20th century

From 1947 to 1989, Romania was a socialist republic. From 1947 to 1965, it was called Romanian People's Republic (Republica Populară Romînă, RPR). In 1965, Nicolae Ceaușescu came to power.  He succeeded Gheorghe Gheorghiu-Dej, who died of cancer that year. To reflect the change, the state was renamed to Socialist Republic of Romania. After the fall of the Berlin wall, in 1989, there was a revolution. Protesters wanted Ceaușescu to step down. During demostrations, Romanian Secret police, Securitate used weapons. Part of the regular armed forces joined the protests. Over 1000 people were killed in the fights that resulted.  Ceaușescu was captured, and tried before a military tribunal. The tribunal sentenced him and his wife to death. Together with his wife, he was shot, on December 25, 1989. Ion Iliescu became the new president.

[[Paincourtville, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in Louisiana

Paincourtville is a census-designated place (CDP) in Assumption Parish, Louisiana, United States. 911 people lived here at the 2010 census.

[[Devi Shetty]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, Indian philanthropists, Living people

Devi Prasad Shetty, MS, FRCS, (born 8 May 1953) is an Indian cardiac surgeon.https://www.credihealth.com/doctor/devi-prasad-shetty-cardiac-surgeon/overview/ref  He is also entrepreneur. He is the chairman and founder of Narayana Health, a chain of 21 medical centers in India. He has performed more than 15,000 heart operations. In 2004 he was awarded the Padma Shri, the fourth highest civilian award, followed by the Padma Bhushan in 2012, the third highest civilian award by the Government of India for his contribution to the field of affordable healthcare.

[[Andy Powell]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, Living people, English guitarists, Singer-songwriters from London

Douglas Jared Powell (born 19 February 1950) is an English musician. He has been one of the lead guitarists for the band Wishbone Ash since 1969. Some have called him one of the most influencial guitarists in history, along with other Wishbone Ash guitarists Ted Turner and Laurie Wisefield.

[[Radio Data System]]

CATEGORIES: Radio technology, Everyday life

Radio Data System is a communication protocol that allows to send small amounts of digital information in a common FM radio broadcast. Aside from time and date, this commonly is the name of the station, or information about the program that is currently broadcast. First tests were done in 1983 and 1984, the standard was officially introduced in 1988. 

The following types of information can be sent:

It is possible to transmit Radio Text. In theory, it is possible to transmit 64 characters per line.

[[Papurana novaeguineae]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Oceania, Frogs

The New Guinea frog (Papurana novaeguineae) is a frog from southern New Guinea. Scientists saw it between between Yamur Lake and the Purari River.

[[Orange banana]]

CATEGORIES: Musaceae

Fe'i banana or Orange banana is a cultivar of banana that occurs on Pacific islands, the Moluccas, and in Papua New Guinea. Unlike other banana species, its sap is red, and not white. When ripe, the fruit has an orange-red color. Today, it is not clear where the banana grew originally. It might have been on Papua. Unlike the dessert banana, this kind of banana is rarely eaten raw.

[[Electrecord]]

CATEGORIES: 20th century establishments in Romania, 1932 establishments in Europe, Record labels, Classical music, Jazz music, Pop music, Rock music, World music, Electronic music, Electronic music record labels

Electrecord is a Romanian record label that started in 1932. It was the only record label in Communist Romania because their government believed in centralization.

[[2003 Georgian constitutional referendum]]

CATEGORIES: Referendums

The 2003 Georgian constitutional referendum was a referendum that was held on 2 November 2003 alongside parliamentary elections. Question was: Are you for or against the reduction in the number of Georgian parliamentarians to 150 members?.

[[New York's 11th congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Congressional districts of New York (state)

New York's 11th congressional district is a congressional district for the United States House of Representatives in New York City. The 11th district includes all of Staten Island and areas of Brooklyn. The district is currently represented by Republican Nicole Malliotakis who was elected in 2020. The district used to be represented by Democrat Max Rose but was on of the few districts that changed to Republican in the 2020 elections.

[[New York's 23rd congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Congressional districts of New York (state)

New York's 23rd congressional district is a congressional district in the state of New York. The district is in the southwest of New York and goes on the border of the state of Pennsylvania. The west side of the district is the shore of Lake Erie. The district has the counties of Allegany, Cattaraugus, Chautauqua, Chemung, Schuyler, Seneca, Steuben, Tompkins, and Yates county along with parts of Ontario and Tioga counties. The district is currently represented by Republican Tom Reed.

[[The Heiress]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 movies, 1940s romance movies, 1940s drama movies, American romantic drama movies, Movies based on plays, Movies based on books, Movies directed by William Wyler

The Heiress is a 1949 American romantic drama movie directed by William Wyler and was based on the 1947 play of same name and also adapted from the 1880 novel Washington Square by Henry James. It stars Olivia de Havilland, Montgomery Clift, Ralph Richardson, Miriam Hopkins, Vanessa Brown, Russ Brown and was distributed by Paramount Pictures. It was nominated for 8 Oscars and won 4 Academy Awards in 1950.

[[New York's 16th congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Congressional districts of New York (state)

New York's 16th congressional district is a congressional district for the United States House of Representatives  in the state of New York. The district is currently represented by Democrat Jamaal Bowman. Jamaal Bowman has been representing the district since 2021, he beat Democrat Eliot Engel in the Democratic Party primary election and won the general election. A Republican has not represented the district since 1949. The 16th district includes the northern part Bronx and the southern half of Westchester County, and also has the cities of Mount Vernon, Yonkers, New Rochelle, and Rye.

[[The Best Years of Our Lives]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 movies, 1940s war movies, 1940s drama movies, American drama movies, World War II movies, Best Picture Oscar, Movies based on books, Movies directed by William Wyler

The Best Years of Our Lives (also known as Glory for Me and Home Again) is a 1946 American drama movie directed by William Wyler and was based on the novella Glory for Me by MacKinlay Kantor. It stars Myrna Loy, Fredric Marsh, Dana Andrews, Teresa Wright, Virginia Mayo, Cathy O'Donnell, Hoagy Caramichael, Harold Russell, Gladys George, Steve Cochran, Howland Chamberlain and won 7 Academy Awards in 1947. It was distributed by RKO Radio Pictures.

[[Dragonwyck (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 movies, 1940s drama movies, American drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Joseph L. Mankiewicz

Dragonwyck is a 1946 American drama movie directed by first time director Joseph L. Mankiewicz and was based on the 1944 novel of the same name by Anya Seton. It stars Gene Tierney, Walter Huston, Vincent Price, Glenn Langan, Anne Revere, Spring Byington, Harry Morgan, Jessica Tandy and was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Red (Pokémon)]]

CATEGORIES: Pokémon characters, Anime characters

Red is the main protagonist of Pokémon Red and Blue, the first two games in the Nintendo's Pokémon franchise, as well as the Pokémon Green and Yellow sequels. 

The protagonist of the main Pokémon's anime adaptation, Ash Ketchum, was based on him.

[[List of Members of the U.S. House of Representatives]]

CATEGORIES: United States-related lists, United States House of Representatives

This is a list of all the current members of the United States House of Representatives. There are currently 435 representatives in the House. 221 representatives are part of the Democratic Party and 211 representatives are part of the Republican Party. There are also delegates from the United States territories. These delegates cannot vote but can take part in committees and other jobs. 

[[Alabama's 2nd congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Congressional districts of Alabama

Alabama's 2nd congressional district is a United States congressional district in Alabama that elected a representative to the United States House of Representatives. It includes most of the Montgomery and into the southeastern part of the state. The district has parts of Montgomery County and all of Autauga, Barbour, Bullock, Butler, Coffee, Conecuh, Covington, Crenshaw, Dale, Elmore, Geneva, Henry, Houston and Pike counties.

The district is represented by Republican Barry Moore since 2021. Barry Moore took over from Martha Roby who retired in 2020.

[[Barry Moore (Alabama politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, United States representatives from Alabama, People from Enterprise, Alabama, US Republican Party politicians, Living people

Barry Moore (born September 26, 1966) is an American politician who is the representative for Alabama's 2nd congressional district in the House of Representatives. Barry is a Republican and has been the representative since 2021 but he first tried to get elected in 2018 but lost in the primary election. Moore was first a state senator for Alabama's 91st district in 2010. In 2014 he was arrested because he lied to police but Barry was not punished. Moore joined 147 House of Representatives Republicans to try to get rid of the 2020 United States presidential election results. 

[[Criss Cross (1949 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 movies, 1940s crime movies, 1940s drama movies, American crime drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Robert Siodmak

Criss Cross is a 1949 American crime drama movie directed by Robert Siodmak and was based on the 1934 novel of the same name by Don Tracy. It stars Burt Lancaster, Yvonne De Carlo, Dan Duryea, Stephen McNally, Tom Pedi, Percy Helton, Esy Morales, Alan Napier, Edna Holland, Tony Curtis (in his movie debut) and was distributed by Universal Pictures. It was remade as The Underneath in 1995.

[[Alabama's 3rd congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Congressional districts of Alabama

Alabama's 3rd congressional district is a United States congressional district in the state of Alabama. The district elects a person to represent the district in the United States House of Representatives. The district has been represented by Republican Mike Rogers since 2003. 

The district is in the east and middle of Alabama and is part of Montgomery and the entirety of Calhoun, Chambers, Cherokee, Clay, Cleburne, Lee, Macon, Randolph, Russell, St. Clair, Talladega, and Tallapoosa counties.

[[Mike Rogers (Alabama politician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, United States representatives from Indiana, People from Hammond, Indiana, US Republican Party politicians, Living people

Mike Rogers (born July 16, 1958) is an American politician and the U.S. Representative for Alabama, since 2003. He is a part of the Republican Party. Mike Rogers was first a part of Alabama's House of Representatives from 1994-2002 before becoming a representative. Mike Rogers does not support abortion but did support getting rid of the Environmental Protection Agency. In December 2020, Rogers and 126 Republicans agreed to stop the results of the 2020 United States presidential election. 

[[Cobra roll]]

CATEGORIES: Roller coasters

A cobra roll is a part of a roller coaster. It is a double-inversion and it looks like the shape of a striking cobra's head. A cobra roll has two half-vertical loops facing the same direction joined together by two half corkscrews that each twist in opposite directions. The coaster train enters the cobra roll' low, completes the first half loop, then turns perpendicular into a half corkscrew, completing a first inversion. This is immediately followed by another half corkscrew that twists in the opposite direction into the other half vertical loop, completing a second inversion and exiting the cobra roll traveling in the opposite direction from which it entered.

[[30 Hudson Yards]]

CATEGORIES: 2010s establishments in New York (state), 2019 establishments in the United States, Skyscrapers in New York City, Buildings and structures in Manhattan, Buildings and structures completed in the 21st century

30 Hudson Yards is the fifth tallest building in the New York City, as of 2019.  This building has 73 floors.  It is 1273 feet tall. Its observation deck, "The Edge," is the highest in New York State.  This is where CNN segments are aired LIVE and is home to Wells Fargo, Facebook, and KKR.  Aside from the business part, it is the biggest tourist attraction in New York City.

[[Keith Valigura]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2021 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Texas, US Republican Party politicians

Keith Valigura (November 6, 1957 – January 12, 2021) was an American Republican politician. He was a member of the Texas House of Representatives from the 16th district from 1985 to 1991. He was born in College Station, Texas.

Valigura died on January 12, 2021, in Conroe, Texas at age 63.

[[National University of Kyiv-Mohyla Academy]]

CATEGORIES: 1610s establishments in Europe, 1615 establishments, Establishments in Ukraine, Colleges and universities in Ukraine, Kiev

The National University of Kyiv-Mohyla Academy (NaUKMA) is a higher education institution in Ukraine founded in 1615. The university campus is in Podil in Kyiv, between Kontraktova Square and the Dnipro river. Teaching at the university is in Ukrainian and English. From 2009 to 2014 it was an autonomous research university.

NaUKMA is the successor of the historical Kyiv-Mohyla Academy which was founded on the basis of the Kyiv Brotherhood School. In 1615, this school received funds from the noblewoman Halshka Hulevychivna. Some teachers of Lviv and Lutsk brotherhood schools moved to Kyiv to teach in Kyiv Mohyla Academy. The school had the support of the Zaporozhian Cossacks, Hetman Sahaidachnyi and Hetman Mazepa.

In September 1632, the Kyiv Brotherhood School merged with the Lavra School. As a result, the Kyiv-Bratsk Collegium was established. Kyiv Metropolitan Petro Mohyla built an education system on the model of Jesuit educational institutions. Much attention in the board was paid to the study of languages, including Polish and Latin.

[[Kotoraantkari]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Georgia (country)

Kotoraantkari (კოტორაანთკარი) is a small village in Mtskheta, Georgia.

[[Peter Mogila]]

CATEGORIES: 1596 births, 1647 deaths

Petro Mohyla or Petro Mogila (Ukrainian: Петро Могила; 21 (31) December 1596, - 1 (11) January 1647) was a Ukrainian political, church and educational figure. He was a Metropolitan of Kyiv, Halych, and All Rus' (1633-1647). He was a representative of the Moldavian noble family Mohyla (in Romanian Movilă). He was born in Suceava, Romania. He is a son of the Moldavian pricne Simion Mohyla (Movilă).

He took part in the political life of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth. He participated in the Khotyn War (1620-1621). He carried out a radical reform of the Orthodox Church and education in Ukraine according to Catholic and Greek Catholic models. He is the founder of Ukrainian theology. He is the author of "Trebnik" (1646), co-author of the catechism "Orthodox Confession of Faith" (1640). He died in Kyiv in 1647 and was buried in Kyiv-Pechersk Lavra. He is a local saint as he was recognized as saint by the Ukrainian Orthodox Church (Moscow Patriarchate) and the Ukrainian Orthodox Church of the Kyiv Patriarchate in 1996.

[[William Fey]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2021 deaths, Roman Catholic bishops, People from Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania

Bishop William  Regis Fey, O.F.M.Cap. (November 6, 1942 – January 19, 2021) was an American Roman Catholic prelate. He was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. He became a priest in 1968. Fey was appointed bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Kimbe, in Kimbe, Papua New Guinea, on June 8, 2010. 

Fey died on January 19, 2021 at the age of 78.

[[Louis Giani]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2021 deaths, American wrestlers, American Olympians, Sportspeople from New York City

Louis Giani (August 18, 1934 – January 19, 2021) was an American wrestler. He competed in the men's freestyle featherweight at the 1960 Summer Olympics. He was a member of the National Wrestling Hall of Fame. He was born in New York City.

Giani died on January 19, 2021 in Huntington, New York at the age of 86.

[[Meherzia Labidi Maïza]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic, Translators, Tunisian politicians

Meherzia Labidi Maïza (محرزية العبيدي معيزة;17 December 1963 – 21/22 January 2021) was a Tunisian politician and professional translator. She was a member of the Assembly of the Representatives of the People from 2011 to 2019 and from 2020 until her death. She was a member of the Ennahda Movement. Labidi Maïza was born in Hammamet, Tunisia.

Labidi Maïza died of COVID-19 in Tunis in January 2021, aged 57.

[[Assembly of the Representatives of the People]]

CATEGORIES: Tunisia, Politics of Tunisia

The Assembly of the Representatives of the People (مجلس نواب الشعب ar, Assemblée des représentants du peuple; ARP) is the legislature of Tunisia. The unicameral Assembly replaced the Constituent Assembly on 26 October 2014. It has 217 members. 

The current speaker of the Assembly is Rached Ghannouchi.

[[Dysautonomia]]

CATEGORIES: Diseases

Dysautonomia or autonomic dysfunction is a condition in which the autonomic nervous system (ANS) does not work properly. This may affect the heart, bladder, intestines, sweat glands, pupils, and blood vessels. Dysautonomia has many causes and may not be neuropathic.

[[Mira Furlan]]

CATEGORIES: 1955 births, 2021 deaths, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Croatian actors, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, American video game actors, Actors from Los Angeles, California, Singers from Los Angeles, California, People from Zagreb, Deaths from West Nile virus

Mira Furlan (7 September 1955 – 20 January 2021) was a Croatian-American actress and singer. She played Ambassador Delenn on the science fiction television series Babylon 5 and Danielle Rousseau on Lost. 

Furlan died on 20 January 2021 in Los Angeles, aged 65. The cause of death was problems caused by the West Nile virus.

[[Babylon 5]]

CATEGORIES: 1993 American television series debuts, 1998 American television series endings, American science fiction television series

Babylon 5 is an American space opera television series created by writer and producer J. Michael Straczynski. The show premiered in the US on January 26, 1994, and ran for five seasons.

[[Jack London (businessman)]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2021 deaths, Businesspeople from Oklahoma

J. Phillip "Jack" London (1937 – January 2021) was an American businessman. He was born in Oklahoma. He was the executive chairman and chairman of the board of CACI International Inc.

London died in January 2021 at the age of 83.

[[John Russell (musician)]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, 2021 deaths

John Russell (19 December 1954 – 18 January 2021) was an American acoustic guitarist who worked in free improvisation. His career began in the 1970s. Russell was born in Kent, England. 

Russell died on 18 January 2021 from cancer, aged 66.

[[Dominic J. Squatrito]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2021 deaths, American judges, Politicians from Hartford, Connecticut, US Democratic Party politicians

Dominic J. Squatrito (April 9, 1938 – January 20, 2021) was an American politician and lawyer. He was nominated to the United States District Court for the District of Connecticut in 1994 by President Bill Clinton. Squatrito was born in Hartford, Connecticut.

Squatrito died on January 20, 2021 in Manchester, Connecticut at the age of 82.

[[Theme Building]]

CATEGORIES: Buildings and structures completed in the 20th century, Buildings and structures in Los Angeles, California

The Theme Building is a Space Age structure at Los Angeles International Airport in California. It was influenced by "Populuxe" architecture. It is built in a Mid-century modern style now called "Googie".  It was built between 1957 and 1961. It was listed as a Historical-Cultural Monument by the city of Los Angeles in 1993.

[[Ted Thompson]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2021 deaths, Tennessee Titans players, Green Bay Packers, American football linebackers, Sportspeople from Texas, Deaths from autoimmune disease

Ted Thompson (January 17, 1953 – January 20, 2021) was an American professional football player and executive in the National Football League (NFL). He was born in Atlanta, Texas.

He was the general manager of the Green Bay Packers from 2005 to 2017. Thompson had a 10-year playing career in the NFL as a linebacker and special teams player with the Houston Oilers from 1975 to 1984. He won two Super Bowls in 1997 and 2011.

In May 2019, Thompson announced that he was diagnosed with dysautonomia, an autonomic disorder. He died on January 20, 2021 in Atlanta, Texas from the disease, three days after his 68th birthday.

[[José Pampuro]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2021 deaths, Cancer deaths in Argentina, Argentine politicians, People from Buenos Aires

José Juan Bautista Pampuro (28 December 1949 – 21 January 2021) was an Argentine politician. He was a member of the Justicialist Party. He was born in Buenos Aires. From 2005 to 2011, Pampuro was a Senator from Buenos Aires.

Pampuro was the Defense Minister during the Néstor Kirchner presidency from 2003 to 2005. From 2006 to 2011, he was the Provisional President of the Senate. From 2002 to 2003, he was the General Secretariat of the Presidency during the Kirchner presidency.

Pampuro died on 21 January 2021 at a Buenos Aires hospital from cancer, aged 71.

[[Edgar Kaminskyi]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 births, Living people

Edgar Kaminskyi (Ukrainian: Едгар Камінський; born 27 February 1985) is a Ukrainian plastic surgeon, founder of Kaminskyi Clinic and Kaminskyi HUB, organizer and patron of the Ukrainian Medical Festival and speaker of medical conferences.

[[Orpierre]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Hautes-Alpes

Orpierre is a commune in the Hautes-Alpes department.

[[Anthony Mwamba]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic, Zambian sportspeople, Olympians, Boxers

Anthony Mwamba (8 August 1960 – 21 January 2021) was a Zambian boxer. He competed in the men's light welterweight event at the 1988 Summer Olympics. 

Mwamba won a bronze medal in the welterweight (67 kg) division at the 1990 Commonwealth Games.

Mwamba died on 21 January 2021 from COVID-19 in Lusaka, aged 60.

[[Space Age]]

CATEGORIES: Space, History

The Space Age is the time period in human history related to the space race, space exploration, and space technology. Most people say this started when Sputnik 1 was launched in 1957, and continues to today. This has influenced culture such as in movies, television, music, art, and architecture.

[[Vasyl Komisarenko]]

Vasyl Pavlovych Komisarenko (January 1, 1907, Chernyakhiv - April 7, 1993, Kyiv) was a Ukrainian endocrinologist and pathophysiologist, academician of the Academy of Medical Sciences of Ukraine and academician of the National Academy of Sciences of Ukraine, organizer and director of the Institute of Endocrinology and Metabolism. Head of the Department of Pathophysiology 1955-1960.

[[Jackson Mthembu]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in South Africa, South African politicians

Jackson Mphikwa Mthembu (5 June 1958 – 21 January 2021) was a South African politician. He was Minister in the Presidency of South Africa's government from 2019 to 2021. He was a member of the African National Congress (ANC). He was the Whip of Parliament from 2016 to 2019. Mthembu was born in Witbank, South Africa.

Mthembu died of COVID-19 on 21 January 2021 in Johannesburg, aged 62.

[[Windows Phone 7]]

CATEGORIES: Microsoft operating systems, Smartphones

Windows Phone 7 is the first release of the Windows Phone mobile client operating system, released on November 8, 2010, worldwide was released on October 21, 2010. It runs on Windows CE 6.0 kernel.

They have similar to Windows 7 but received updates from Microsoft, the last being is Windows Phone 7.8, which was released on March 13, 2013. After few features backported for Windows Phone 8, such as a more customizable start screen. The succeeded is Windows Phone 8, released in 2012.

[[Jerry Kiernan]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, 2021 deaths, Irish Olympians

Jeremiah "Fran" Kiernan (31 May 1953 – 21 January 2021) was an Irish long-distance runner. He was born in Listowel, County Kerry. He represented his native country at the 1984 Summer Olympics in Los Angeles, California, where he finished in ninth place in the men's marathon.

Kiernan twice won the Dublin Marathon, in 1982 and 1992.

Kiernan died on 21 January 2021, aged 67.

[[Rémy Julienne]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in France, French movie actors, Stuntmen, Racecar drivers

Rémy Julienne (17 April 1930 – 21 January 2021) was a French stuntman, racecar driver and actor. He was a rallycross champion and 1956 French motorcross champion. He was born in Cepoy, France. He appeared in over 1,400 movies. He was known for being the stuntman on The Italian Job, The Da Vinci Code and six James Bond movies.

Julienne died on 21 January 2021 in France from COVID-19, aged 90.

[[Jean Graton]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2021 deaths, French writers, French artists, Comics writers, Cartoonists, Comics artists

Jean Graton (10 August 1923 – 21 January 2021) was a French comic book author and cartoonist. Graton created the famous character Michel Vaillant and his comics series of the same name in 1957. Graton was born in Nantes, France. 

On 21 January 2021, Graton died in Brussels, Belgium, at the age of 97.

[[Nathalie Delon]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2021 deaths, Cancer deaths in France, French movie actors, French stage actors, French movie directors, French novelists, Autobiographers

Nathalie Delon (born Francine Canovas; 1 August 1941spnd21 January 2021) was a French actress, writer and movie director. She was known for starring in many movies with her ex-husband Alain Delon. Her best known movie roles was in Le Samouraï by Jean-Pierre Melville. 

Delon died at the age of 79, on 21 January 2021 in Paris from cancer.

[[Jean-Pierre Melville]]

CATEGORIES: 1917 births, 1973 deaths, Deaths from stroke, Movie directors from Paris, Movie producers from Paris, French screenwriters

Jean-Pierre Melville (mɛlvil; born Jean-Pierre Grumbach; 20 October 1917 – 2 August 1973) was a French filmmaker and actor.

He became well known for his noir movies, such as Le Doulos (1962), Le Samouraï (1967) and Le Cercle rouge (1970). 

[[Phouoibi]]

CATEGORIES: Meitei gods and goddesses

Phouleima   is the goddess and the female personification of the agriculture, crops, grains, paddy, rice and wealth in Meitei mythology and religion.

She is the lover of Akongjamba, a hero in ancient legend. But fate doesn't permit the lovers to unite. So, Phouoibi and Akongjamba reincarnated in the legend.

The Meitei people believe that the gleaming black stone is a personification of the goddess, which if kept inside the earthenware pot of the granary, will bring good luck and prosperity, as long as it shines.

[[Lino Ventura]]

CATEGORIES: 1919 births, 1987 deaths, Italian movie actors, French movie actors, People from Emilia-Romagna, Deaths from myocardial infarction

Angiolino Giuseppe Pasquale Ventura (14 July 1919 – 22 October 1987) was an Italian actor. He was known for playing a tough man, either a criminal or a cop. He played a cop leader of the Resistance in the Jean-Pierre Melville directed Army of Shadows.

Some of his most famous roles include the portrait of corrupt police chief Tiger Brown in The Threepenny Opera (1963) and mob boss Vito Genovese in The Valachi Papers (1972).

[[Claude Miller]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2012 deaths, Movie directors from Paris, Movie producers from Paris, Writers from Paris, French screenwriters

Claude Miller (20 February 1942 – 4 April 2012) was a French movie director, producer and screenwriter.

He was inspired by François Truffaut. He was known for directing La meilleure façon de marcher, Les Mistons (1957) and The 400 Blows (1959).

[[Claude Sautet]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2000 deaths, Deaths from liver cancer, French screenwriters, French movie directors

Claude Sautet (23 February 1924 – 22 July 2000) was a French movie director and screenwriter.

His first movie, Hello Smile! came out in 1956. He was well known for his movie The Things of Life, which he wrote and directed.

Sautet died of liver cancer in Paris at the age of 76.

[[Michel Serrault]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2007 deaths, French movie actors, French stage actors

Michel Serrault (24 January 1928 – 29 July 2007) was a French stage and movie actor. He appeared from 1954 until 2007 in more than 130 movies.

He met and worked with Jean Poiret in the early 1950s. Their movies were Cette sacrée gamine (1956) with Brigitte Bardot and Sacha Guitry's last movie Assassins et voleurs (1957).

[[Sacha Guitry]]

CATEGORIES: 1885 births, 1957 deaths, French movie actors, French stage actors, French screenwriters, Movie directors from Paris, Actors from Paris, Writers from Paris

Alexandre-Pierre Georges "Sacha" Guitry (gitʁi; 21 February 1885spaced ndash24 July 1957) was a French stage and movie actor, director, screenwriter, and playwright.

[[Ngaleima]]

CATEGORIES: Meitei gods and goddesses

"Lemlei Ngaleima" (lem-lei ngaa-lei-ma), also spelt as "Ngareima" (ngaa-rei-ma), is the female deity and the divine personification of the fishes and the aquatic life in Meitei mythology and religion. She is a daughter of Atingkok and a sister of the goddesses, Phouoibi, Thumleima and Ereima.

[[Hank Coe]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2021 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Wyoming, US Republican Party politicians, Deaths from pancreatic cancer

Henry H. R. "Hank" Coe (April 29, 1946 – January 21, 2021) was an American politician. He was a Republican member of the Wyoming Senate from 1989 until 2021. Coe was born in Cody, Wyoming.

Coe died on January 21, 2021 in Cody from pancreatic cancer at the age of 74.

[[Henryk Chmielewski (comics)]]

CATEGORIES: 1923 births, 2021 deaths, Polish artists, Polish journalists, Comics artists, Writers from Warsaw

Henryk Jerzy Chmielewski (7 June 1923 – 22 January 2021), also known under his pseudonym Papcio Chmiel, was a Polish comic book artist and journalist.

He started working as a graphic artist in the Świat Młodych magazine, where he also published comics. He was known for creating the Tytus, Romek i A'Tomek comic book series, which began in 1966.

Chmielewski died on 22 January 2021 in Warsaw, aged 97.

[[Thumleima]]

CATEGORIES: Meitei gods and goddesses

"Noinu Thumleima" (ꯅꯣꯢꯅꯨ ꯊꯨꯝꯂꯩꯃ), also known as "Thumkhong Lairembi" (ꯊꯨꯝꯈꯣꯡ ꯂꯥꯢꯔꯦꯝꯕꯤ), is the goddess and the female personification of the salt and the natural salt brines in Meitei mythology and religion. She is a sister of goddesses, Phouleima, Ngaleima and Ereima. She is worshipped by the people for the prosperity of salt, which is a main composition of diet for the mankind.

She is considered to be the concubine of Pakhangba, the royal deity.

[[Pittman Center, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Tennessee

Pittman Center is an incorporated town in Sevier County, Tennessee, United States. 477 people lived here at the 2000 census.

[[Sevier County, Tennessee]]

Sevier County (s "severe") is a county of the U.S. state of Tennessee. In the 2010 census, 89,889 people lived here. Its county seat and largest city is Sevierville.

[[Sevierville, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Tennessee, County seats in Tennessee

Sevierville s is a city in and the county seat of Sevier County, Tennessee. 14,807 people lived here at the 2010 United States Census.

[[Pigeon Forge, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Tennessee

Pigeon Forge is a mountain resort city in Sevier County, Tennessee, United States. In the 2010 census, the city had 5,875 people living here.

[[Princess Stéphanie of Monaco]]

CATEGORIES: 1965 births, Living people, Princes and princesses of Monaco, Singers, Models

Princess Stéphanie of Monaco (Stéphanie Marie Elisabeth Grimaldi; born 1 February 1965) is the youngest child of Rainier III, Prince of Monaco, and the American actress Grace Kelly.

She is the younger sister of Albert II, Prince of Monaco, and Caroline, Princess of Hanover. She is the 14th in the line of succession to the Monegasque throne. She was also a singer, swimwear designer and fashion model.

[[Caroline, Princess of Hanover]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, Living people, Princes and princesses of Monaco

Caroline, Princess of Hanover (Caroline Louise Marguerite Grimaldi; born 23 January 1957), is the oldest child of Rainier III, Prince of Monaco, and the American actress Grace Kelly. She is the oldest sister of Prince Albert II and Princess Stéphanie. 

Until the births of her niece and nephew, Princess Gabriella and Prince Jacques, in December 2014, was the heir presumptive to the throne of Monaco.

Caroline is married to Ernst August, Prince of Hanover (born 1954).

[[Prince Ernst August of Hanover (born 1954)]]

CATEGORIES: 1954 births, Living people, Princes and princesses, People from Hanover

Ernst August, Prince of Hanover (Ernst August Albert Paul Otto Rupprecht Oskar Berthold Friedrich-Ferdinand Christian-Ludwig Prinz von Hannover Herzog zu Braunschweig und Lüneburg Königlicher Prinz von Großbritannien und Irland; born 26 February 1954), is head of the royal House of Hanover. He is the husband of Princess Caroline of Monaco. He is the brother-in-law of Albert II, Prince of Monaco.

[[Jacques, Hereditary Prince of Monaco]]

CATEGORIES: 2014 births, Living people, Princes and princesses of Monaco

Jacques, Hereditary Prince of Monaco, Marquis of Baux (Jacques Honoré Rainier Grimaldi; born 10 December 2014), is the heir apparent to the Monegasque throne. He is the son of Prince Albert II and Princess Charlene. He is the twin brother of Princess Gabriella.

The newborn prince was baptised Jacques Honoré Rainier. He received the title Marquis of Baux from his father.

[[John Garfield]]

CATEGORIES: 1913 births, 1952 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, American movie actors, American stage actors, American political activists, Actors from New York City

John Garfield (born  Jacob Julius Garfinkle, March 4, 1913 – May 21, 1952) was an American actor. He was nominated for two Academy Awards for his roles in Four Daughters (1938) and Body and Soul (1947). 

[[Robert Walker (actor, born 1918)]]

CATEGORIES: 1918 births, 1951 deaths, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, Drug-related accidental deaths in the United States, Actors from Salt Lake City, Utah

Robert Hudson Walker (October 13, 1918 – August 28, 1951) was an American actor. He was known for his role as the villain in Alfred Hitchcock's thriller Strangers on a Train (1951).

[[Claiborne Pell]]

CATEGORIES: 1918 births, 2009 deaths, Deaths from Parkinson's disease, United States senators from Rhode Island, Politicians from New York City, US Democratic Party politicians

Claiborne de Borda Pell GCC GCM (November 22, 1918 – January 1, 2009) was an American politician and writer. He was a United States Senator from Rhode Island for six terms from 1961 to 1997. He was a member of the Democratic Party. Pell is the longest serving U.S. Senator from Rhode Island.

He retired from the U.S. Senate because of bad health since he had Parkinson's disease.

[[Lady and the Tramp (2019 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2019 romance movies, 2010s musical movies, Disney movie remakes, American musical movies, American romance movies

Lady and the Tramp is a 2019 American live-action/CGI musical romance movie directed by Charlie Bean and written by Andrew Bujalski and Kari Granlund. It was produced by Walt Disney Pictures and Taylor Made.

The movie is a live-action and CGI version of Walt Disney’s 1955 animated movie of the same name.

The movie stars the voices of Tessa Thompson, Justin Theroux, Janelle Monáe, and Sam Elliott with the human characters played by Thomas Mann, Kiersey Clemons, Yvette Nicole Brown, F. Murray Abraham, Adrian Martinez, and Ken Jeong.

Lady and the Tramp was released on November 12, 2019 on Disney+.

[[Jim Dale]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, Living people, English movie actors, English television actors, English voice actors, English comedians, English singer-songwriters, English composers, People from Northamptonshire, Drama Desk Award winners, Tony Award winning actors, Grammy Award winners

Jim Dale, GBR (born James Smith; 15 August 1935) is an English actor, singer-songwriter, director, and composer. He appeared in many of the Carry On movies. He is well known narrating all seven of the Harry Potter audiobooks in the American market.

He also starred in the Disney movie Pete's Dragon (1977). He was nominated for a BAFTA Award for playing a young Spike Milligan in Adolf Hitler: My Part in His Downfall (1973).

[[Aeneas Chigwedere]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2021 deaths, Zimbabwean people, African politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Zimbabwe, African writers, Historians

Aeneas Soko Chigwedere (En-us-Aeneas Chigwedere from Zimbabwe pronunciation (Voice of America).ogg) (25 November 1939 – 22 January 2021) was a Zimbabwean politician, historian, educationist, and traditional leader. He was the Minister of Education, Sports, & Culture from August 2001 until his death. He became Governor of Mashonaland East Province in August 2008. 

Chigwedere died on 22 January 2021 after suffering from COVID-19 at the age of 81.

[[José Crisologo Sorra]]

CATEGORIES: 1929 births, 2021 deaths, Roman Catholic bishops, People from Manila

José Crisologo Sorra (9 March 1929 – 21 January 2021) was a Filipino Roman Catholic bishop. Sorra was born in the Manila, Philippines. He became a priest in 1956. He was bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Virac Philippines, from 1974 to 1993 and as bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Legazpi from 1993 to 2005.

Sorra died on 21 January 2021, aged 91.

[[Renita Grigoryeva]]

CATEGORIES: Russian movie directors, Russian movie actors, Russian screenwriters, 1931 births, 2021 deaths

Renita Andreevna Grigorieva (Russian: Рени́та Андре́евна Григо́рьева; July 13, 1931 – January 19, 2021) was a Russian director, actress, writer, and screenwriter. She was a 1983 winner of the USSR State Prize. She directed the 1990 movie Boys. She also starred in There Is Such a Lad. 

Grigoryeva died on January 19, 2021 at the age of 89.

[[Norodom Yuvaneath]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2021 deaths, Cambodian people, Royalty, Disease-related deaths in California

Prince Norodom Yuvaneath (នរោត្តម យុវនាថ, October 17, 1943 – January 13, 2021) was a Cambodian royal. He was the first son of the late king of Cambodia, Norodom Sihanouk and Princess Sisowath Pongsanmoni. He is the half-brother of the current king, Norodom Sihamoni. Yuvaneath was born in Phnom Penh.

Yuvaneath died on January 13, 2021 in California, aged 77.

[[Wilbur Brotherton]]

CATEGORIES: 1922 births, 2021 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Chicago, Politicians from Michigan, US Republican Party politicians

Wilbur Vernon "Sandy" Brotherton (July 6, 1922 – January 15, 2021) was an American politician. He was a member of the Michigan House of Representatives from 1975 to 1988. Brotherton was born in Chicago, Illinois. He was a member of the Republican Party.

Brotherton died on January 15, 2021 in Farmington Hills, Michigan at the age of 98.

[[Farmington Hills, Michigan]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Michigan

Farmington Hills is a city in Oakland County in the U.S. state of Michigan. 79,740 people lived here at the 2010 census. It is a northern suburb of Metro Detroit and is the second most-populated city in Oakland County after the city of Troy.

[[Richard Wagner (judge)]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, Living people, Canadian lawyers, Politicians from Montreal, Chief Justices of Canada

Richard Wagner CAN (vɑɡnɛːʁ vahg; born April 2, 1957) is a Canadian politician and lawyer. He is the 18th and current Chief Justice of Canada since 2017. 

On January 21, 2021, Wagner became Administrator of Canada after the resignation of Julie Payette as Governor General of Canada. He left office when Mary Simon became governor general.

[[Chief Justice of Canada]]

CATEGORIES: Chief Justices of Canada

The Chief Justice of Canada (Juge en Chef du Canada) is the presiding judge of the nine-member Supreme Court of Canada, the highest judicial body in Canada.

[[Beverley McLachlin]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, Living people, Chief Justices of Canada, Politicians from Alberta

Beverley Marian McLachlin CAN CStJ (born September 7, 1943) is a Canadian jurist and author. She was the 17th chief justice of Canada from 2000 to 2017. She was the first woman to hold that position and the longest-serving chief justice in Canadian history.

[[Supreme Court of Canada]]

CATEGORIES: 1870s establishments in Canada, 1875 establishments in North America, National supreme courts, Government of Canada, Buildings and structures in Ottawa

The Supreme Court of Canada (SCC; Cour suprême du Canada, CSC) is the highest court of Canada, the final court of appeals in the Canadian justice system.

[[Sylvirana]]

CATEGORIES: Frogs, Animals of Asia

Sylvirana is a genus of frogs in the family Ranidae.  They live in South and East Asia, from northeastern India in the west to China in the north, Taiwan in the east, and Thailand in the south. Sylvirana was proposed in 1992.  At first, in scientists thought Sylvirana should be a subgenus of Rana. Since then, it has been considered both a genus of its own and a synonym of Hylarana. Scientists think it should be its own genus because of molecular genetic analyses published in 2015.

[[Sabail F.K.]]

CATEGORIES: 21st century establishments in Azerbaijan, 2016 establishments in Asia, Football clubs, Sport in Azerbaijan, Baku

Sabail FK (Səbail Futbol Klubu) is an Azerbaijani football club based in Baku. The club participates in the Azerbaijan Premier League.

[[Azad Hind]]

CATEGORIES: History of India

Atad Hind was the name of an Indian government, which was established in Singapore, in 1943. Its English name is usually Provisional Government of Free India. It was very dependent on its ally, the Empire of Japan. They fought the Burma campaign together. After the Second World War, Azad Hind stopped existing.

[[Eternal return]]

CATEGORIES: Philosophy, Religion

Eternal return is an idea that everything will repeat forever. It is also called Eternal recurrence. Eternal return can be found in different religions or philosophies.

[[Prick Up Your Ears (Family Guy)]]

CATEGORIES: Family Guy (season 5) episodes, 2006 television episodes

"Prick Up Your Ears" is the 6th episode of the 5th season of Family Guy. It was first shown on the Fox network on November 19, 2006. The episode is about Lois Griffin being a teacher for sex education. She gets fired because she teaches her students about safe sex.

The episode was written by Cherry Chevapravatdumrong. James Purdum is the director of the episode. 

[[Louis Fieser]]

CATEGORIES: Chemists

Louis Fieser was the lead scientist of a team of Harvard chemists that developed napalm in the 1940s.

Below is a list of television series based off of Marvel Comics.

[[Acadia]]

CATEGORIES: History of Canada, History of the United States

Acadia is the name of a territory in northeastern North America. Today, the area is mostly part of Canada. At the time, England and France fought over the territory. France said it had a legitimate claim, because Giovanni da Verrazzano and Jacques Cartier had done expeditions in the area. The British claim was founded on an expedition of Giovanni Caboto. The borders of the territory had never been defined clearly. Fights about where these borders were, were common. Historically, Acadia covered the territories of  Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, Prince Edward Island and the southern part of the Gaspé Peninsula, in Quebec. The northeastern part of Maine was also part of Acadia.

[[Terrace (agriculture)]]

CATEGORIES: Agriculture

Terraces are small plots on water used for farming, closely relating to the New World.  People dig into a hillside or other sloping surface and build it up so it is level in places, like steps.  Terraces can be in rectangles or they can follow the natural shape of the land.  Terracing prevents the rain from washing the soil away.

[[New Police Story]]

CATEGORIES: 2004 movies, 2000s action movies, Hong Kong movies, Chinese movies

New Police Story (新警察故事) is a 2004 Hong Kong action movie produced and directed by Benny Chan, starting Jackie Chan (who also produced it). The movie was released in the Hong Kong on 24 September 2004. The movie is a reboot of the Police Story movie series and is the fifth movie. It stars Nicholas Tse, Charlie Yeung, Charlene Choi, Daniel Wu, and Ken Lo. At box office, this film did business of HK$21 million.

[[The Yearling]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 movies, 1940s drama movies, American drama movies, Movies based on books, MGM movies, Movies directed by Clarence Brown

The Yearling is a 1946 American drama movie directed by Clarence Brown and was based on the 1938 novel of the same name by Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings. It stars Gregory Peck, Jane Wyman, Claude Jarman Jr., Chill Wills, Forrest Tucker, Henry Travers, Clem Beavans, Margaret Wycherly and was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer. It was nominated for 7 Oscars and won 2 Academy Awards.

[[The Vagabond King (1956 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 movies, 1950s musical movies, American musical movies, Movies directed by Michael Curtiz

The Vagabond King is a 1956 American musical movie directed by Michael Curtiz and was based on the 1925 musical of the same name by Rudolf Friml. It stars Kathryn Grayson, Oreste Kirkop, Rita Moreno, Leslie Nielsen, Jack Lord, Vincent Prince and was distributed by Paramount Pictures.

[[Disappointment]]

CATEGORIES: Emotions

Disappointment is an emotion that a person feels when something has gone wrong. It is usually related to failure. Failures tend to cause disappointment.

[[Fortress chess]]

CATEGORIES: Chess variants, Chess

Fortress chess (also called Russian Four-Handed chess) is a chess variant (a kind of chess with different rules) for four players. The board has 192 squares on it.

There are four "fortresses" (the extra parts of the board) in each corner. The fortresses have 16 squares each. A rook, a knight, and a bishop are inside each fortress.

There is no evidence that this chess variant was ever generally played, or even that it was playable. Compare, for example, with the manuscript sources for the old Indo/Arabic version of chess.

[[California's 23rd congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Congressional districts of California

California's 23rd congressional district is a congressional district in the U.S. state of California. It made up of Kern County and parts of Los Angeles and Tulare counties. The cities in the district are Porterville, Ridgecrest, most of Bakersfield, and part of Lancaster.

House Minority Leader, Kevin McCarthy is the current representative for the district. Kevin McCarthy has been the representative since 2013. The 13th district was first created in 1943. The district is the most Republican district in California.

[[Lou Correa]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, Living people, United States representatives from California, US Democratic Party politicians

Lou Correa (born January 24, 1958) is a United States representative for California's 46th congressional district. He is a member of the Democratic Party and was first elected to the United States House of Representatives in 2016. Lou Correa was a state senator and in the California State Assembly before this.

[[Akongjamba]]

CATEGORIES: Meitei folklore, Meitei literature, Meitei mythology

Akongjamba  (Akongchampa) is one of the principal characters in ancient Moirang Kangleirol legend. He is a nobleman of the king of Ancient Moirang. He is a lover of goddess Phouoibi, and a mortal being belonging to the Thoidingjam. However, fate doesn't permit the lovers to unite, which induces both to take rebirth for the unfulfilled love.

[[Khuman Khamba]]

CATEGORIES: Meitei folklore, Meitei literature, Meitei mythology

Khuman Khamba (Khuman Khampa) or Moirang Khamba (Moilang Khampa) is one of the principal figures in the ancient Moirang Kangleirol legends. He is an orphan prince of the Khuman dynasty, brought up by his sister, Khamnu as a poor man. Later, he was married to his lady love Thoibi, the princess of the Moirang dynasty.

The term "Khamba" means ultimate or fullness.

[[Moirang Thoibi]]

CATEGORIES: Meitei folklore, Meitei literature, Meitei mythology

Moirang Thoibi (Moilang Thoipi) or Ewanglon Thoibi (Ewanglon Thoipi) is one of the principal characters in the ancient Moirang Kangleirol legends. She is a princess of the Moirang kingdom, daughter of Chingkhuba and the niece of the king of Moirang. She is a lady love of Khuman Khamba, a poor orphan prince.

The term "Thoibi" means perfection or completion of beauty and accomplishments.

[[Mexicanal]]

CATEGORIES: Television

Mexicanal cable system DirecTV added on August 23, 2005 of launch in January 2014 late AT&T U-verse removed on May 15, 2016 On April 2, 2018 Mexicanal added on Dish Network

[[Khamnu]]

CATEGORIES: Meitei folklore, Meitei literature, Meitei mythology

Khamnu is the daughter of Khuman Puremba, the prime minister of Ancient Moirang. Biologically, she is a daughter of Ngangkha Leima and King Chingkhuba of Ancient Moirang. She is a sister of Khuman Khamba, whom she brought him up, since childhood, after the demise of their parents.

[[Donna Britt]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2021 deaths, American journalists, American television personalities, Writers from Louisiana, People from Baton Rouge, Louisiana, People from Biloxi, Mississippi, Deaths from motor neurone disease

Donna Britt (July 10, 1958 – January 21, 2021) was a longtime television news anchor at WAFB in Baton Rouge. She co-anchored the station's top rated 6 PM and 10 PM news broadcasts.

As a student, she had been working for WYNK radio, and so in 1981 she decided to get a temporary job with WAFB, the local CBS affiliate. She quickly moved from weekend reporter to full-time reporter to host of morning news shows to prime time, where she anchored 9 News.

Britt was diagnosed with amyotrophic lateral sclerosis in 2017, and retired the following year. She died at her home on January 21, 2021, at age 62.

[[Nongban]]

CATEGORIES: Meitei folklore, Meitei literature, Meitei mythology

Angom Nongban Kongyamba, better known as Nongban, is a popular villain character who is depicted as the man who always tried many unsuccessful attempts to eliminate Khuman Khamba in the ancient Moirang Kangleirol legends. He is a rich man of Angom clan. Besides having seven wives, he is a suitor of princess Moirang Thoibi, for which, he has a rivalry with Khuman Khamba.

[[Quagga mussel]]

CATEGORIES: Bivalves

The Quagga mussel is a freshwater mussel. Originally it occurred in the drainage basin of the Dnieper river, mostly in Ukraine. The mussel is named after the Quagga, an extinct species of zebra. The mussels live for three to five years. Since about the 1940s, they have spread a lot outside their original range. They are considered an invasive species in most of Europe, and North America. It looks like certain species of perch have developped an appetite for thes mussels. They are now considered as a natural form of pest control.

[[Safra Catz]]

CATEGORIES: 1961 births, Living people, Israeli businesspeople, American billionaires, Naturalized citizens of the United States

Safra A. Catz (Hebrew: צפרא כץ, born December 1, 1961) is an Israeli-American billionaire banker and technology executive. She is the CEO of Oracle Corporation.

In April 2011, she was named co-president and chief financial officer (CFO).

[[Onsi Sawiris]]

CATEGORIES: 2021 deaths, 1930 births, Egyptian businesspeople

Onsi Sawiris (also written Sawires, ⲁⲛⲥⲓ ⲥⲉⲩⲏⲣⲟⲥ, أنسي ساويرس; August 14, 1930 – June 29, 2021) was an Egyptian businessman. His net worth is $1.2 billion according to Forbes in 2017. He was the head of the Sawiris family. He founded the Orascom conglomerate.

[[Dina Powell]]

CATEGORIES: 1973 births, Living people, American philanthropists, American diplomats, Businesspeople from New York City, Politicians from New York City, People from Cairo, US Republican Party politicians, Women diplomats

Dina Powell McCormick (Dina Habib Ⲇⲓⲛⲁ Ϩⲁⲃⲓⲃ, دينا حبيب; born June 12, 1973) is an American financial executive, philanthropist and political advisor. She is best known for having been the United States Deputy National Security Advisor for Strategy to President Donald Trump.

[[Jessica Jackley]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, Living people, Businesspeople from Pennsylvania

Jessica Erin Jackley (born October 29, 1977) is an American businesswoman. She is known for having co-founded Kiva and later ProFounder, two organizations that help the creation of businesses through microloans.

[[Franklin Park, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: Boroughs in Pennsylvania

Franklin Park is a borough in Allegheny County, Pennsylvania, United States. 13,470 people lived here at the 2010 census.

[[The Dark Mirror (1946 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 movies, 1940s crime movies, 1940s thriller movies, American crime thriller movies, Movies directed by Robert Siodmak

The Dark Mirror is a 1946 American crime thriller movie directed by Robert Siodmak and starring Olivia de Havilland, Lew Ayers, Thomas Mitchell, Garry Owen, Lela Bliss, Lester Allen. It was distributed by Universal Pictures and was nominated for an Academy Award in 1947.

[[Kadeng Thangjahanba]]

CATEGORIES: Legends, Meitei mythology

"Kadeng Thangjahanba" (ꯀꯗꯦꯡ ꯊꯥꯡꯖꯍꯟꯕ) is one of the principal characters in the ancient Moirang Kangleirol legends. He is a blacksmith and a minster in the court of the king of Moirang kingdom. He is a lover of Tonu Laijinglembi.

According to legend, he has no match as a skilled blacksmith.

Many scholars opined Kadeng Thangjahanba to be a real historical figure who existed during the reign of Emperor Iwang Puriklai Laijing Punsiba in Ancient Moirang.

[[Montmorin, Hautes-Alpes]]

CATEGORIES: Former communes in Hautes-Alpes

Montmorin was a commune in the Hautes-Alpes department. On 1 July 2017, it merged with Bruis and Sainte-Marie and is now part of the Valdoule commune.

[[Montmaur, Hautes-Alpes]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Hautes-Alpes

Montmaur is a commune in the Hautes-Alpes department.

[[Montjay, Hautes-Alpes]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Hautes-Alpes

Montjay is a commune in the Hautes-Alpes department.

[[LauncherOne]]

CATEGORIES: Rockets

LauncherOne is a two-stage orbital launch vehicle developed and flown by Virgin Orbit. It was in development from 2007 to 2020. It is an air-launched rocket. It carries a smallsat payloads of up to 300 into Sun-synchronous orbit (SSO).

The first successful flight was on 17 January 2021. LauncherOne was the first all liquid-fuelled air-launched orbital rocket.  A test flight was unsuccessful on 25 May 2020, when the rocket failed to reach space. 

[[Air-launch-to-orbit]]

CATEGORIES: Rockets

Air launch to orbit is the method of launching rockets. An airplane carries the rocket which would then be launched to carry satellites to low Earth orbit.

[[Montbrand]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Hautes-Alpes

Montbrand is a commune in the Hautes-Alpes department.

[[Tonu Laijinglembi]]

CATEGORIES: Legends, Fiction, Meitei mythology

"Tonu Laijinglembi" (ꯇꯣꯅꯨ ꯂꯥꯢꯖꯤꯡꯂꯦꯝꯕꯤ) is one of the principal characters in the ancient Moirang Kangleirol legends. She is a lady love of Kadeng Thangjahanba, with whom she united after her former marriage to the king of Moirang kingdom.

But some opined Tonu Laijinglembi to be a historical figure who appeared during the reign of Emperor Iwang Puriklai Laijing Punsiba in Ancient Moirang.

[[Montclus, Hautes-Alpes]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Hautes-Alpes

Montclus is a commune in the Hautes-Alpes department.

[[Lettret]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Hautes-Alpes

Lettret is a commune in the Hautes-Alpes department.

[[Mitchell Johnson]]

CATEGORIES: 1981 births, Living people, Australian cricketers, Sportspeople from Queensland

Mitchell Guy Johnson (born 2 November 1981) is an Australian former cricketer. He was a left-handed batsman and a left-handed fast bowler. He has been awarded the International Cricket Council's Sir Garfield Sobers Trophy twice (2009 and 2014). He famously took part in the Australian Test squad during the 2013–14 Ashes series. His country won the series 5–0. Johnson also won the player of the series award for taking 37 wickets in a dominant showing against the English batsmen. During his Test career, he played 73 matches and took 313 wickets from 16,001 balls bowled. He retired from all forms of cricket in 2018.

Johnson was born in Townsville, Queensland. Although he bats and bowls left-handed, Johnson writes with his right hand. In 2016, he published his autobiography Resilient.

[[Gregory Sierra]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2021 deaths, Cancer deaths in California, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, Actors from New York City

Gregory Sierra (January 25, 1937 – January 4, 2021)  was an American actor. He was known for his roles as Detective Sergeant Chano Amenguale on Barney Miller and as Julio Fuentes on Sanford and Son.

Sierra died on January 4, 2021 from cancer at his home in Laguna Woods, California at the age of 83.

[[Laguna Woods, California]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in California, Settlements in Orange County, California

Laguna Woods (l) is a city in Orange County, California, United States. 16,192 people lived here at the 2010 census.

[[Jeannette Wood]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2021 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Washington, Politicians from New York, US Republican Party politicians

Jeannette Wood (February 19, 1932 – January 9, 2021) was an American Republican politician. He was a member of the Washington House of Representatives from the 21st district from 1988 to 1994 and in the Washington State Senate from the 21st district from 1994 to 1999. Wood was born in Auburn, New York.

Wood died of problems caused by dementia on January 9, 2021, in Woodway, Washington at age 88.

[[Woodway, Washington]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Washington (U.S. state)

Woodway is a city in Snohomish County, Washington, United States. 1,307 people lived here at the 2010 census.

[[Charlotte Cornwell]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, 2021 deaths, English movie actors, English stage actors, English television actors, Actors from London

Charlotte Cornwell (26 April 1949 – 16 January 2021) was an English actress. She was born in London. Cornwell was a leading member of the Royal Shakespeare Company for three years. She starred Rosalind in As You Like It and Beatrice in Much Ado About Nothing. 

Cornwell was in many movies such as Stardust (1974), The Brute (1977), The Krays (1990), The Russia House (1990), White Hunter Black Heart (1990), The Saint (1997), Ghosts of Mars (2001) and Dead Space: Aftermath (2010).

Cornwell died on 16 January 2021, aged 71.

[[Royal Shakespeare Company]]

CATEGORIES: 1879 establishments in England, Theatres in the United Kingdom, Companies of the United Kingdom

The Royal Shakespeare Company (RSC) is a major British theatre company. It is in Stratford-upon-Avon, Warwickshire, England. The company has over 1,000 staff and makes around 20 productions a year. Most of the plays made by the company are by William Shakespeare.

[[Maynard Wallace]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2021 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Missouri, US Republican Party politicians

Maynard Wallace (April 21, 1943 – January 17, 2021) was an American Republican politician. He was a member of the Missouri House of Representatives from the 143rd district from 2003 to 2011. He was born in Ozark County, Missouri.

Wallace died on January 17, 2021 at her home near Gainesville, Missouri at age 77.

[[Gainesville, Missouri]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Missouri, County seats in Missouri

Gainesville is a city in Ozark County, Missouri, United States. 773 people lived here at the 2010 census. It is the county seat of Ozark County.

[[Thorsten Johansson]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2021 deaths

Thorsten Johansson (9 October 1950 – 18 January 2021) was a Swedish sprinter. He competed in the men's 200 metres at the 1976 Summer Olympics.

Johansson died on 18 January 2021, aged 70.

[[Jim Vickerman]]

CATEGORIES: 1931 births, 2021 deaths, State legislators of the United States, Politicians from Minnesota, US Democratic Party politicians

James Murray Vickerman (May 1, 1931 – January 19, 2021) was an American politician. He was a member of the Minnesota Senate from 1987 to 2011. He was a member of the Minnesota Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party. He was born in Tracy, Minnesota.

Vickerman died on January 19, 2021 in Marshall, Minnesota at the age of 89.

[[Tracy, Minnesota]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Minnesota

Tracy is a city in Lyon County, Minnesota, United States. 2,163 people lived here at the 2010 census.

[[Bill Sheat]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2021 deaths, New Zealand people, New Zealand lawyers, Activists

William Newton Sheat NZL (1 May 1930 – 20 January 2021) was a New Zealand lawyer and arts activist. He was a founding member of the New Zealand Film Commission, Creative New Zealand and Downstage Theatre. Sheat was born in Hāwera, New Zealand.

Sheat died on 20 January 2021 in Lower Hutt, New Zealand at the age of 90.

[[Central American Integration System]]

CATEGORIES: Political organizations, Central America

The Central American Integration System (Sistema de la Integración Centroamericana, or SICA) has been the economic and political organization of Central American states since February 1, 1993.

In 1991, SICA's first nations to join were Guatemala, El Salvador, Honduras, Nicaragua, Costa Rica and Panama. Belize joined in 1998 as a full member, while the Dominican Republic became an associated state in 2004 and a full member in 2013. 

Mexico, Chile and Brazil became part of the organization as regional observers, and the Republic of China, Spain, Germany and Japan became extra-regional observers. 

SICA has been an observer of the United Nations General Assembly. 

[[California's 46th congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Congressional districts of California

California's 46th congressional district is a congressional district in the U.S. state of California. A representative is elected every two years to represent the district in the United States House of Representatives. The district is currently represented by Democrat Lou Correa. The district is in Orange County and includes the cities of Anaheim and Santa Ana, as well as parts of Orange. It is both the most liberal and most Latino congressional district in Orange County. The district was first created in 1993 and was represented by a Republican.

[[Mauricio Herdocia Sacasa]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, Nicaraguan politicians, Lawyers, Editors

Mauricio Herdocia Sacasa (1 August 1958 – 21 January 2021) was a Nicaraguan politician, lawyer and editor. He was born in León, Nicaragua. Herdocia Sacasa was a Nicaraguan representative for the International Court of Justice. He worked for the newspaper La Prensa. 

In 2000, for a short time, Herdocia Sacasa was General-Secretary of the Central American Integration System.

Herdocia Sacasa died of a heart attack on 21 January 2021 in Managua, Nicaragua at the age of 62.

[[Amanda Gorman]]

CATEGORIES: 1988 births, Living people, African American writers, American poets, American political activists, Writers from Los Angeles, California

Amanda S. C. Gorman (born March 7, 1998) is an American poet, writer, speaker, and political activist. She read one of her poems during the installment ceremony of the American President Joe Biden in January 2021, getting praise.

[[León, Nicaragua]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Nicaragua

León (leˈon) is the second largest city in Nicaragua, after Managua. It is the capital and largest city of León Department.

[[Cecilia Mangini]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, 2021 deaths, Italian movie directors, Italian screenwriters

Cecilia Mangini (31 July 1927 – 21 January 2021) was an Italian movie director and screenwriter. She was thought to be the first female documentary filmmaker in Italy. Mangini wrote the screenplay for the 1973 drama movie Black Holiday. She was born in Mola di Bari, Italy.

Mangini died on 21 January 2021 in Rome at the age of 93.

[[Mola di Bari]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Apulia

Mola di Bari, commonly referred to simply as Mola (Barese: Màule), is a town and comune of the Metropolitan City of Bari, in the region of Apulia, in Southern Italy, on the Adriatic Sea.

[[Tony Ferrer]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2021 deaths, Filipino actors, Movie directors, Movie producers, Deaths from cardiovascular disease

Antonio Laxa (June 12, 1934 – January 23, 2021) better known by his stage name Tony Ferrer, was a Filipino actor, movie director and producer. He was called the James Bond of the Philippines for his movie role as Tony Falcon in the Agent X-44 spy movie series. Ferrer was born in Macabebe, Pampanga. He also played Inspector Ramos in The Vengeance of Fu Manchu and Ben Guevara in Blind Rage.

Ferrer died on January 23, 2021 in Quezon City from heart disease, aged 86.

[[Pampanga]]

CATEGORIES: Provinces of the Philippines

Pampanga (Lalawigan ning Pampanga; Lalawigan ng Pampanga) is a province in the Central Luzon region of the Philippines.

[[Ricardo Durão]]

CATEGORIES: 1928 births, 2021 deaths, Portuguese sportspeople, Olympians

Ricardo Fernandes Durão (13 June 1928 – 22 January 2021) was a Portuguese modern pentathlete. He competed at the 1952 Summer Olympics.

Durão died on 22 January 2021, aged 92.

[[Feliks Gromov]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, 2021 deaths, Russian military people

Fleet Admiral Feliks Nikolayevich Gromov (Феликс Николаевич Громов; August 29, 1937 – January 22, 2021) was a Russian admiral. He was the Commander-in-Chief of the Russian Navy from 1992 to 1997. Gromov was born in Vladivostok, Soviet Union.

Gromov died on January 22, 2021 at the age of 83.

[[Juan Guzmán Tapia]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2021 deaths, Salvadoran politicians, Chilean politicians, Chilean lawyers, Judges

Juan Salvador Guzmán Tapia (22 April 1939 – 22 January 2021) was a Salvadoran-born Chilean politician and lawyer. He was the first Chilean judge to prosecute Augusto Pinochet over human rights violations during his dictatorship. Guzmán Tapia was born in San Salvador, El Salvador.

Guzmán Tapia died on 22 January 2021 in Santiago de Chile, aged 81.

[[Gianfranco Lombardi]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2021 deaths, Italian Olympians, Basketball players, People from Livorno, Sportspeople from Tuscany

Gianfranco "Franco" Lombardi (20 March 1941 – 22 January 2021) was an Italian professional basketball player and coach. During his playing career, his nickname was "Dado". He was born in Livorno, Italy. He played for the national team. He participated in the 1960, 1964 and 1968 Summer Olympics.

In 2006, he was honored into the Italian Basketball Hall of Fame.

Lombardi died on 22 January 2021 in Cocquio-Trevisago, Varese, Italy at the age of 79.

[[Cocquio-Trevisago]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Lombardy

Cocquio-Trevisago (ˈkɔkkwjo treviˈzaːɡo; Coeuch-Trevisagh ˈkøːk treʋiˈzɑːk) is a comune (municipality) in the Province of Varese in the Italian region of Lombardy. It is about 60 northwest of Milan and about 12 northwest of Varese.

[[F. X. Sudjasmin]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 births, 2021 deaths, Indonesian people, Military people

Fransiskus Xaverius Sudjasmin (26 August 1943spnd22 January 2021) was an Indonesian military officer. He was the deputy chief of staff of the Indonesian Army from 1995 until 1997. Sudjasmin was born in Salatiga, Japanese Dutch East Indies. 

Sudjasmin died on 22 January 2021 in Jakarta at the age of 77.

[[Marius van Heerden]]

CATEGORIES: 1974 births, 2021 deaths, South African sportspeople, Olympians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in South Africa

Marius van Heerden (8 September 1974 – 22 January 2021) was a South African middle-distance runner. He competed in the men's 800 metres at the 1996 Summer Olympics. He was born in Clanwilliam, South Africa.

Van Heerden died on 22 January 2021 in Cape Town from COVID-19, aged 46.

[[Farah Pahlavi]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, Living people

Farah Pahlavi (فرح پهلوی, née Farah Diba فرح دیبا; born 14 October 1938) is an Iranian royal. She is the widow of Mohammad Reza Pahlavi. Pahlavi was the Shahbanu (empress) of Iran from 1961 to 1979. Pahlavi was born in Tehran.

[[Fawzia Fuad of Egypt]]

CATEGORIES: 1921 births, 2013 deaths, Princes and princesses, Egyptian people

Fawzia Fuad of Egypt (الأميرة فوزية فؤاد; شاهدخت فوزیه فؤاد; 5 November 1921 – 2 July 2013), also known as Muluk Fawzia of Iran and Fawzia Chirine, was an Egyptian princess who became Queen of Iran as the first wife of Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, Shah of Iran.

Fawzia died on 2 July 2013 at the age of 91.

[[Soraya Esfandiary-Bakhtiary]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2001 deaths, Kings and Queens consort, Iranian actors

Soraya Esfandiary-Bakhtiary (Sorayâ Esfandiyâri-Baxtiyâri; 22 June 1932 – 26 October 2001) was the queen consort of Iran as the second wife of Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, whom she married in 1951.

Soraya died on 26 October 2001 in her apartment in Paris, France; she was 69.

[[Khuyol Haoba]]

CATEGORIES: Legends, Fiction, Meitei mythology

Khuyol Haoba (ꯈꯨꯌꯣꯜ ꯍꯥꯎꯕ) or Khuyon Haoba (ꯈꯨꯌꯣꯟ ꯍꯥꯎꯕ) is one of the principal characters in the ancient Moirang Kangleirol legends. He is the son of Khuyol Khuntoulempa, and a lover of Yaithing Konu, the fair daughter of Huiningsumba. Right from childhood, he grew up as an orphan man.

[[Shahnaz Pahlavi]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, Living people, Princes and princesses, People from Tehran

Shahnaz Pahlavi (شهناز پهلوی, born 27 October 1940) is the first child of the Shah of Iran, Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, and his first wife, Princess Fawzia Fuad of Egypt.

[[Reza Pahlavi, Crown Prince of Iran]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, Living people, Princes and princesses, People from Tehran

Reza Pahlavi (رضا پهلوی; born 31 October 1960) is the oldest son of Iranian Mohammad Reza Pahlavi and his wife Farah Diba. Until the Iranian Revolution in 1979, he was the crown prince and the last heir apparent to the throne of the Imperial State of Iran. 

[[Farahnaz Pahlavi]]

CATEGORIES: 1963 births, Living people, Princes and princesses, People from Tehran

Farahnaz Pahlavi (فرحناز پهلوی; born 12 March 1963) is the eldest daughter of Mohammad Reza Pahlavi by his third wife, Farah Diba.

In a 2004 article in Los Angeles Times, she tried to work at an international aid agencies such as UNICEF, but was rejected because of her name.

[[Pilgrimage (Wishbone Ash album)]]

CATEGORIES: 1971 albums, Hard rock albums

Pilgrimage is the second studio album by English rock band Wishbone Ash. The album is more like folk music than the last album, which was more like blues rock. The album sold many copies and reached number 14 on the UK Albums Chart. Their next album, Argus sold more than this album, and was their most popular.

[[Ali-Reza Pahlavi]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, 2011 deaths, Suicides by firearm in the United States, Princes and princesses, People from Tehran

Ali-Reza Pahlavi (علیرضا پهلوی; 28 April 1966 – 4 January 2011) was a member of the Pahlavi Imperial Family of the Imperial State of Iran. He was the younger son of Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, the former Shah of Iran and his third wife Farah Diba. 

He was second in order of succession to the Iranian throne before the Iranian Revolution.

Pahlavi, who had depression, shot himself on 4 January 2011 in Boston, Massachusetts at the age of 44.

[[Leila Pahlavi]]

CATEGORIES: 1970 births, 2001 deaths, Drug-related deaths in the United Kingdom, Drug-related suicides, Princes and princesses, People from Tehran

Leila Pahlavi (لیلا پهلوی, 27 March 1970 – 10 June 2001) was a princess of Iran and the youngest daughter of Mohammad Reza Pahlavi, Shah of Iran, and his third wife, Farah Pahlavi.

On 10 June 2001, Pahlavi was found dead in her room in Leonard Hotel in London by her doctor. She was found to have more than five times the lethal dose of barbiturate and cocaine. She was found in bed and she suffered from anorexia and bulimia. 

[[Hyman G. Rickover]]

CATEGORIES: 1900 births, 1986 deaths, Naturalized citizens of the United States, Polish military people, American military personnel of World War II, Presidential Medal of Freedom recipients, Congressional Gold Medal recipients

Hyman G. Rickover (January 27, 1900 – July 8, 1986) was an Admiral in the U.S. Navy. He helped create nuclear powered submarines. He was director of the U.S. Naval Reactors office. Rickover is also one of four people who have been awarded two Congressional Gold Medals.

[[Moirang Shayon]]

CATEGORIES: Meitei culture, Meitei folklore, Meitei literature, Meitei mythology, Manipur

The "Moirang Shayon" (ꯃꯣꯢꯔꯥꯡ ꯁꯥꯌꯣꯟ) or "Moirang Saiyon" (ꯃꯣꯢꯔꯥꯡ ꯁꯥꯢꯌꯣꯟ)(lit. Moirang incarnations) is a genre of the seven incarnations of a God and a Goddess, induced by Lord Thangjing, in the ancient Moirang kingdom, a southern province in Ancient Manipur (Antique Kangleipak).

The list of the seven pairs of incarnations are:
