[[Chabottes]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Hautes-Alpes

Chabottes is a commune in the Hautes-Alpes department.

[[Self-disorder]]

CATEGORIES: Psychology

A self-disorder is also called an ipseity disturbance. It is a bad change in the minimal self of the person. The minimal self is like a solid center that someone experiences reality with. It can be disturbed in schizophrenia and similar disorders. The self-disorder can show itself in different ways.

[[Champcella]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Hautes-Alpes

Champcella is a commune in the Hautes-Alpes department.

[[Sophie Nélisse]]

CATEGORIES: 2000 births, Canadian child actors, Canadian television actors, Canadian movie actors, Actors from Ontario, Living people

Sophie Nélisse (born March 27, 2000) is a Canadian actress. Her performance in Monsieur Lazhar won a Genie Award. She played Liesel Meminger in the movie adaptation of the best-selling novel The Book Thief. 

Nélisse won a Young Artist Award for Best Leading Young Actress in an International Feature Film. She was later at the Cannes Film Festival to present the movie Mean Dreams.

Nélisse was born in Windsor, Ontario.

[[Paul Tonko]]

CATEGORIES: 1949 births, United States representatives from New York, US Democratic Party politicians, People from Amsterdam, New York, Living people

Paul Tonko (born June 18, 1949) is a United States representative for New York's 20th congressional district. Tonko is a Democrat and has represented the district since 2009. When Tonko became a congressman, New York's 20th congressional district was part of New York's 21st congressional district and Tonko also represented that. But the districts were changed and he became the congressman for the 20th district. Tonko was also a member of the New York State Assembly before and was the Chief executive officer of New York State Energy Research and Development Authority.

[[Bea Miller]]

CATEGORIES: 1999 births, American singer-songwriters, American child singers, American child actors, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Singers from New Jersey, Actors from New Jersey, Living people

Beatrice Annika Miller (born February 7, 1999) is an American singer-songwriter and actress. She came in ninth place on season two of The X Factor (U.S.) when she was thirteen years old. Her first extended play Young Blood was released in 2014. Her first studio album Not an Apology was released on July 24, 2015. In 2016, she released the song "Yes Girl".

Miller released "It's Not You it's Me", "That Bitch", "Feel Something" and "Never Gonna Like You" in 2019. 

In October 2020, after the success of "Feel Something", Miller released the song "Wisdom Teeth" on her EP Elated.

Miller was born in Maplewood, New Jersey.

[[Chess symbols in Unicode]]

CATEGORIES: Chess, Symbols, Typography

Unicode has characters of chess symbols. This means that chess symbols can be encoded as text instead of images. Algebraic notation (text that shows where to move a chess piece) can be typed using the symbol of the piece. For example, ♘c6 instead of Nc6. 

[[Echizen Ono Castle]]

CATEGORIES: Castles in Japan, Fukui Prefecture, Buildings and structures in Fukui Prefecture

Echizen Ono Castle is a Japanese castle that is in Ono City, Fukui Prefecture. Until the Meiji period, the administrative headquarters of the Ono Domain region was established. In 2017, it was included in "Second series Top 100 Japanese Castle". The castle which appears every conditions are met in the morning, is called "castle in the sky (天空の城)".

In 1575, Nagachika Kanamori began to build a castle on Kameyama mountain, a small mountain in Ono County. It took several years to build the castle. After the Kazunori Aoki’s era, the Echizen Matsudaira family became a shogunal property, and the castle owner changed many times until the Doi family got it. The castle burned down in 1775 and was rebuilt in 1795 with the exception of the castle tower, but it was destroyed again after the Meiji Restoration. The castle tower today was built in the Shōwa period (1968). 

[[Marius Swart]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in South Africa, South African politicians, South African businesspeople

Marius Swart (1941spnd17 January 2021) was a South African politician and businessman. He was a member of the Democratic Alliance. He was Executive Mayor of the George Local Municipality from 2000 to 2004. He was a member of the National Assembly from 2004 to 2014. Swart was born in Swellendam, South Africa.

On 8 January 2021, Swart was hospitalized in George with COVID-19 in critical condition. He died from the virus on 17 January, aged 79.

[[Justin Lekhanya]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2021 deaths, Prime Ministers of Lesotho

General Justin Metsing Lekhanya (7 April 1938 – 20 January 2021) was a Lesotho politician. He was the Chairman of the Military Council of Lesotho from 24 January 1986 to 2 May 1991. He was born in Thaba-Tseka, Lesotho.

Lekhanya died on 20 January 2021, aged 82.

[[California grizzly bear]]

CATEGORIES: Ursidaes, Mammals of North America

The California grizzly bear (Ursus arctos californicus) is an extinct population or subspecies of the brown bear. 

The California grizzly bear was much like the Kodiak bear of the southern coast of Alaska. 

The grizzly became a symbol of the Bear Flag Republic.

[[Advance to the Rear]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 comedy movies, 1960s western movies, American western movies, American comedy movies, MGM movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by George Marshall

Advance to the Rear is a 1964 American western comedy movie directed by George Marshall and was based on the 1957 novel Company of Cowards by Jack Schaefer. It stars Glenn Ford, Stella Stevens, Melvyn Douglas, Jim Backus, Joan Blondell, Andrew Prine, Alan Hale Jr., Whit Bissell and was distributed by Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer.

[[Dienoycus]]

Dienoycus is a genus of dinosaur.  Dienocus is a dromaeosaurid theropod dinosaur.  There are one known species in this genus: Deinonychus antirrhopus.

[[Guem]]

CATEGORIES: Algerian people, 1947 births, 2021 deaths, Singers

Guem, stage name of Abdelmajid Guemguem (9 March 1947 – 22 January 2021) was an Algerian percussionist. He composed Le Serpent, re-recorded in 1996 for the program Ça se discute on France 2. In 2011, he composed Mon Paris.

Guem died on 22 January 2021 in Paris, aged 73.

[[Paul Foytack]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2021 deaths, Detroit Tigers players, Los Angeles Angels players, Sportspeople from Pennsylvania, People from Scranton, Pennsylvania

Paul Eugene Foytack (November 16, 1930 – January 23, 2021) was an American professional baseball player and right-handed pitcher. He appeared in 312 games in Major League Baseball between 1953 and 1964 for two American League clubs, the Detroit Tigers and the Los Angeles Angels. He was born in Scranton, Pennsylvania.

Foytack died on January 23, 2021 in Spring Hill, Tennessee at the age of 90.

[[Spring Hill, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Tennessee

Spring Hill is a city in Maury and Williamson counties, Tennessee. Spring Hill had 43,769 people lived here in 2019.

[[Brock, Ontario]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Ontario

Brock is a township in the Regional Municipality of Durham, Ontario, Canada.

[[Bruce Kirby (actor)]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, 2021 deaths, American movie actors, American television actors, American stage actors, American voice actors, Actors from New York City

Bruce Kirby (born Bruno Giovanni Quidaciolu; April 28, 1925 – January 24, 2021) was an American character actor.

During the 1960s, he appeared in I Dream of Jeannie, The Nurses, The Defenders, Car 54, Where Are You?, and The Patty Duke Show among others.

He was known for his role as Pop Ryan, father of Officer John Ryan (played by Matt Dillon) in the 2005 movie Crash.

His son was actor Bruno Kirby (1949–2006).

Kirby died at age 95 in Los Angeles on January 24, 2021.

[[Crash (2004 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 2004 drama movies, 2000s crime drama movies, Academy Award winning movies, Screen Actors Guild Award winners, Satellite Award winners, American crime drama movies

Crash is a 2004 American crime drama movie produced, directed, and co-written by Paul Haggis.

The movie stars Sandra Bullock, Don Cheadle, Matt Dillon, Jennifer Esposito, William Fichtner,  Brendan Fraser, Terrence Howard, Chris "Ludacris" Bridges, Thandie Newton, Michael Peña, and Ryan Phillippe.

It received six Academy Award nominations. It won three for Best Picture, Best Original Screenplay, and Best Film Editing.

[[Paul Haggis]]

CATEGORIES: 1953 births, Living people, Canadian movie directors, Canadian screenwriters, Canadian movie producers, Writers from Ontario, People from London, Ontario, Canadian television writers, Emmy Award winners, Academy Award winning writers, BAFTA Award winning writers, Satellite Award winners

Paul Edward Haggis (born March 10, 1953) is a Canadian screenwriter, movie producer, and movie director. He is best known as screenwriter and producer for the Best Picture Oscar winners: Million Dollar Baby (2004) and Crash (2005). He also directed the James Bond movies Casino Royale (2006) and Quantum of Solace (2008).

Haggis was sued for an alleged sexual assault claim in New York City in 2013.

[[Larne Borough Council]]

CATEGORIES: Settlements in Northern Ireland

Larne Borough Council was a Local Council in County Antrim in Northern Ireland. It merged with Ballymena Borough Council and Carrickfergus Borough Council in May 2015.

32,180 people lived here at the 2011 Northern Ireland census.

[[Marcel Uderzo]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in France, French artists, Comics artists

Marcel Uderzo (20 December 1933 – 24 January 2021) was a French comic book artist. He was the younger brother of fellow comic book artist Albert Uderzo. He made ink boards for Asterix. His last Asterix work was Asterix in Belgium.

Uderzo died on 24 January 2021 from COVID-19 in Évreux, France at the age of 87.

[[The Boy in Blue (1986 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 drama movies, 1980s biographical movies, Canadian drama movies, 20th Century Fox movies, Movies directed by Charles Jarrott

The Boy in Blue is a 1986 Canadian biographical drama movie directed by Charles Jarrott and starring Nicolas Cage, Cynthia Dale, Christopher Plummer, Sean Sullivan, David Naughton, Melody Anderson, Jeff Wincott. It was distributed by 20th Century Fox.

[[Sōichi Aikawa]]

CATEGORIES: 1942 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from respiratory failure, Japanese politicians, Mayors

Sōichi Aikawa was a Japanese politician. Aikawa was born in Urawa, Saitama. He was elected mayor of Urawa in 1991 until 2001. He was chosen as the first mayor of the city of Saitama. He retired in 2009.

Aikawa died of respiratory failure on 25 January 2021, aged 78.

[[David Bright (football manager)]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, 2021 deaths, Botswana people, Football managers, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic

David Bright (13 June 1956 – 25 January 2021) was a Botswanan football manager.

In 1992, Bright joined Mogoditshane Fighters in the Botswana First Division. He led the team to three Botswana Premier League titles between 1999 and 2001.

Bright has also managed Engen Santos, Bay United, Gaborone United and Bay United.

Bright died of COVID-19 during the COVID-19 pandemic in Botswana on 25 January 2021, aged 64.

[[COVID-19 pandemic in Botswana]]

CATEGORIES: Botswana, COVID-19 pandemic by country

This article documents the impacts of the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic in Botswana.

On 30 March, the first three cases in the country were confirmed. On 25 March a 78-year-old woman who was suspected of having COVID-19 died in Ramotswa. A few days after her death, the results came back positive making it the fourth case of COVID-19 in Botswana.

[[Jaoid Chiguer]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from myocardial infarction, French Olympians, Boxers

Jaoid Chiguer, by some sources spelled Jaouad (11 August 1985 – 25 January 2021), was a French amateur boxer. He qualified for the 2008 Olympics at welterweight.

Chiguer died on 25 January 2021, at the age of 35 from heart attack.

[[Avelino Méndez Rangel]]

CATEGORIES: 1958 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Mexico, Politicians from Mexico City

Avelino Méndez Rangel (26 November 1958 – 25 January 2021) was a Mexican politician. He was a member of the Party of the Democratic Revolution. From 2009 to 2012, he was a federal deputy representing the Federal District. He also was borough mayor in Xochimilco.

Méndez Rangel died in Mexico City on 25 January 2021 after being hospitalized with COVID-19 days earlier, during the COVID-19 pandemic in Mexico, aged 62.

[[Vladimír Suchánek]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2021 deaths, Czech artists

Vladimir Suchánek (12 February 1933 – 25 January 2021) was a Czech graphic artist and postage stamp designer. He was born in Nové Město nad Metují, Czechoslovakia. He was President of the Hollar Society, the leading Czech graphic art organisation. He was the designer of several stamps for the Czech Republic.

Suchánek died in Prague on 25 January 2021, aged 87.

[[Maryan Synakowski]]

CATEGORIES: 1936 births, 2021 deaths, French footballers

Maryan Synakowski (14 March 1936 – 25 January 2021) was a French footballer. He played as a centre back. 

Synakowski played for Olympique Saint-Quentin, Sedan-Torcy B, Sedan-Torcy, Stade Français, Union Saint-Gilloise, Reims and Sedan.

He played for the French national team between 1961 and 1965.

[[Enrique Tábara]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2021 deaths, People from Guayaquil, Painters, Educators

Luis Enrique Tábara (21 February 1930 – 25 January 2021) was an Ecuadorian painter and teacher. He was born in Guayaquil, Ecuador. He was inspired by the Constructivist Movement. He also painted many works with Joaquín Torres García and Manuel Rendón. 

Tábara died on 25 January 2021 in Guayaquil, aged 90.

[[Winfried Bölke]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2021 deaths, German cyclists

Winfried Bölke (25 May 1941 – 26 January 2021) was a German cyclist. In 1963 he won the national championships and a bronze medal at the world championships in the road race for amateurs. He continued competing professionally until 1973.

[[Francis Bazire]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, Living people, French cyclists, French Olympians

Francis Augustin Bazire (born 17 April 1939) is a retired French cyclist. He won a silver medal in the amateur road race at the 1963 UCI Road World Championships. He competed at the 1964 Summer Olympics and finished in 53rd place in the same event.

[[Carlos Holmes Trujillo]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Colombia, Ambassadors of Colombia, Mayors, Colombian politicians

Carlos Holmes Trujillo García (23 September 1951 – 26 January 2021) was a Colombian lawyer and politician. He was born in Cartago, Colombia. Trujillo was Mayor of Cali from 1988 to 1990. He was a member of the Democratic Center.

From 1992 to 1993, he was Minister of Education. From 1997 to 1998, he was Minister of the Interior. From 2018 to 2019, Trujillo was Minister of Foreign Affairs. From 2019 until his death, he was Minister of Defense.

Trujillo died on 26 January 2021 at a hospital in Bogota from COVID-19, aged 69.

[[Peter Vere-Jones]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2021 deaths, New Zealand movie actors, New Zealand television actors, New Zealand stage actors, Actors from Cheshire

Peter Vere-Jones NZL (21 October 1939 – January 2021) was a New Zealand actor. He was known for his works with director Peter Jackson. He appeared in four of his movies. He was also known for starring in the New Zealand television series Shortland Street.

In the 2002 Queen's Birthday and Golden Jubilee Honours, Vere-Jones was appointed an Officer of the New Zealand Order of Merit.

Vere-Jones died in January 2021, aged 82.

[[Ron Johnson (baseball)]]

CATEGORIES: 1956 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, Kansas City Royals players, Montreal Expos players, Sportspeople from California, People from Long Beach, California

Ronald David Johnson (September 12, 1956 – January 26, 2021) was an American baseball player and minor league manager. He played for the Kansas City Royals from 1982 to 1983 and Montreal Expos in 1984. He coached the Boston Red Sox from 2010 to 2011. Johnson was born in Long Beach, California.

Johnson died on January 26, 2021 in Morrison, Tennessee from COVID-19, aged 64.

[[Sergei Eduardovich Prikhodko]]

CATEGORIES: 1957 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from motor neurone disease, Russian politicians

Sergei Eduardovich Prikhodko (Сергей Эдуардович Приходько; 12 January 1957 – 26 January 2021) was a Russian politician. From May 2013 to May 2018, he was Deputy Prime Minister in Dmitry Medvedev's Cabinet. He was the First Deputy Head of the Russian Government Office from 2018 to 2021.

Prikhodko died on 26 January 2021 at the age of 64 from amyotrophic lateral sclerosis in Moscow.

[[Lars Norén]]

CATEGORIES: 1944 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Sweden, Swedish playwrights, Swedish novelists, Swedish poets, Writers from Stockholm

Lars Göran Ingemar Norén (9 May 1944 – 26 January 2021) was a Swedish playwright, novelist and poet. His plays are realistic. He was born in Stockholm, Sweden. Norén was director at Folkteatern in Gothenburg between 2009 and 2011.

Norén died on 26 January 2021, at the age of 76 from COVID-19 during the COVID-19 pandemic in Sweden.

[[John Mortimore (footballer)]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2021 deaths, English footballers, English football managers, Sportspeople from Hampshire

John Mortimore (23 September 1934 – 26 January 2021) was an English football player and manager.

Mortimore played as a centre half in the Football League for Chelsea. He scored 10 goals from 279 games in all competitions between 1956 and 1965 and won the 1965 Football League Cup. He also played for Queens Park Rangers.

Mortimore died on 26 January 2021, aged 86.

[[Luc Julian Matthys]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2021 deaths, People from Ghent, Australian Roman Catholics, Roman Catholic bishops

Luc Julian Matthys (3 May 1935 – 26 January 2021) was a Belgian-born Australian Roman Catholic bishop. Matthys was born in Drongen, Ghent, Belgium. 

He became a priest in 1961 for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Johannesburg, South Africa. He was a priest for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Melbourne, Australia, in 1976.  

He was bishop of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Armidale, Australia from 1999 to 2011.

Matthys died on 26 January 2021, aged 85.

[[Hana Maciuchová]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 1993 deaths, Czech movie actors, Czech television actors, Czech stage actors

Hana Maciuchová (29 November 1945 – 26 January 2021) was a Czech actress. She was born in Šternberk, Czechoslovakia.

Maciuchová was known for her roles in Chalupáři (1975), Prázdniny pro psa (1980), Krkonošské pohádky (1984), In the Coat of Lioness' Arms (1994), Loners (2000), Ulice (2005–2015) and Dobrá čtvrť (2008).

Maciuchová died on 26 January 2021 in Olomouc, Czech Republic at the age of 75.

[[Billy Kenoi]]

CATEGORIES: 1968 births, 2021 deaths, American mayors, Politicians from Hawaii, US Democratic Party politicians, Deaths from myelofibrosis, Cancer deaths in the United States

William P. Kenoi (November 1968 – January 26, 2021) was an American Democratic politician. Kenoi was Mayor of Hawaii County from 2008 to 2016. He was a legislative aide in the State House and State Senate. He was born in Kalapana, Hawaii.

In 2015, Kenoi was diagnosed with myelofibrosis. He died from the disease on January 26, 2021 in Honolulu at the age of 52.

[[Aminuddin Ponulele]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2021 deaths, People from Palu, Governors of Central Sulawesi, Indonesian politicians

Aminuddin Ponulele (5 July 1939 – 27 January 2021) was an Indonesian academic and politician who served as Governor of Central Sulawesi from 2001 to 2006. He also served as the speaker of the Central Sulawesi Provincial House of Representatives from 2009 to 2019. He also ran as a candidate for governor in the Central Sulawesi Provincial General Election in 2011.

Aminuddin died on 27 January 2021 at the age of 81.

[[Palu]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Indonesia

Palu is a chartered city on the Indonesian island of Sulawesi, at the mouth of the Palu River. It is the capital of the province of Central Sulawesi.

[[Mark Milley]]

Mark Alexander Milley (born June 18, 1958) is a United States Army general. He is the 20th chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. He was the 39th Chief of Staff of the United States Army.

Dundalk (pron DUN or ˈ DUN) is an unincorporated community and census-designated place in Baltimore County, Maryland, United States. 63,597 people lived here at the 2010 census.

[[Kaja Kallas]]

CATEGORIES: 1977 births, Living people, Current national leaders, Former MEPs, People from Tallinn, Prime Ministers of Estonia, Women politicians

Kaja Kallas (born 18 June 1977) is an Estonian politician. She is the Prime Minister of Estonia since 26 January 2021. She is the first woman to be Prime Minister. She has been the leader of the Reform Party since 2018. She has been a Member of the Riigikogu from 2011 to 2014 and since 2019.

Kallas was a Member of the European Parliament from 2014 to 2018.

[[Siim Kallas]]

CATEGORIES: 1948 births, Living people, Prime Ministers of Estonia, European Union politicians, People from Tallinn

Siim Kallas (born 2 October 1948) is an Estonian politician. He was the European Commissioner for Transport between 2010 and 2014. Before that he was European Commissioner for Administrative Affairs, Audit and Anti-Fraud between 2004 and 2009. 

Kallas has been Prime Minister of Estonia from 2002 to 2003.

[[Estonian Centre Party]]

CATEGORIES: 1991 establishments in Europe, Liberal parties, Estonia

The Estonian Centre Party (Eesti Keskerakond) is a centrist, social-liberal, populist political party in Estonia. It is one of the two largest political parties in Estonia and currently has 26 seats in the Estonian Parliament. 

The party is a member of the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe (ALDE).

[[A for Andromeda]]

CATEGORIES: BBC television dramas, Science fiction books, Movies set in the future

A for Andromeda is a media drama written by Fred Hoyle and John Elliott for BBC television. It was originally presented in these forms:

There are book versions of the three works in English. They are listed in the usual sources, for example https://www.goodreads.com/series/69975.

Although at first sight the authors seem to have suggested the signal is connected with the galaxy Andromeda, further thought suggests that "from the direction of Andromeda" could describe a source within our own galaxy. And so the authors avoid the implication that the message would have taken 2.5 million years in arriving,  but could come from within our own galaxy.

The message might come from as close as 420 light years away.

[[Sylvirana spinulosa]]

The Spiny frog or fine-spined frog (Hylarana (Sylvirana) spinulosa) is a frog from Hainan Island in China.  Scientists have seen it as high as 840 meters above sea level.

[[South China Morning Post]]

CATEGORIES: English-language newspapers published in Asia, Hong Kong, 1903 establishments, 1900s establishments in Asia

The South China Morning Post (SCMP) is an English-language newspaper based in Hong Kong. It has a Sunday edition called the Sunday Morning Post. It is owned by Alibaba Group.

In 2016 there is a new owner for the newspaper. After that it has been alleged to be promoting China's power.

[[WeChat]]

CATEGORIES: Social networking, 2011 establishments in Asia, 2010s establishments in China

WeChat (微信) is a Chinese mobile app with many uses, such as messaging, social media and mobile payment. It is made by Tencent. It has been the world's largest app since 2018, and has over 1 billion monthly active users. It has been called China's "app for everything" because of how many uses it has.

User information from the app is shared with the Chinese Government as part of the country's mass surveillance network. WeChat censors some political topics in China. Data from accounts outside of China is watched and analyzed and used to make censorship algorithms in China.

In 2020, she received more popularity for her main role as a teenager with telekinetic abilities in the Netflix drama series I Am Not Okay with This.

Warren County is a county Middle Tennessee, United States. As of the 2010 census, 39,839 people lived here. Its county seat is McMinnville.

[[McMinnville, Tennessee]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Tennessee, County seats in Tennessee

McMinnville is the largest city in and the county seat of Warren County, Tennessee, United States. 13,605 people lived here at the 2010 census. It was named for Governor Joseph McMinn.

[[Chapultepec Peace Accords]]

CATEGORIES: 1990s treaties, 1992, El Salvador

The Chapultepec Peace Accords were a set of peace agreements signed on January 16, 1992. It ended the Salvadoran Civil War. The treaty created peace between the Salvadoran government and the Farabundo Martí National Liberation Front (FMLN). It was signed in Chapultepec Castle, Mexico.

The treaty was negotiated by representatives of the Salvadoran government, the rebel movement FMLN, and political parties, with observers from the Roman Catholic Church and United Nations.

[[Margitta Gummel]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2021 deaths, Competitors in athletics, Female athletes, German Olympic silver medalists, German Olympic gold medalists

Margitta Gummel (née Helmbold, 29 June 1941 – 26 January 2021) was a German Olympic shot putter. She competed for the Unified German team in the 1964 Summer Olympics. She also participated at the 1972 Summer Olympics. 

Gummel had a long rivalry with Nadezhda Chizhova of the Soviet Union. She won an Olympic gold medal in 1964 and a silver medal in 1972. Gummel was born in Magdeburg, Nazi Germany. She won two silver medals (1966, 1969) and a bronze medal (1971) at the European Athletics Championships.

Gummel died on 26 January 2021 in Wietmarschen, Germany at the age of 79.

[[Nadezhda Chizhova]]

CATEGORIES: 1945 births, Living people, Competitors in athletics, Olympic gold medalists, Olympic bronze medalists, Olympic silver medalists, Russian sportspeople

Nadezhda Vladimirovna Chizhova (Надежда Владимировна Чижова, born 29 September 1945) is a retired Russian shot putter who won three Olympic medals and four European titles, and set seven new world records. She retired after the 1976 Olympics

[[Alan Ashcroft]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2021 deaths, English rugby union players

Alan Ashcroft (21 August 1930 – 26 January 2021) was an English rugby union player. He played in the Number 8 position. Ashcroft played club rugby with Waterloo FC and was a member of the British Lions team that toured in 1959. He played for the English national rugby team from 1956 to 1959.

Ashcroft died on 26 January 2021, aged 90.

[[Chedly Ayari]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2021 deaths, Tunisian politicians, African diplomats, Economists, People from Tunis, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic

Chedly Ayari (الشاذلي العياري) (21 August 1933 – 28 January 2021) was a Tunisian politician, economist, and diplomat. He was in many cabinet positions under the Habib Bourguiba goverment. He was President of the Central Bank of Tunisia from 24 July 2012 to 16 February 2018.

Ayari was Minister of Education from 1970 to 1971. He also was Minister of Finance from 1972 to 1974. He was a member of the Socialist Destourian Party. He was born in Tunis, Tunisia.

Ayari died on 28 January 2021 from COVID-19, aged 87.

[[Héctor Fix-Zamudio]]

CATEGORIES: 1924 births, 2021 deaths, Mexican lawyers, Politicians from Mexico City, Judges, Deaths from heart failure

Héctor Fix-Zamudio (24 September 1924 – 27 January 2021) was a Mexican politician and lawyer. From 1987 to 1997, Fix-Zamudio was Judge of the Inter-American Court of Human Rights.

Fix-Zamudio was born in Mexico City. He studied at the National Autonomous University of Mexico. Fix-Zamudio died of heart failure in Mexico City on 27 January 2021, aged 96.

[[Efraín Ruales]]

[[Tupac Huallpa]]

CATEGORIES: 15th century births, 1533 deaths, Inca rulers

Tupac Huallpa (15th century – 1533) was the fourteenth Sapa Inca. He only ruled for a few months, in the year 1533, after Atahualpa, his half-brother, had been murdered. Tupac Hualpa was the last Inca ruler. He was the son of Sapa Inca Huayna Cápac. Huayana Cápac died in 1527. After that, there was a civil war between Tupac Huallpa and Huáscar, his half-brother. This war ended in 1532, with the victory of Atahualpa. Shortly aferwards Spanish troops led by Francisco Pizarro captured Huascár. Even though a large ransom was paid, Huascar was executed. Tuupac Huallpa was Huasca's younger brother. Atahualpa was executed in 1533, and the Spanish made Tupac Huallpa king of the Incas.

[[Bokeh]]

CATEGORIES: Photography

Bokeh (from the Japanese word "boke" which means "blur") is the appreciation of the blurred backgrounds seen in photography, it is also used to describe the quality of such out-of-focus backgrounds in camera lenses.

Bokeh is not a special technique but rather a natural effect caused by what photographers (people who take pictures) call a narrow depth of field, it simply means that the more light a camera lens lets in, the more blurry the background can be, distance between the subject and lens also affects bokeh, if the subject is far enough away, there will be no bokeh.

[[Ternary numeral system]]

CATEGORIES: Mathematics

A ternary /ˈtɜːrnəri/ numeral system (also called base 3) has three as its base. This means that you can only count with 0, 1, and 2. The first ten numbers in ternary are 00, 01, 02, 10, 11, 20, 21, 22, 100, 101. When all the digits in the number reach 2, you add a 1 in front and change everything else to 0. There is another system with the same name more specifically called the balanced ternary system. This system is called that way because 0 is the middle digit, with the other two digits being -1 and 1. That system is used in comparison logic and ternary computers. 

Similar to a bit in binary, a ternary digit is called a trit.

[[2016 Formula One World Championship]]

CATEGORIES: Formula One seasons, 2016 in sports

The 2016 Formula One World Championship is the 67th season of the Formula One World Championship. The motor racing championship is the highest class of competition for open-wheel racing cars. German racing driver Nico Rosberg won the title. 

The Mercedes team also won the title.

Red Bull Racing and Scuderia Toro Rosso changed drivers during the season, when Red Bull driver Daniil Kvyat switched places with Toro Rosso driver Max Verstappen. Verstappen won his first race with Red Bull at the Spanish Grand Prix.

Central Park Tower is the second tallest skyscraper in the United States. Construction of the tower started in 2013 and the building was completed in June 2021.

[[Consistent life ethic]]

CATEGORIES: Philosophy, Religion

The consistent life ethic is also known as the consistent ethic of life. It opposes abortion, capital punishment, assisted suicide, euthanasia, and war. Some people who follow this are only opposed to unjust war, and some are full pacifists. The term was made popular in 1983 by Joseph Bernardin, a Catholic Cardinal. The ideology is based on all life being important, and that it should be protected by law.

[[Mehrdad Minavand]]

CATEGORIES: 1975 births, 2021 deaths, Iranian footballers, Iranian football managers, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Iran, Sportspeople from Tehran

Mehrdad Minavand (مهرداد میناوند, 30 November 1975 – 27 January 2021) was an Iranian professional footballer and coach. He played mostly as a left midfielder, but he also was a left winger or left-back.

He played for the Iran national football team and was a participant at the 1998 FIFA World Cup.

On 21 January 2021, Minavand was hospitalised in Tehran with COVID-19. Six days later, he died from the virus on 27 January, aged 45.

[[West Bountiful, Utah]]

West Bountiful is a city in Davis County, Utah, United States. It is part of the Ogden–Clearfield, Utah Metropolitan Statistical Area. 5,265 people lived here at the 2010 census.

[[Fundamental attribution error]]

CATEGORIES: Psychology, Cognitive biases

In social-psychology, fundamental attribution error is the phenomenon where people judge other people and themselves in a different way. The person tends to judge other people's good behavior as them having a good personality and the person also judges other people's bad behavior as them having a bad personality. The error comes from the fact that the person judges themselves on the context or situation and not on personality. This can lead people to assume others are bad people instead of them making a mistake.

An example of this error would be if we had a person, who we will name Alice. Alice is a driver. Bob goes in front of her and Alice assumes he has bad personal qualities such as being selfish, being a bad driver, or being a jerk. However there are possible explanations that are related to context instead of personal qualities. Bob could have almost missed his flight, or his wife could be giving birth at the hospital. If she goes in front of someone else, she will likely make the opposite mistake and explain her behavior as situational instead of being a personal flaw. This is still the same error because it is an attribution (placement) that is wrong.

[[Klymene]]

CATEGORIES: Nymphs

Klymene was an Okeanid. She was one of the daughters of Okeanos and Thethys. Some people think she was Asia. With Iapetos, she had the children  Atlas, Prometheus, Epimetheus and Menoitio.

She was married to Merops, with whom she raised Phaethon. She also raised the Heliades with him. The father of the Heliades was Helios. She is sometimes called Merope, and Phaeton's father is given as Clymenus.

[[Ella Henderson]]

CATEGORIES: 1996 births, English singer-songwriters, English pop singers, People from Lincolnshire, Living people

Gabriella Michelle "Ella" Henderson (born 12 January 1996) is an English singer-songwriter. She competed in the ninth series of The X Factor (UK). She finished in sixth place despite being a favorite to win. Her first studio album, Chapter One (2014), reached #1 in the United Kingdom. On the album were the singles "Ghost", and the top 20 singles "Glow" and "Yours".

Henderson began singing around the age of three. She taught herself to play the piano a few years later. She began putting on shows for her family. 

Henderson was born in Tetney, Lincolnshire, England.

[[Type Ia supernova]]

CATEGORIES: Supernovae

A type Ia supernova is a type of supernova that occurs in binary systems (two stars orbiting one another) in which one of the stars is a white dwarf. The other star can be anything from a giant star to an even smaller white dwarf. Physically, carbon-oxygen white dwarfs with slow rotation are limited to below 1.44 solar masses. 

Since type Ia supernovae have a known brightness they can be used as standard candles to determine the distance to a galaxy once the stretch-factor is accounted for. 

When a runaway thermonuclear explosion rips through a white dwarf star and blows the star to bits, it is called a type 1a supernova. These explosions are incredibly violent and incredibly bright, sometimes outshining entire galaxies.

Type I (especially Ia) supernova create most of the iron and nickel found in the interstellar medium. Type 1a supernovae are several times more luminous than type Ib, Ic, and type II supernovae. They leave no core remnant behind, and happen when a low-mass star's core remnant (a white dwarf) detonates.

[[Zenith Electronics]]

CATEGORIES: American technology companies, Electronics companies, 1923 establishments in the United States

Zenith Electronics is an American research and development company. It develops Advanced Television Systems Committee (ATSC) standards and digital rights management technologies. It is owned by the South Korean company LG Electronics. Zenith was earlier an American brand of consumer electronics. The company was headquartered in Glenview, Illinois. After a series of layoffs, the consolidated headquarters moved to Lincolnshire, Illinois (north of Chicago).

Zenith-branded products were sold in North America, Vietnam, Myanmar (Burma), India, Germany, Cambodia and Thailand (until 1983)

Zenith made televisions, radios and remote controls.

Zenith Electronics was founded in Chicago, Illinois.

[[Acrolith]]

CATEGORIES: Sculpture, Ancient Greek and Roman statues

An acrolith is a type of sculpture or carved art. In an acrolith, the outermost parts, for example the head, hands and feet, are made of stone, and the rest is made in a different material. The different material is usually wood or something else that can wear out or rot, so it does not survive. Museums and other collectors often have only the stone parts. They are often separated from each other. Pausanias, a Greek traveller and geographer who lived during the 2nd century A.D., talked about acroliths.

Scientists think this might be the same frog as Sylvirana nigrovittata.

It is a part of the area covered by Kolkata Metropolitan Development Authority (KMDA). Bandel is a major rail junction station of Eastern Railway zone. It is 40 km from Howrah railway station.

[[Kote Tolordava]]

CATEGORIES: Actors from Georgia (country), 1979 births, 2015 deaths

Kote Tolordava (May 13, 1979 - April 11, 2015, Moscow, Russia) was Georgian film and theater actor.  Kote's first wife was actress Mariam Jologua.  From the marriage the couple has a son, Buka.

The actor married Gano Melitauri for the second time on June 8, 2007. By the time of Kote's death, the couple already had two children - Taso (2008) and Tara (2012), while Gano was pregnant to their third child.

He has played roles in the theaters of Marjanishvili and teenagers, as well as in the theater on Atoneli. He gained special popularity as Dito Sharashenidze in the TV series "My Wife's Girlfriends". In 2014, he participated in the documentary film "Who Killed Ilia" based on the documentary film made by the Ministry of Internal Affairs, where he played the role of Ilia Chavchavadze. Along with acting, she hosted the program "Gano and Kote" on Palitra TV with her wife Gano Melitauri.

[[A Springfield Summer Christmas for Christmas]]

[[David Kato]]

CATEGORIES: 1964 births, 2011 deaths, Ugandan people, Murder victims, Teachers, LGBT rights activists, Assassinated people, Gay men, Deaths by beating

David Kato Kisule (1964 – 26 January 2011) was a Ugandan teacher and LGBT rights activist, considered a father of Uganda's gay rights movement and described as "Uganda's first openly gay man". He served as advocacy officer for Sexual Minorities Uganda (SMUG).

Kato was murdered at his home in 2011, shortly after winning a lawsuit against a magazine which had published his name and photograph identifying him as gay and calling for him to be executed.

[[Hurricane Fifi–Orlene]]

CATEGORIES: Category 2 Atlantic hurricanes

Hurricane Fifi (later known as Hurricane Orlene) was a catastrophic tropical cyclone that killed over 8,210 people in Honduras in September 1974 , ranking it as the third deadliest Atlantic hurricane on record, only behind Hurricane Mitch in 1998, and the 1780 hurricane.

At the time that it hit, Fifi was the worst natural disaster to ever hit Honduras. It formed off the coast of Jamaica and made landfall as a Category 2 hurricane. It then weakened significantly and became a tropical storm, and then a tropical depression. It moved into the Pacific and regained strength. Fifi was a tropical cyclone that lasted for 18 hours and was renamed Orlene. Orlene then intensified into a hurricane and reached Category 2 status. Orlene made landfall in Mexico and became extratropical over the mountains.

[[Hurricane Ione]]

CATEGORIES: Category 4 Atlantic hurricanes, Retired tropical cyclone names, Hurricanes in North Carolina, 1950s in North Carolina, 1955 in the United States, September events

Hurricane Ione was a strong, Category 4 hurricane that affected North Carolina in September 1955, bringing high winds and significant rainfall. It came on the heels of Hurricanes Connie and Diane, and compounded problems already caused by the two earlier hurricanes.

[[Paradigm shift]]

CATEGORIES: Science-related lists, Natural sciences

A paradigm shift was first called that way by Thomas Kuhn. He is a physicist and philosopher. A paradigm shift is a big change in big concepts and practices in a model, system, or scientific discipline. It can also be known as a scientific revolution. 

[[New Mexico's 2nd congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Congressional districts of New Mexico

New Mexico's 2nd congressional district is a congressional district in the state of New Mexico. The district is the 5th largest congressional district in the United States of America and the largest district that is not the entire state. The district is currently represented by Republican Yvette Herrell. Yvette Herrell defeated the incumbent Democrate Xochitl Torres Small in the 2020 United States House of Representatives elections. The district was one of the 15 districts who used to have a Democrat representative but now a Republican representative in the 2020 elections.

[[Texas's 32nd congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Congressional districts of Texas

Texas's 32nd congressional district is a congressional district in the state of Texas. This district was created in 2003 after the 2000 census and Texas got two more congressional districts. The district is in northern Dallas, Texas but after redistricting in 2011-2012 it also has eastern Dallas. The district is currently represented by Democrat Colin Allred. When the district was made Republican Pete Sessions was the congressman. He was the congressman for 16 years but lost reelection to Allred.

The Indian state of West Bengal is divided into five administrative Divisions, namely:

A group of districts forms a division, which is administered by a 'Divisional Commissioner'. West Bengal is now divided in 23 districts, grouped under five divisions:

[[Pictureland]]

CATEGORIES: 1911 movies, American romance movies, American silent movies

Pictureland is a 1911 American silent romance movie directed by Thomas H. Ince and starring King Baggot, Isabel Rea. It was a previously lost movie until it was rediscovered in 2015 in Australia.

[[Lone Chaw]]

Lone Chaw(လုံးချော) is a retired Burmese fighter and former Open Lethwei World Champion.

[[Rivière-des-Prairies, Quebec]]

CATEGORIES: Landforms of North America, Geography of Quebec

The Rivière des Prairies (pronounced de pʁɛʁi; literally River of the Prairies, sometimes called the Back River in English) is a delta channel of the Ottawa River in southwestern Quebec, Canada. The indigenous inhabitants of what's now known as the Island of Montreal called it Skowanoti, meaning "River behind the island".

[[Night and Day (1946 movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 movies, 1940s musical movies, American biographical movies, American musical movies, Warner Bros. movies, Movies directed by Michael Curtiz

Night and Day is a 1946 American biographical musical movie directed by Michael Curtiz and starring Cary Grant, Alexis Smith, Selena Royle, Henry Stephenson, Jane Wyman, Dorothy Malone, Eve Arden, Ginny Simms, Paul Cavanagh, Victor Francen, Alan Hale Sr., Donald Woods. It was distributed by Warner Bros. and was nominated for an Academy Award in 1947.

[[Alabama's 4th congressional district]]

CATEGORIES: Congressional districts of Alabama

Alabama's 4th congressional district is a congressional district from the state of Alabama which elects a representative for the United States House of Representatives. The district is in the counties of Franklin, Colbert, Marion, Lamar, Fayette, Walker, Winston, Cullman, Lawrence, Marshall, Etowah, and DeKalb. The district has been represented by Republican Robert Aderholt since 1997. 

[[Robert Aderholt]]

CATEGORIES: 1965 births, 20th-century American politicians, 21st-century American politicians, United States representatives from Alabama, People from Hayleyville, Alabama, US Republican Party politicians, Living people

Robert Aderholt (born July 22, 1965) is an American politician and the representative for Alabama's 4th congressional district in the United States House of Representatives since 1997. He is a member of the Republican Party. Aderholt used to be a judge for Haleyville, Alabama. He was also a helped for the governor of Alabama, Rob James. He won the 1996 Republican primary election and won the general election. Robert Aderholt is pro-life and wanted other politicians to stop abortion. Adlerholt also believes in gun rights. In December 2020, Alderholt joined 126 Republicans to agree to stop completing the counting of the 2020 United States presidential election. 

[[Axel Tuanzebe]]

CATEGORIES: 1997 births, Black British sportspeople, English footballers, Manchester United F.C. players, People from the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Living people

Axel Tuanzebe (born 14 November 1997) is a English football player who plays for Manchester United. He was born in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. He moved to England as a child. He has represented England in several age groups.

[[European Portuguese]]

CATEGORIES: Languages of Europe, Romance languages

European Portuguese (português europeu, puɾtuˈɣez ewɾuˈpew) also known as Portuguese of Portugal (Portuguese: português de Portugal), Iberian Portuguese (Portuguese: português ibérico), Peninsular Portuguese (Portuguese: português peninsular)

is a dialect of Portuguese language spoken in Portugal.

[[Data deficient]]

CATEGORIES: Taxonomy, Conservation

Data deficient is a conservation status.  Scientists say a species is data deficient when there is not enough information to figure out how many of them there are and whether they are endangered.  Very often, this means that it is unclear, where the species lives, or how often it can be found.

[[Khwairakpa Erel]]

CATEGORIES: Religion, Islands of India, Assam

"Khwairakpa Erel" (ꯈ꯭ꯋꯥꯢꯔꯥꯛꯄ ꯏꯔꯦꯜ), also known as "Khwairakpa Erel Umang Lai Nongpok Ningthou Khuvam" (ꯈ꯭ꯋꯥꯢꯔꯥꯛꯄ ꯏꯔꯦꯜ ꯎꯃꯪ ꯂꯥꯢ ꯅꯣꯡꯄꯣꯛ ꯅꯤꯡꯊꯧ ꯈꯨꯚꯝ), is a sacred island, in the middle of the Barak river, in Lakhipur region of Cachar district in Assam. Formerly known as Naraindhor Baba, the island is a pilgrimage site of the people of Assam and Manipur.

The site is dedicated to the sylvan deity, "Khwairakpa", a form of "Nongpok Ningthou". Thousands of worshippers crowd the sacred site every year to seek blessings from the presiding deity.

[[Lake Berryessa]]

CATEGORIES: Lakes of the United States, Bodies of water of California, Napa County, California

Lake Berryessa is an artificial lake in Napa County, California. It is the largest lake in the county. It was formed after the construction of Monticello Dam, in the 1950s. Since the 1960s, the lake has provided electricity to the North Bay area of San Francisco. When it is full, the lake covers an area of about 25 by 5. It has a maximum depth of about 84. As of 2021, the lake has the largest spillway in the world. It also became known because it is the site of one of the murders of the Zodiac Killer.

[[GameStop short squeeze]]

CATEGORIES: January 2021 events, February 2021 events, Economic history, Video games

In January 2021, a fast and large increase of GameStop stock and other assets took place on many stock exchanges. It caused major damage to hedge funds. The stock price of GameStop went up by almost 200 times from its record low, hitting a high of nearly $500 per share on January 28, 2021.

This was caused by users of the forum r/wallstreetbets on Reddit through commission-free trading apps such as Robinhood.

On January 28, Robinhood stopped the buying of GameStop and other securities. This caused many criticisms and accusations of market manipulation from politicians and businesspeople.  People who criticized Robinhood were Senator Ted Cruz, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, and Tesla CEO Elon Musk. 

Lawsuits were also filed against Robinhood in the U.S. District Courts for the Southern District of New York and the Northern District of Illinois.

[[Henry VI (plays)]]

CATEGORIES: Plays by William Shakespeare, Plays by Christopher Marlowe, Plays based on British history

Henry VI is a series of three history plays by William Shakespeare. They are set during the lifetime of King Henry VI of England. 

Henry VI, Part 1 deals with the loss of England's French territories and the politics leading up to the Wars of the Roses. Henry VI, Part 2 shows the King's inability to deal with the quarrelling  nobles, and the armed conflict which follows. Henry VI, Part 3 deals with the horrors of that conflict.

In 2016, scholars working on the New Oxford Shakespeare editions, announced that they were crediting Shakespeare's colleague and rival, Christopher Marlowe, as the co-author of the trilogy. 

[[Their First Misunderstanding]]

CATEGORIES: 1911 movies, 1910s drama movies, American drama movies, American silent movies, Short movies

Their First Misunderstanding is a 1911 American short silent drama movie directed by Thomas H. Ince (who also stars) and also starring Mary Pickford, Owen Moore, Ben Turpin.

[[Marlovian theory]]

CATEGORIES: Theater, William Shakespeare, Controversies

The Marlovian theory is an idea about who wrote Shakespeare's plays.  The Marlovian theory says that Christopher Marlowe wrote most of those poems and plays. The theory also says Marlowe did not die in Deptford on 30 May 1593.  It says his death was faked. Like William Shakespeare, Christopher Marlowe was an Elizabethan poet and playwright.  They were both born in 1564.

Marlovian theory began in the 1800s. The idea is that the Church wanted to punish Marlowe for being an atheist, so Queen Elizabeth's government helped him fake his death, leave the country and continue writing plays by pretending those plays were Shakespeare's.

One piece of the puzzle is that the play Lust's Dominion was attributed to Marlowe when it was published in 1657. The play borrows from a pamphlet published in 1599, about the death of King Philip II of Spain in 1598. Marlowe died in 1593. The attribution has been recognized as spurious (wrong) by critics and scholars for nearly two centuries.

[[Ishak Pamumbu Lambe]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 births, 2021 deaths, Indonesian politicians

Ishak Pamumbu Lambe (February 6, 1946 – January 1, 2021) was an Indonesian Torajan Christian pastor and politician. He was a Senator in the national Regional Representative Council from 2004 to 2009. Lambe was also the former Chairman of the Toraja Church Synod Worker's Agency from 1992 to 2001.

Lambe died on January 1, 2021 at the age of 74.

[[Batik Air]]

CATEGORIES: Establishments in Indonesia, 2012 establishments in Asia, Airlines of Asia, Transport in Indonesia

Batik Air is an Indonesian scheduled airline which was founded in 2012. It made its first flight on 3 May 2013 from Jakarta to Manado and Yogyakarta.

As of September 2019, Batik Air flies more than 45 domestic and international routes, with over 350 flights daily. International destinations, including Singapore, Bangkok, Chennai, and Perth, as well as Guilin, Nanning, Kunming and Shenzhen

in China.

[[U.S. Bancorp]]

CATEGORIES: Banks of the United States

U.S. Bancorp (stylized as us bancorp) is an American bank which is headquartered in Minneapolis, Minnesota. The bank was founded in Delaware. It is the parent company of U.S. Bank National Association. It is the fifth largest bank in the United States. 

It has 3,106 locations and 4,842 automated teller machines, mainly in the Western and Midwestern United States.

[[Chico Borja]]

CATEGORIES: 1959 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from colorectal cancer, Ecuadorian footballers, American footballers, American football managers, People from Quito

Hernan "Chico" Borja (August 24, 1959 – January 25, 2021) was an Ecuadorian–American soccer player and coach. He made eleven appearances for the U.S. national team from 1982 to 1988.

In 1984, Borja played for the U.S. Olympic soccer team at the 1984 Summer Olympics. Borja was also on the U.S. team at the 1987 Pan American Games.

Borja died on January 25, 2021 from colon cancer at the age of 61.

[[Dick Smith (third baseman)]]

CATEGORIES: 1926 births, 2021 deaths, Pittsburgh Pirates players, Sportspeople from Pennsylvania

Richard Harrison Smith (July 21, 1926 – January 25, 2021) was an American professional baseball player. He appeared in 70 games over parts of five Major League Baseball seasons (1951–1955) as a member of the Pittsburgh Pirates. Smith was born in Blandburg, Pennsylvania.

Smith died on January 25, 2021 in Boalsburg, Pennsylvania at the age of 94.

[[Blandburg, Pennsylvania]]

CATEGORIES: Census-designated places in Pennsylvania, Unincorporated communities in Pennsylvania

Blandburg is an unincorporated community and census-designated place (CDP) in Reade Township, Cambria County, Pennsylvania, United States. 402 people lived here at the 2010 census.

[[Georgi Ananiev]]

CATEGORIES: 1950 births, 2021 deaths, Bulgarian politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Bulgaria

Georgi Gervanov Ananiev (Георги Герванов Ананиев; 12 April 1950 – 26 January 2021) was a Bulgarian politician. He was Minister of Defence between 1997 and 1999. Ananiev was born in Pernik Province, Bulgaria. 

Ananiev died on 26 January 2021 of COVID-19 during the COVID-19 pandemic in Bulgaria, aged 70.

[[Harry Beal]]

CATEGORIES: 1930 births, 2021 deaths, American military people, People from Pennsylvania

Harry Beal (August 16, 1930 – January 26, 2021) was the first US Navy Seal.

[[Gert Blomé]]

CATEGORIES: 1934 births, 2021 deaths, Swedish Olympians, Swedish ice hockey players, Olympic silver medalists

Gert Arne Blomé (28 August 1934 – 27 January 2021) was a Swedish ice hockey player. He competed at the 1960 and 1964 Winter Olympics. He won a silver medal in 1964. Blomé was born in Gävle, Sweden. 

Blomé died on 27 January 2021 in Gothenburg, Sweden at the age of 86.

[[Blas Camacho]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, 2021 deaths, Spanish politicians, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain

Blas Camacho Zancada (1939 – 27 January 2021) was a Spanish politician. He was born in Tomelloso, Sweden. He was a Deputy from 1977 to 1982 and 1986 to 1993. He was a member of the People's Party.

Camacho died of COVID-19 in Madrid on 27 January 2021 during the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain at the age of 81.

[[Adrián Campos]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from aortic dissection, Spanish sportspeople, Formula One drivers

Adrián Campos Suñer (17 June 1960 – 27 January 2021) was a Spanish Formula One driver. He participated in 21 Grands Prix. He made his first appearance on 12 April 1987. He was the founder of the Campos Meta Formula One team (later known as HRT). Campos owned Campos Racing. He was born in Alzira, Valencia. 

Campos died on 27 January 2021 in Valencia, Spain of an aortic dissection, aged 60.

[[Corky Lee]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States, American photojournalists, Journalists from New York City

Young Kwok "Corky" Lee (1947 – January 27, 2021) was an American photojournalist. He was known for taking pictures of Asian American culture which not many people paid attention to. He was known for protecting and promoting Asian American history and how it should be a part of American history. Lee was born in New York City.

Mayor of New York City David Dinkins made May 5, 1988 "Corky Lee Day". Many of his photographs appeared on Downtown Express and The Villager during the 1990s and 2000s. 

Lee died on January 27, 2021 at a hospital in New York City from problems caused by COVID-19, aged 73.

[[Lai Xiaomin]]

CATEGORIES: 1962 births, 2021 deaths, Chinese businesspeople, Chinese economists, Criminals, Executed people

Lai Xiaomin (赖小民; July 8, 1962 – January 29, 2021) was a Chinese businessman and senior economist. He was party chief and chairman of the board of China Huarong Asset Management from September 2012 to April 2018. Lai was born in Ruijin, Jiangxi, China.

In January 5, 2021, Lai was sentenced to death for bribery, embezzlement, and bigamy. He was executed on January 29, 2021 at the age of 58.

[[Tochinoumi Teruyoshi]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from pneumonia, Japanese sumo wrestlers

Tochinoumi Teruyoshi was a Japanese professional sumo wrestler. He was born in Aomori, Japan. He was the sport's 49th yokozuna. He won six special prizes. He was one of the lightest yokozuna ever at just 110 kg. He was a coach at Kasugano stable, and was head coach from 1990 until his retirement in 2003.

Teruyoshi died on January 29, 2021 from pneumonia at the age of 82.

[[Juan del Río Martín]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain, Spanish Roman Catholics, Roman Catholic bishops, Roman Catholic archbishops

Juan del Río Martín (14 October 1947 – 28 January 2021) was a Spanish Roman Catholic prelate. He was the Military Archbishop of Ordinary of Spain from 2008 until his death in 2021. From 2000 to 2008, he was Bishop of Asidonia-Jerez. del Río Martín was born in Ayamonte, Spain.

del Río Martín died on 28 January 2021 from COVID-19 in Madrid, aged 73.

[[Wismoyo Arismunandar]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 2021 deaths, Indonesian people, Generals, Asian military people

Wismoyo Arismunandar (10 February 1940 – 28 January 2021) was an Indonesian high-ranking Army officer. He was Army Chief of Staff from 1993 to 1995 and Commander of Army Strategic Command from 1990 to 1993. Arismunandar was born in Bondowoso, Dutch East Indies.

Arismunandar died on 28 January 2021 in Jakarta, Indonesia at the age of 80. 

[[Ryszard Kotys]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, 2021 deaths, Polish movie actors, Polish stage actors, Polish television actors

Ryszard Kotys (20 March 1932 – 28 January 2021) was a Polish actor. He appeared in more than 140 movies and television shows during his career. His career lasted from 1953 until his death. Kotys was born in Mniów, Poland. He was best known for his roles in Operacja Himmler, Shivers and Świat według Kiepskich.

Kotys died on 28 January 2021 of a long-illness in Poznań, Poland at the age of 88.

[[César Isella]]

CATEGORIES: 1938 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from coronary artery disease, Argentine singers, Argentine writers, Argentine musicians, Guitarists, Songwriters, Folk singers, Folk musicians

César Isella (20 October 1938 – 28 January 2021) was an Argentinian folk singer-songwriter and guitarist. He played for Los Fronterizos from 1956 to 1966. He also wrote "Canción con todos", which is thought to be the Latin American anthem. He was born in Salta, Argentina.

Isella died on 28 January 2021 in Buenos Aires from coronary artery disease, aged 82.

[[Guillermo Galeote]]

CATEGORIES: 1941 births, 2021 deaths, Deaths from the COVID-19 pandemic in Spain, Spanish politicians, Spanish physicians

Guillermo Galeote Jiménez (6 May 1941 – 28 January 2021) was a Spanish politician and physician. He was a member of the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party. Galeote was born in San Sebastián, Spain. Galeote was a member of the Congress of Deputies from 1977 to 1993.

Galeote died on 28 January 2021 in Madrid from COVID-19, aged 79.

[[Maravilha, Santa Catarina]]

CATEGORIES: Cities in Santa Catarina

Maravilha, Santa Catarina is a city in the state of Santa Catarina in the South region of Brazil.

[[Sylvirana faber]]

CATEGORIES: Animals of Asia, Frogs

Sylvirana faber is a frog.  It lives in the hills in Cambodia and Thailand.

The adult frog is 5.9 cm long.  The head is long and narrow.  There are eight vomerine teeth in its jaw.

This frog is light brown in color on the back and dark brown on the sides and eardrum.  There are stripes of dark brown on its legs.  The belly is white and the insides of the legs are pink.  There are disks for climbing on its toes.

Scientists say this frog is related to Rana nigrovittata and ''Rana mortenseni.

[[Paul J. Crutzen]]

CATEGORIES: 1933 births, 2021 deaths, Dutch academics, Dutch chemists, Dutch Nobel Prize winners, People from Amsterdam

Anthropocene term

ChemistryPaul Jozef Crutzen (pʌul ˈjoːzəf ˈkrɵtsə(n); 3 December 1933 – 28 January 2021) was a Dutch atmospheric chemist.  He won the Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 1995. He was known for work on the ozone layer and climate change.

Crutzen died on 28 January 2021 at the age of 87.

[[Eddie Connachan]]

CATEGORIES: 1935 births, 2021 deaths, Scottish footballers

Edward Devlin Connachan (27 August 1935 – 28 January 2021) was a Scottish football goalkeeper. He played for Dunfermline Athletic, Middlesbrough, Falkirk, East London Celtic and the Scotland national team.

[[Donald M. Blinken]]

CATEGORIES: 1925 births, Living people, Ambassadors of the United States, Businesspeople from New York City, Politicians from New York City, US Democratic Party politicians

Donald Mayer Blinken (born November 11, 1925) is an American politician and businessman. He was born in New York City.

Blinken was director and one of the founders of E. M. Warburg Pincus & Company. He was the board chairman of the State University of New York from 1978 to 1990. He was the American Ambassador to Hungary from 1994 to 1998 during the Bill Clinton presidency. He is the father of United States Secretary of State Antony Blinken.

[[Harriet Andersson]]

CATEGORIES: 1932 births, Living people, Swedish movie actors, Swedish television actors, Swedish stage actors, Swedish voice actors, Actors from Stockholm

Harriet Andersson (born 14 February 1932) is a Swedish actress. She is best known for appearing in many movies directed by Ingmar Bergman and eventually being his romantic partner. Andersson appeared in several of his best-known movies, including Smiles of a Summer Night (1955), Through a Glass Darkly (1961), Cries and Whispers (1972), and Fanny and Alexander (1982).

[[Nils Eklund]]

CATEGORIES: 1927 births, Living people, Swedish movie actors, Swedish television actors, Swedish stage actors, Swedish voice actors, Actors from Stockholm

Nils Eklund (born 17 January 1927) is a Swedish actor. He has appeared in more than 50 movies and television shows since 1952. He was born in Stockholm.

Eklund appeared in Äktenskapsbrottaren (1964), Rooftree (1967), Doctor Glas (1968), The Bookseller Gave Up Bathing (1969), Pistol (1973), Peter-No-Tail (1981), Göta kanal eller Vem drog ur proppen? (1981), The Journey to Melonia (1989), Freud's Leaving Home (1991)

He voiced dubbed Charles F. Muntz in the Swedish version of the 2009 Disney movie Up.

[[Alan Blinken]]

CATEGORIES: 1937 births, Living people, Ambassadors of the United States, Politicians from New York City, Businesspeople from New York City, US Democratic Party politicians

Alan John Blinken (born 1937) is an American businessman and politician. He was the U.S. Ambassador to Belgium from 1993 to 1997 during the Bill Clinton presidency. He was born in New York City.

Blinken was also the 2002 Democratic nominee for Idaho United States Senator, losing to Larry Craig.

He is the brother of U.S. Ambassador Donald M. Blinken and the uncle of United States Secretary of State Antony Blinken.

[[Abdellatif Kechiche]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, Living people, Tunisian actors, Tunisian writers, French movie directors, French movie actors, French screenwriters, People from Tunis

Abdellatif Kechiche (abdɛlatif keʃiʃ; عبد اللطيف كشيش, born 7 December 1960) is a Tunisian-French actor, movie director and screenwriter. He is known for directing the movie Blue Is the Warmest Colour, which won the Palme d'Or at the 2013 Cannes Film Festival.

[[Ruggero Deodato]]

CATEGORIES: 1939 births, Italian movie directors, Italian movie producers, Italian screenwriters, Italian movie actors, Living people

Ruggero Deodato (born 7 May 1939) is an Italian movie director, screenwriter and actor. His best known movie is Cannibal Holocaust, thought to be one of the most controversial and brutal in the history of cinema. It has been banned or censored in many countries. He is known as "Monsieur Cannibal" in France.

Deodato has inspired many movie directors like Oliver Stone, Quentin Tarantino and Eli Roth.

[[Michael O'Donoghue]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 births, 1994 deaths, American television writers, American editors, Journalists from New York City, Comedians from New York City, Deaths from cerebral hemorrhage

Michael O'Donoghue  (January 5, 1940 – November 8, 1994) was an American writer and performer. He was known for his dark comedy and humor. He was known for his writings for National Lampoon magazine. He was the first head writer of Saturday Night Live. He was born in Sauquoit, New York.

O'Donoghue died on November 8, 1994 in New York City of an intracerebral hemorrhage, aged 54.

[[Sauquoit, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Hamlets in New York

Sauquoit is a hamlet in the Town of Paris, Oneida County, New York, United States.

[[Paris, New York]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in New York

Paris is a town in Oneida County, New York, United States. The town is in the southeast part of the county and is south of Utica. 4,411 people lived here at the 2010 census.

[[Goddess Bunny]]

CATEGORIES: 1960 births, 2021 deaths, LGBT actors, LGBT entertainers, LGBT models, Drag queens, American movie actors, Transgender and transsexual people, Actors from Santa Monica, California, Models from California, Deaths from poliomyelitis

Sandra "Sandie" Crisp; (January 13, 1960 – January 27, 2021), also known by her stage name The Goddess Bunny, was an American entertainer, drag queen, actress, and model. She was born in Santa Monica, California.

She made her acting debut as Charlean in the 1986 movie Hollywood Vice Squad. He made an appearance in the music video for "The Dope Show" by Marilyn Manson.

Crisp was a transgender woman. She was born with polio.

Crisp ran as a write-in candidate for President of the United States in the 2020 election.

Crisp died on January 27, 2021 from problems caused by polio and HIV, at age 61.

[[The Boys (2019 TV series)]]

CATEGORIES: 2010s American television series debuts, American satirical television series, DC Comics

The Boys is an American satirical superhero streaming television series. It is created by Eric Kripke for Prime Video. 

It is based on the comic book of the same name by Garth Ennis and Darick Robertson, which was originally published by DC Comics. It is about vigilantes with superpowers who abuse their abilities. 

It stars Karl Urban, Jack Quaid, Laz Alonso, Tomer Capon, Karen Fukuhara, Antony Starr, Erin Moriarty, Dominique McElligott, Chace Crawford, Jessie T. Usher and Nathan Mitchell.

The series premiered on July 26, 2019.

CATEGORIES: 1994 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, Actors from New York City

Erin Elair Moriarty (born June 24, 1994) is an American actress. She is best known for her role as Annie January / Starlight in the Amazon Prime Video series The Boys (2019–present).

[[Chace Crawford]]

CATEGORIES: 1985 births, Living people, American movie actors, American television actors, American voice actors, Actors from Texas, People from Lubbock, Texas

Christopher Chace Crawford (born July 18, 1985) is an American actor. He is known for his role as Nate Archibald on The CW's teen drama series Gossip Girl. In 2019, he appeared as the Deep in the Amazon Prime Video original series The Boys.

[[Afro-Jamaicans]]

CATEGORIES: African people, Ethnic groups in Jamaica

Afro-Jamaicans are Jamaicans of predominantly or majority  Sub-Saharan African descent. They presently represent the largest ethnic group in the country.

[[Ancient Manipur]]

CATEGORIES: History of Manipur

Ancient Manipur, also known as Antique Kangleipak, was an antique civilization, concentrated along the central plains of the present day Manipur, India.

The Kangla served as the foremost capital city of Ancient Manipur (Kangleipak) from the 15th century BC upto the late 19th century AD. It has its earliest evidence of monarchy right from 15th century BC, during the reign of Emperor "Tangja Leela Pakhangba" (1445 BC-1405 BC).

[[Hurricane Anna (1961)]]

CATEGORIES: Category 2 Atlantic hurricanes

Hurricane Anna hit Central America and the Windward Islands in July 1961. Anna was the first tropical cyclone and first hurricane of the 1961 hurricane season. Anna developed on July 20 from an easterly wave in the Intertropical Convergence Zone over the Windward Islands.

[[Online encyclopedia]]

An online encyclopedia, also called an internet encyclopedia, or a digital encyclopedia, is an encyclopedia accessible through the internet. Such as Wikipedia, which is an example of an encyclopedia, just online.

[[Provisional names for elements]]

The elements RUTHERFORDIUM to OGGENESSIAN had provisional "names" and "symbols". Here is a graph with all the names wanted.And a table with the rules for what some people call "number naming" (the provisional names), mad by IUPAC.

UNUNENIUM has not been discovered-but someone made it be called LIGHTINIUM (zigzag dragons).

[[Piccadilly Incident]]

CATEGORIES: 1946 movies, 1940s drama movies, British drama movies, Movies directed by Herbert Wilcox

Piccadilly Incident is a 1946 British drama movie directed by Herbert Wilcox and starring Anna Neagle, Michael Wilding, Coral Browne, Edward Rigby, Leslie Dwyer, Brenda Bruce, Reginald Owen, Roger Moore, Michael Medwin.

[[Bengal Fan]]

CATEGORIES: Geography of Bangladesh, Landforms of India

The Bengal Fan, also known as the Ganges Fan, is the largest submarine fan on Earth. The fan is about 3,000 km (1,900 mi) long, 1,430 km (890 mi) wide. It has a maximum thickness of 16.5 km (10.3 mi). The fan was formed by the erosion of the Himalayas and the Tibetan Plateau. This happened because of the collision between the Indian Plate and the Eurasian Plate. Most of the sediment in the fan comes from the Ganges and Brahmaputra rivers which supply the Lower Meghna delta in Bangladesh and the Hoogly delta in India. The oldest sediments gotten from the Bengal fan are from Early Miocene age.

The fan was first discovered by bathymetric survey in the sixties by Bruce C. Heezen and Marie Tharp which identified the abyssal cone and canyon structures. It was named by Joseph Curray and David Moore in 1968.

[[One Wild Oat]]

CATEGORIES: 1951 comedy movies, British comedy movies, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by Charles Saunders

One Wild Oat is a 1951 British comedy movie directed by Charles Saunders and was based on the play of the same name by Vernon Sylvaine. It stars Robertson Hare, Stanley Holloway, Sam Costa, Andrew Crawford, Robert Moreton, Audrey Hepburn, Roger Moore.

[[Mirkelam]]

CATEGORIES: 1966 births, Living people, Turkish singers

Fergan Mirkelam (born 20 May 1966, Istanbul) is a Turkish singer. He first became known with his song "Her Gece" ("Every Night") in 1995.

[[Haynesville, Louisiana]]

CATEGORIES: Towns in Louisiana

Haynesville is a small town in Claiborne Parish, Louisiana, United States.

[[Secret Beyond the Door...]]

CATEGORIES: 1947 movies, 1940s thriller movies, American thriller movies, Movies directed by Fritz Lang

[[Hurricane Gladys (1968)]]

CATEGORIES: Category 1 Atlantic hurricanes, Hurricanes in Florida, Natural disasters in Canada, 1960s in Cuba, 1960s in Canada, 1968 in the United States, October events

Hurricane Gladys was the first Atlantic hurricane to be observed each by the Hurricane Hunters, radar imagery, and photographs from space. The seventh named storm and fifth hurricane of the 1968 season, Gladys formed on October 13 in the western Caribbean from a broad disturbance related to a tropical wave.

[[Our Town (movie)]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 movies, 1940s romance movies, 1940s drama movies, American romantic drama movies, Movies based on plays, Movies directed by Sam Wood

Our Town is a 1940 American romantic drama movie directed by Sam Wood and was based on the 1938 play of the same name by Thornton Wilder. It stars William Holden, Martha Scott, Fay Bainter, Beulah Bondi, Thomas Mitchell, Guy Kibbee, Stuart Erwin, Frank Craven and was nominated for 6 Academy Awards in 1941.

[[Gleðibankinn]]

CATEGORIES: 1986 songs

"Gleðibankinn" (English translation: "Bank of Fun") is a song by ICY. Singers Eiríkur Hauksson, Helga Möller and Pálmi Gunnarsson were part of the band. It was the first Icelandic entry and the first song in Icelandic at the Eurovision Song Contest, being performed at Eurovision Song Contest 1986.

The music is positive. It talks about "the bank of fun", which is said to be where people's happiness is found, and not "your empty blues". And because happiness is stored in a bank, it can be taken out at any time when someone is feeling depressed.

Before the song was submitted, all three members performed the song. Only Pálmi Gunnarsson performed the song in the Icelandic finals.

It was the sixth song to be performed, after the United Kingdom's Ryder with "Runner In The Night" and before the Netherlands' Frizzle Sizzle with "Alles heeft ritme". When voting closed, it had 19 points, placing 16th out of 20 countries.

The next song performed for Iceland was Hægt og hljótt by Halla Margrét, which was performed at Eurovision Song Contest 1987.

[[Shunning]]

CATEGORIES: Religions, Social issues, Taxation, Punishments

Shunning is the rejection of a person. It is usual in some religious groups to cut people off if they do not believe the beliefs or follow the rules of the group. It has been used in industrial action (strikes) and as a punishment in certain societies.

[[Jodie Comer]]

CATEGORIES: 1993 births, English movie actors, English television actors, English stage actors, English child actors, Emmy Award winning actors, Actors from Liverpool, Living people

Jodie Marie Comer (born 11 March 1993) is an English actress. 

She is best known for her role as Villanelle in the  BBC drama spy thriller Killing Eve (2018–present). She got critical acclaim and won the Primetime Emmy Award for Outstanding Lead Actress in a Drama Series and the British Academy television award for Best Actress.

Comer's other notable roles include Chloe Gemell in the E4 comedy-drama series My Mad Fat Diary (2013–2015), Kate Parks in the BBC One drama series Doctor Foster (2015–2017), Ivy Moxam in the BBC Three drama miniseries Thirteen (2016), and Elizabeth of York in the Starz historical miniseries The White Princess (2017).

[[Sylvirana maosonensis]]

The Mao-son frog or Maoson frog (Sylvirana maosonensis) is a frog from China, Laos and Vietnam.

[[Hurricane Hilda]]

CATEGORIES: Category 4 Atlantic hurricanes, Retired tropical cyclone names, Hurricanes in Louisiana, 1960s in Louisiana, 1964 in the United States

Hurricane Hilda was an intense tropical cyclone that ravaged areas of the United States Gulf Coast, particularly Louisiana. In addition to its damage inland, the hurricane greatly disrupted offshore oil production, and at its time was the costliest tropical cyclone for Louisiana's offshore oil production.

[[Kotowice, Masovian Voivodeship]]

CATEGORIES: Villages in Poland

Kotowice is a village in the administrative district of Gmina Brwinów, within Pruszków County, Masovian Voivodeship, in east-central Poland. It lies approximately 5 west of Brwinów, 11 west of Pruszków, and 26 west of Warsaw.

The village has a population of 100.

[[Praise-God Barebone]]

CATEGORIES: 1590s births, 1679 deaths, Writers from London

Praise-God Barebone (or Barbon or Barbone) about 1598–1679, was an English leather-seller, and a preacher. He was influential when Oliver Cromwell ruled Britain.

His name is recalled in the Barebone's Parliament of the English Commonwealth of 1653. The Commonwealth was the political structure from 1649 to 1660. England and Wales, later with Ireland and Scotland, were governed as a republic. This was after the end of the Second English Civil War, and the trial and execution of Charles I of England.

[[Tallard]]

CATEGORIES: Communes in Hautes-Alpes

Tallard is a commune in the Hautes-Alpes department.

[[Schadenfreude]]

CATEGORIES: Emotions

Schadenfreude comes from the German word by the same name. It literally translates to harm joy. It is the happiness that somebody gets when somebody else is hurt. Psychologists theorize that there are three causes for this emotion. Aggression, rivalry, or justice. Aggression-based schadenfreude happens because seeing someone else's group fail makes them feel better about themselves. Rivalry-based schadenfreude happens because seeing someone else fail makes them feel better about themselves. These may seem similar, but the difference is in that aggression is related to in-group and out-group identities, and rivalry is based on individuals. The last form is justice-based schadenfreude. This happens because people feel happy that someone bad is being punished. They feel good that the bad person is getting what they deserve.

[[Kitty Foyle]]

CATEGORIES: 1940 movies, 1940s romance movies, 1940s drama movies, American romantic drama movies, Movies based on books, Movies directed by Sam Wood

Kitty Foyle (also known as The Natural History of a Woman) is a 1940 American romantic drama movie directed by Sam Wood and was based on the 1939 novel of the same name by Christopher Morley. It stars Ginger Rogers, Dennis Morgan, James Craig, Gladys Cooper, Eduardo Ciannelli, Ernest Cossart, Walter Kingsford, Cecil Cunningham, Edward Fielding, Odette Myrtil and was distributed by RKO Radio Pictures. It was nominated for 5 Oscars and won an Academy Award in 1941.

[[Action in the North Atlantic]]

CATEGORIES: 1943 movies, 1940s war movies, 1940s drama movies, American war movies, American drama movies, World War II movies, Warner Bros. movies, Movies directed by Lloyd Bacon

Action in the North Atlantic (also known as Heroes Without Uniforms) is a 1943 American World War II drama movie directed by Lloyd Bacon and starring Humphrey Bogart, Raymond Massey, Ruth Gordon, Alan Hale Sr., Julie Bishop, Sam Levene, Dane Clark, Peter Whitney. It was distributed by Warner Bros. and was nominated for an Academy Award in 1944.

[[Spillway]]

CATEGORIES: Engineering

A spillway is a construction to release extra water from a dam, in a way that this water does not cause damage. Each dam has a maximum capacity. Water that is more than this capacity cannot be stored, and has to be released. A spillway allows to do this in a safe way.

[[Beal Crossing, Louisiana]]
